genius_description:
Drake reunites with Atlanta trap artists Future and Young Thug for a tribute to the Atlanta rap collective D4L, which consisted of members Fabo, Mook-B, Stoney, and Shawty Lo.

The song is a remix of Dreezy’s and 2 Chainz‘ January 2018 track “2nd to None”–which was also produced by Southside.

Throughout the track, the trio represent their individual labels, Drake’s October’s Very Own (OVO), Future’s FreeBandz Gang (FBG), and Thugger’s Young Stoner Life Records (YSL), brag about their high-class lifestyles, and interpolate Drizzy’s iconic “what’s hannenin'?” from his June 2010 single with Lil Wayne, “Miss Me”—a line which was in turn borrowed from D4L’s November 2005 song, “I’m Da Man.”
genius_annotations:
[('I remember grade six, I was up in Payless tryna get some Asics
 Now I’m Nike’d down in a motherfuckin’ snake pit', [['Payless ShoeSource is an international footwear chain that sells shoes at a discount price and Asics is an inexpensive Japanese shoe brand.

Nike is a popular brand that sells footwear, clothing, equipment, accessories, and more. Unlike Asics, most Nike products are expensive. Drake reflects on how he couldn’t afford expensive brands like Nike when he was younger and how he now can easily afford it.



Drake wearing a Nike sweatsuit and Nike sneakers']]), ('Bowen Homes, you know, that shiesty shit (What’s hannenin’?)', [["The Bowen Homes are a section of housing projects which were originally built in 1964 and were demolished in 2009. The homes were located in the Bankhead section of Atlanta, Georgia. Both Young Thug and Future are Atlanta natives.

D4L are from the Bowen Homes and T.I. shot the music video for What Up, What’s Haapnin' at the Bowen Homes. The video can be viewed here."]]), ('Richard Mille, all this year, nigga, what’s hannenin’? (What’s hannenin’?)', [['Richard Mille is a Swiss luxury watchmaker, famous for their unique casings and visible mechanics.

The RM 56-02 Tourbillon Sapphire is priced at insane $2,020,000 for its complex case design, pure sapphire, and pulleys air suspension movement.



Young Thug also name-dropped the Swiss watchmaker on his August 2018 track, “Tsunami”:

I put your name on my wrist
Fat Richard Mille on my wrist']]), ('Foreign breed, American, she call me papi (Yeah, yeah, yeah)', [['Here, Future references Drake’s Instagram username, @champagnepapi. He also goes under the moniker “papi” when addressed by his foreign female counterpart, who presumably is of Spanish descent, since “papi” is Spanish for “daddy.”']]), ('I eat calamari (Brr, yeah, yeah, yeah)', [['Young Thug has previously displayed his affection for calamari. In the Jaden Smith-featured track, Sin.

Plus she got red calamari skin']]), ('On that Earl Manigault, shootin’ it out the spoon', [['Earl Manigault was an American street basketball player, famous for his nickname as the Goat. Many believe that Earl is the origin of the GOAT acronym, meaning greatest of all time. GOAT is now a common term used in basketball debates as well as rap and other industries.']]), ('Woah, woah, Bankhead, started seein’ spaceships, woah', [["Drake pays more homage to D4L as this is an allusion to the group’s November 2005 song, “Scotty”:

I’m startin' to see spaceships on Bankhead"]]), ('(808 my crew)
 (Ayy, Southside, where you get all that drip?)', [['This is the producer tag of Atlanta-based producer Southside, who, alongside, fellow Atlanta producer Lex Luger, formed the iconic producer conglomerate 808 Mafia.

This is the sixth official collaboration between Drake and Southside, following:



“Company” (Feb. 2015)

“Digital Dash” with Future (Sep. 2015)

“Live from the Gutter” with Future

“I’m the Plug” with Future (Sep. 2015)

“Grammys” (Apr. 2016)



Southside has also produced on a number of tracks where Drake has been featured, most prominently seen on Gucci Mane’s January 2017 track “Both” and DJ ESCO’s June 2016 track “100it Racks.”']]), ('D4L, Stunna Man, say what’s hannenin’? (What’s hannenin’?)', [["D4L is a 2000s rap group made up of Atlanta rappers Fabo, Mook-B, Stoney and Shawty Lo. The group is best known for their chart-topping November 2005 track “Laffy Taffy,” which hit #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 in January 2006. “Stunna Man” is a nod to Stoney, who was also known as Stuntman.

The phrase “What’s hannenin'?” was first popularized  by D4L on their 2005 track “I’m Da Man”

That’s what’s hannenin'
And you know I keep work

What’s hannenin', I’m the man, bitch I’m the man

Drake would later use the phrase on his June 2010 single, “Miss Me”:

I said, “Tell me what’s really goin' on”
Drizzy back up in this thing, I’m ready, what’s hannenin'?"]]), ('FBG, YSL, know just what’s brackin’, yeah (Yeah, yeah)', [['Drake, Future, and Young Thug each shout out their respective labels on the chorus of the track. Future (FREEBANDZ Gang, or FBG), Thugger (Young Stoner Life Records, or YSL) and Drake (October’s Very Own, or OVO) all founded and have at least partial ownership in their respective label.

All three of the featured artists have long collaboration histories with each other, and their labels have even teamed up to release two collaboration tapes:


FBG & OVO for September 2015’s What a Time to Be Alive

FBG & YSL for October 2017’s SUPER SLIMEY




Future and Thug have both confirmed that a sequel to SUPER SLIMEY is also coming soon, also incorporating YSL artist Gunna and Quality Control artist Lil Baby into the collaboration.']])]

genius_description:
Hate the way I miss you (short term Hate the way) is the first single off These Things Happen Too.

The song is about a relationship that didn’t went well but overall (said by G-Eazy in a interview) its about getting related to missing someone or something.
This features the long time collaborator blackbear who the two have worked together on songs such as Remember You.

This song was announced in early 2020 with a feature from late rapper Juice WRLD, however his feature was removed when the song released officially possibly due to his label wanting to use his verse for one of his many upcoming posthumous songs.

“These Things Happen Too” is the sequel of his 2014 success album “These Things Happen”. We will probably get back an old G-Eazy, with nostalgic songs like this single.
We already teased the album by doing as blackbear feature like he did on the presequel.
genius_annotations:
[('Hate the way you talkin’ when you with your friends, too
 Yeah, they don’t know about the shit we’ve been through
 I said I hate the fucking way I always', [['Gerald: “ This  song does not offer a solution. It’s more of like a case study on what it feels like to be back and forth and be on the fence and experience the highest the highest but then the lowest to lowest. But then at the end of the day, when dust settles, stuff stops burning and blowing, I still miss you. You’re in the back of my mind. ”

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('Wishin’ I was closer to you, wish you wasn’t distant
 Wishin’ I was with you, still wish this shit was different
 Wishin’ we could travel back in time and we could switch it
 All this pain, wishin’ it was something that could fix it', [['Gerald: “The reputation of word "wishing” over and over in that sequence is to trying to hammer down the point of this empty hope. You wish s*** was better but at the same time you’re not doing the steps to fix those things that aren’t better. It’s not going to fix itself. But more often than not, the behaviors of people in those situations is just wishing it would just go away, wishing it would just be better without the necessary steps that are required to get you there."

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('Lie to myself every time I say that I’m done with you
 Every day without you passes slower than one with you
 Two days pass, it’s feelin’ like a week, this shit is stressful
 I swear all these helpin’ hands ain’t even helpful', [['Gerald: “The past 10 years of me, touring and doing music… You live so much life, you’ve seen so much life in a such short amount of time. But it creates this really fast-paced lifestyle. When that’s just going and going and going, the pace is really fast and you’re not thinking. But then when you try to step back and do nothing, time is passing so much slower because you’re used to everything going so fast, its like "Okay. Let me stay inside. Let me not see anybody. Let me not think about this person.” “Is it only been a day?!Has is only been two days?!”.

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('Know I got my issues, some I won’t admit to
 No one’s got the answers, everybody wants to fix you', [['G-eazy said: “ A big thing in a relationships is being able to take ownership/being able to accept it "okey i did this that was f***** up.” It’s much easier to just get mad at the others than it is to look inwardly and be like “okey.” It’s just something i’ve tried to work through."

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('Made a promise to myself, a promise I should stick to
 Talkin’ to myself, I said I promised I would quit you
 I’ve been trying to let go, but it’s powerful, it grips you
 First, you think you got control until I see you, can’t resist you', [['G-Eazy says: “ Habits into dependency, addiction, the general realm of things like that is a wide world. You could be addicted to food, drugs, to people or certain types of behavior. I’ve always been a fan of storytelling songs and that kind of keep it vague and open for interpretation. The whole entire time you don’t know "is he talking about this ?”, “is he talking about that ?” “.
So he leave it open for interpretation of whatever you’re going through.

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('And every time I leave, it’s too long
 And every time I leave, it’s all wrong (You know)
 I hate the way, the way I always miss you (Ayy, yeah)
 I hate the way, the way I always miss you, yeah (Yeah)', [['According to Genius’s interview with blackbear, he said: “It’s insane not leaving the crib for so long. Because last year, it was every weekend i had a college, every other weekend i was in a different countries. This type of missing someone, or missing somethings is a totally different from being far away. Because you feel even further, even though we are in the same country or whatever it is. You know you feel even further, I think it hit different.”

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('Yeah, I hate the way, the way I always miss you
 Yeah, I know I’m crazy, but you’re sick, too
 Even after everything we’ve been through
 Thought I was the one with all the issues', [['According to Genius’s interview with blackbear, he said: “It just talks about toxicity, the song really has this high level of toxicity and it really speaks to me because mental health is a huge deal. I struggle with anxiety, seasonal depression, all kinds of s***. This song spoke to me in a deeper way and i tweeted out. For some of us mental health day is every day because it is, and thats the truth.”

https://youtu.be/i9nPI17D4IU']]), ('Medicate myself, different substances, I mix it
 Set my limits, try to draw the line and then she sniffs it', [['G-Eazy plays on the idiom “draw the line,” which means to set boundaries. Although he’s expressing a wish to get clean, his girl draws him into drug abuse, disregarding the limits he set.

G-Eazy often raps about drugs in his music, which he delved deeper into in a 2018 interview with Billboard. Regarding his consumption, he said:

Well, I think that’s a blurry line, it’s not black and white, I think sometimes the line between recreation or just tapping in turns into leaning on or depending on or escaping from.

Gerald used the same idiom on 2014’s “Tumblr Girls”:

Loves the drama, she chose it
She draws the line then she blows it']]), ('See your face on my Explore and then I miss you', [["G-Eazy sees his ex-lover on Instagram’s ‘explore' page, which typically showcases new content. “Missing” can be seen as ignoring someone, but in this context likely means he feels her absence.

Gerald uses social media to illustrate his points in songs such as 2020’s “Had Enough,” where he states:

It’s been this long so why you callin' me?
Texting the homies, you re-followed me

However, this is emphasized more on  “Special Love” released in 2017, where he raps the following:

I know you hate to party, know you want me off that shit
Un-followed you on IG but I can’t lie, I still watch that shit (yeah)"]]), ('Got this magic 8 ball, but I ain’t got no crystal', [['A Magic 8 Ball is a fortune-telling device invented by Albert Carter, according to Magic8ball.org, and uses a 20-sided die that, when shook, provides an answer to a question.

On the other hand, healing crystals are marketed as an alternative medicine and were the subject of a 2017 article by Time:

Crystals or placing them on your body is thought to promote physical, emotional, and spiritual healing. Crystals supposedly do this by positively interacting with your body’s energy field or chakra.

G-Eazy states that while he has the answers, he is seemingly not of sound mind to act on these answers and subsequent advice, and craves the relationship over any stability or progression in his life.

This can also be seen as a double entendre, as “8-ball” and “crystal” are slang terms for cocaine and crystal meth respectively. G-Eazy was arrested for possessing cocaine in 2018.']])]

genius_description: H.E.R takes it back and samples Herb Alpert’s 1987 hit “Making Love in the Rain” on her rnb jam “Damage”. On the track she expresses how she doesn’t want to be taken for granted by her lover and how they need to be careful with her because they could hurt her .
genius_annotations:
[('Either learn me or I’m a lesson, gone, no', [['Relationships, getting to know somebody, it takes patience. And you gotta get to know that person, how that person wants to be loved. So you can either learn me or I’m a lesson.']]), ('Careful what you take for granted, yeah
 ’Cause with me know you could do damage
 You (Uh), you could do damage
 You (You), you could do damage (You, you, you, you)', [['“Damage” is really expressing that vulnerability that you have when you like somebody or you’re getting to know somebody in a relationship and you just hope that they won’t do damage. You hope they won’t break your heart.']])]

genius_description:
The Compton rapper, YG assists H.E.R on this song in the attempts of showcasing two sides to her supposed new perspectives on love and relationships.
The first being that she is slowly coming out of the shadows following her often anonymity in which she clearly portrays this by her frequent use of sun glasses so as to hide her eyes from the general public and love in general but this time even from the music video, her contact with the camera which is portrayed as the lover shows her steady movement to being less anonymous and more willing to show love.
The second is how she tries to show her loving and presumably sexual side and this is due to the 97 bpm that the song is done in in the B major key.
genius_annotations:
[('I ain’t gotta know astrology, I know your vibe', [['This line may seem like a throwaway jab at Co-Star users, but it instantly acquires a more significant meaning when you consider that the song dropped on the heels of YG and Kehlani debuting their relationship on Instagram. After all, the R&B songstress is known to take astrology pretty seriously.



YG respectfully suggests that he’s a more grounded individual who may not know a sun sign from an ascending, but it doesn’t stop him from connecting with his lover.']]), ('Where we goin’? Baby, what’s the move?
 We should take a trip up to the moon
 Get a room', [['When I say let’s go to the moon, I’m like, there’s nothing we can’t do together. There is nowhere we can’t go. This is literally building with somebody at the same time as it could be being in the moment with somebody. We should take a trip to the moon. Who does that? Who goes to the moon? We can. We should get a room.']]), ('I don’t care if we on the run
 Nothin’ matters when we one on one
 Lookin’ at us ‘cause we goin’ dumb', [['When you’re in the car with somebody and they play some Bay Area music, you’re going dumb. This is going dumb when you just, you just beat in it. And that’s the hyphen movement right there, that’s what we do in our candy pink car. We, we go dumb.']]), ('Baby, when we gon’ slide? Hey, hey
 Up all night, baby, when we gon’ slide? Oh, yeah, yeah
 Baby when we gon’ slide, slide, slide, slide?
 Slide, uh', [['People in the Bay always say, “I’m finna slide. I’m finna slide,” or, “I’m going to come scoop.” That’s just the lingo, you know? So, when we going to slide? When we going? Where are we going? What are we doing? It’s just, like I said, that urgency of let’s be in this moment. What are we doing? Tell me what it is, you know? Tell me to go. I don’t even remember if the word came with the melody, but everything was just a flow. Like it felt so seamless in creation.']]), ('Tell me when to go, baby, when we gon’ slide?', [['The Hyphy Movement. E-40, obviously, inspired that line. “Tell me when to go. Tell me when to go.” It’s direct. Like Kendrick said, E-40 head is thinking rational. So, that’s inspiration. Vallejo.']]), ('Ooh, I got five, you know it’s all live', [['When I was a kid, I ain’t know what the song was talking about. I don’t think anybody as a kid knew what the song was talking about. In the song it’s more so like I’m a put $5 on gas, on a gas tank, just put it that way.']]), ('And we up ‘til six in the mornin’
 When the sun rise, we be on it', [['My favorite time of day is sunrise and sunset. So that moment, it’s just a small moment. The song is about a moment and the sunrise is a very short period of time. You have just a few minutes to catch it. So that’s where that comes from, it’s just being in the moment.']]), ('With the top down screamin’, “Money ain’t a thing”', [['It’s really just that free feeling, like we don’t care about anything. We ain’t worried about nothing but this moment right here. That’s where that inspiration came from.']]), ('Doin’ our thing, movin’ too fast
 Candy paint with the windows all black', [['When I think about the Bay Area, I think about being home in downtown Vallejo and seeing all the candy-paint cars. That’s really where that came from. I grew up seeing people ghost-riding the whip and doing donuts in these amazing blue, purple, different colored cars.  I never got a candy-painted ride, unfortunately. But my ride is matte black, which I think is more me, if a little bit more mysterious and cool.']]), ('I don’t plan on gettin’ no sleep, while we', [['With all my songs, I like it to be conversational. Most of my songs, it kind of sounds like a text message or something. So I felt like the whole song just needs to be a conversation between me and this person. Why we doing this? What’s it going to be?']])]
genius_comments:
['3 things I love her for:
1. Her Music
2. Her singing
3. genius_description:
On “Lion King on Ice,” J. Cole reverts to his alter ego, Young Simba, but now in a much colder and darker tone. He raps about his come-up and his experience growing up in Fayetteville, where he wasn’t always certain that he would see the next day. He furthers this by reflecting on the challenges he has endured in his career and realizing that his fame and wealth haven’t erased the trauma of his past.

Parts of the song are rapped from the perspective of a young Cole, as he raps about needing to prove himself and rise to the top of the rap game, both of which the current Cole has already accomplished.

Two days before releasing this song, Cole published an essay titled “The Audacity” in which he discussed how the feeling of needing to prove himself is what drove him when he first began rapping:

When I started rapping, it was the competition that drove me. I had a burning desire to be the best in the world and to prove it with every verse.

This and “The Climb Back” were initially the first two singles from Cole’s album, The Fall Off, and were released together as Lewis Street. However, the latter was relocated to The Off-Season in May 2021.
genius_annotations:
[('Goin’ live, but we not on the ’Gram', [['“Goin’ live” here seems to refer to a concert or new endeavor. However, Cole explicitly states that he is not referring to going live on Instagram.

Interestingly, Cole has been on Instagram Live only one time. It occurred on January 24, 2019, the day after he released “MIDDLE CHILD.” He joined the Live of his Dreamville signee, Ari Lennox, and the two conversed for about five minutes before Cole logged off. He actually had difficulty leaving the session, noting that he had never done it before.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P8JoEI8IPsY']]), ('Pockets holdin’ hope', [["“Pockets holdin' hope” literally is saying that the only thing that Cole had to his name at that time was hope, only a dream of what one day he could/wanted to be. Interesting is that he says that it’s his pockets that are “holding” hope, which means that his life at that point was so low that even his very pockets had to grab on and barely was holding on to the little hope he had at the time.

A similiar line was also said by JAY-Z back in 2001 on his song Renegade,
“Feelin' braver, durag wrappin' my waves up, pockets full of hope”

in the same way Cole reflects on his tough past and upbringing, that one day would fill his pockets with much more than just hope."]]), ('Where my young niggas choppin’ up grams
 And them choppers won’t pry from they hands
 Packin’ lead like they got a exam', [['Throughout this song, Cole raps about his teenage years. Here, he talks about some of his friends that became involved in the gangster lifestyle, where they were “choppin’ up grams” (managing drugs) and wielding “choppers” (guns).

Cole creates a double entendre when discussing his friends “packin’ lead.” It literally refers to the lead ammunition for their guns, but Cole ties this to the mention of an “exam” because the graphite within pencils is often (and wrongly) referred to as “lead.” Of course, pencils are the required utensil for most examinations.']]), ('Deep down inside, though, I still feel as broke
 As that nigga who just graduated from college', [['J. Cole graduated from St. John’s University in Queens, New York in 2007, earning magna cum laude honors and accruing a 3.82 GPA over his tenure. He detailed his college lifestyle in his May 2007 track, “College Boy,” which was released right as he was graduating from school.

Cole spoke about his financial situation post-graduation in an interview with Interview Magazine in February of 2013:

Ah, man. Well, actually, I graduated magna cum laude. And after college, man, that was… Well, I was broke as hell. I was renting an apartment in Queens with my roommates during school, and after we graduated, they moved out and started their careers. I didn’t really have a career at that point[…] Well, I was hitting my mom up for money. I kept hitting other people up for money, too. I just felt like a bum. I owed thousands of dollars in rent and I was just waiting on my deal. My landlord was always letting me slide, but eventually I had to give him something, even just to show that I had income. So my homie hooked me up with this job at a newspaper.

Cole hasn’t forgotten that part of his life, however. He remains close with his aforementioned landlord, Mohammad, and even paid him back his missed rent and some once he got his deal.']]), ('Sound like a whole Lambo’ truck in my stomach
 Bitch, I ain’t hungry, this feeling is starving', [['Cole reflects on his past when he was broke and couldn’t afford to eat. He was hungry to the point his stomach rumbled so loud that it sounded like a Lambo truck. The car in question is the Lamborghini Urus, Lamborghini being a luxury sports car manufacturer known for it’s fast and deafening loud cars.

“LamboTruck” was also a song on J. Cole’s label, Dreamville’s, 2019 album Revenge of the Dreamers III. In the song, Dreamville Records signee Cozz goes on to say that Cole actually drives a Lamborghini Urus:

Cole just pulled up in a Lamborghini truck

J. Cole continues this verse by speaking on how he needs to stay dedicated to finally make it. Therefore, the double-meaning of these bars is that Cole was not only hungry for success, but starving for it, and kept working until he finally got the Lambo truck that may have been foreshadowed in his past. Coincidentally, a theme throughout “LamboTruck” is being hungry as a young artist, which can be seen in Cozz’s lyrics:

I just ate, but still I’m hungry

and

Nigga, this hunger got me finna choke




The Laborghini Urus in the “LamboTruck” music video']]), ('Niggas wanted me to look the part, had to stop takin’ advice
 Put the jewelry to the side, had to find me, had to find God', [['At the current stage of his career, Cole is known for his modesty and reserved persona. Some even say that Cole dresses like he’s homeless, something that Dreamville signee JID played off of in a skit on his November 2018 song, “Workin Out”:

Why that nigga J. Cole got all this money [but] look like he ‘bout to borrow somebody charger or something?

However, when Cole was still a rising artist, he often chose to dress like “the traditional rapper,” wearing expensive jewelry and clothing.



The most notable instance of this was Cole’s outfit at the 2013 BET Awards, pictured above. After two other artists wore the exact same thing, it became a public spectacle of “Who Wore It Best?”

Cole recalled this in his March 2019 GQ interview. He said that he wanted to wear something else, but the people around him were trying to convince him that the Versace sweater and chain were the things that would make him be perceived as a superstar, which is what he was longing for at the time.

Ultimately, this didn’t work out the way that Cole or those people had thought, which is part of why he came to the realization that he was doing things to impress others rather than being himself. From that point, he made a notable shift in his public persona that still persists. He doesn’t want to be defined by materialistic things or be perceived as vain. He also notes that he had to find God, which indicates that the glorification of wealth within the music industry may have initially deterred his relationship with Him.

Interestingly, less than two weeks before the award show, Cole had discussed his negative perception of materialism on his record, “Chaining Day.” It has also been discussed in several interviews and songs since the June 2013 event.']]), ('Half the time, we be pacifyin’, what they expect from us?
 But that’s treacherous, that shows less of us
 I need y’all to see every part of me
 Every scar and every artery
 Every story that I can recall, then I can fall', [['Cole talks about what he needs to complete before he can officially retire, or “fall.” He is telling his fans that instead of only giving listeners what they are expecting from him, he’s going to be completely transparent and tell as many stories as he can recall.

Since Cole unveiled the album’s title in April of 2018, fans theorized that The Fall Off was titled this way because it would be Cole’s final album and the start of his retirement. However, he had teased possibly retiring nearly two years prior on DJ Khaled’s July 2016 record, “Jermaine’s Interlude,” rapping:

Said all that I could say, now I play with thoughts of retirement

Cole is now contradicting his previous stance as he realizes that there is more that he can divulge to his listeners.

Two days before releasing this song, Cole published an essay titled “The Audacity” in which he discussed several critical periods of his life. He also wrote on the times that he contemplated retirement before ultimately deciding against it. In the essay’s final paragraph, he wrote:

On my career bucket list, there remain a few more items to check off before I give myself permission to enter whatever the next chapter of my life may be.

It is still unknown whether or not The Fall Off will be Cole’s final album, but he seems to be preparing for the final stages of his career.

“Scar” could be connecting this line to the 1994 film, The Lion King, which inspired Cole’s alter ego and is where this song’s title is derived from. The movie’s main antagonist is a lion named Scar, so Cole could be saying that he wants to show his fans his darker side.']]), ('Niggas dissed me, it was nonsense
 I sat ’em down like his father
 My nigga asked, ”Why you bother?
 We should’ve caught him and mobbed him”
 I said, “We gotta move smarter”
 Don’t wan’ be the reason for one more sad song
 I tried to warn niggas they wouldn’t last long
 I hope that you see how they came and they went
 They shots never hit, but they made they attempts', [["J. Cole calls back to his songs that have ridiculed the new wave of rappers, like his December 2016 track, “everybody dies,” and his April 2018 song, “1985.”

“1985” is the most notable; it was made in response to a trend of fans jokingly chanting, “Fuck J. Cole,” that was started by two Miami rappers, Lil Pump and Smokepurpp. The trend became quite popular and was even the title of a now-scrapped song by Pump. Cole eventually caught wind of what he perceived as disrespect, leading him to discuss his opinion on Pump and other artists like him. On one part of the song, Cole raps:

I’m just tellin' you what’s probably gon' happen when you rappin'
‘Bout the type of shit you rappin’ ‘bout
It’s a faster route to the bottom
I wish you good luck
I’m hoping for your sake that you ain’t dumb as you look
But if it’s really true what people sayin’
And you call yourself playin' with my name
Then I really know you fucked, trust
I’ll be around forever ‘cause my skills is tip-top
To any amateur niggas that wanna get rocked
Just remember what I told you when your shit flop
In five years, you gon’ be on Love & Hip-Hop, nigga

Following the song’s release, Cole and Lil Pump had an endearing conversation at Cole’s home in which they discussed the “Fuck J. Cole” situation and more. However, this didn’t stop Pump from falling off as Cole had predicted. Pump’s second album, released in February 2019, was critically panned and sold only 48,000 units in its first week. Pump will likely never regain the amount of attention or success that he had when he rose to stardom in 2017.

One of the other rappers that Cole was speaking to on “1985” is Pump’s friend, Smokepurpp. He has also evidently fallen off; his last release before this song, June 2020’s Florida Jit, sold slightly over 4,700 units in its first week.

Cole is also saying that he had the fatherly sit-down with Pump because he didn’t want to feel guilty if Pump had died a young death due to the topics of his raps."]]), ('I got mud on my shoes, I ain’t gon’ lie', [['While this chorus and song seem to be rapped from the perspective of a young Cole, this bar calls back to a line from January 2019’s “MIDDLE CHILD,” where Cole raps:

The Bentley is dirty, my sneakers is dirty
But that’s how I like it, you all on my dick

Figuratively, the mud on his shoes alludes to having “come from the dirt,” a slang term akin to the ghetto or slums. This ties into the young persona that Cole takes on throughout the song.']]), ('May have a good year like that name on the blimp
 But you know what it takes to be poppin’ this long?
 Dedication on another level niggas never seen in they life
 Celebratin’ all your first downs like they touchdowns bring a price', [['Continuing the above lines about the artists that try to diss him, Cole then alludes to the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, particularly the company’s famous blimp.



Rappers like Lil Pump and Smokepurpp, who have dissed Cole, may have one “good year” of success (2017 for them), but their careers will ultimately fail to attain the same longevity that Cole’s career has. He offers the answer as to why: they don’t possess the same dedication and modesty.

Many rappers, with varying career lengths, go broke because of wealth mismanagement, which can often include a lack of saving and a penchant for making unnecessary or reckless purchases. Cole suggests that celebrating after every minor accomplishment can be costly in the long run.']])]

THE REAL IS BACK, THE VILLE IS BACK!', '‘Ville on tha map 🔥', 'YOUNG SIMBA.', 'bro the production is so so fire man, and cole is flowing like crazyyyyy this album  gonna pack heat if he takes his time', 'I knew he was finna drop the finale of the simba trilogy🤩🤑🥶', 'yessir. new flow, new level 🔥🔥🔥', "got real, real big plans, I ain’t gon' lie\nI got a whole lot to prove, I ain’t gon' lie 🥵🥵🥵🔥 Cole Tha G.O.A.T 🐐", 'The production on this one 🔥🔥🔥', 'Young Simba, couldn’t wait to be the king.', 'Ahhhh Simba back!!!', 'FIRE SHITTT', 'C R O W N this M A N', 'The album cover is hard asfff. genius_description:
J. Cole’s first offering of 2019 serves as a warning in advance of an extensive rollout of Dreamville material. On the track, Cole envisions himself in the center of the old and new generations of hip-hop, therefore making him the “middle child” of rap.

“Middle Child Syndrome” is a psychological condition in which middle children sometimes feel neglected by their families due to the attention that their younger and older siblings receive.
genius_annotations:
[('They poisoned the well', [['“Poisoning the well” is a logical fallacy in debate culture, where someone inserts a personal attack against the opponent into their argument.

Similarly, black kids face prejudice before being given a chance to reach adulthood. Distorted media coverage, discriminatory government policies, and high incarceration rates are just a few factors that stack the odds against them and create barriers to success.']]), ('Distorted self-image,', [['Whether it’s the music business or the government, the system always wants to put people (especially Black people and people of color) within their established stereotypes and styles, thus hiding the real image of who we are.']]), ('This year gon’ be different, I set my intentions
 I promise to slap all that hate out your voice', [['As of this song’s release, Cole is preparing to release The Off-Season, his fourth mixtape, Revenge of the Dreamers III, the third compilation by Dreamville Records, a currently untitled album under his “kiLL edward” alter ego, and The Fall Off, his sixth studio album.

The four projects mentioned above prove that 2019 is a different year for Cole, as he has never released more than one full-length project in a year.

After this song released, Cole tweeted:
https://twitter.com/JColeNC/status/1088584217951420416']]), ('You good, T-Minus?', [['Ontario, Canadian producer T-Minus co-produced this track with Cole. The two worked together on Cole’s April 2018 song, “Kevin’s Heart,” and 6LACK’s September 2018 song, “Pretty Little Fears,” which features Cole.

In his Complex interview, T-Minus stated that this song was recorded in a session that predated the Revenge of the Dreamers III recording sessions, which occurred less than three weeks before this song was released.

The following image was taken during the recording session for this song.']]), ('To the OGs, I’m thankin’ you now
 Was watchin’ you when you was pavin’ the ground
 I copied your cadence, I mirrored your style
 I studied the greats, I’m the greatest right now', [['On August 2018’s “Album of the Year (Freestyle),” Cole hinted at mirroring legendary rappers like The Notorious B.I.G.:

My cadence be the greatest we’ve seen since the late MC whose name was The Notorious—']]), ('Too many niggas in cycle of jail
 Spending they birthdays inside of a cell', [['The estimated number of young adults ages 18-29 in prison increased from 745,200 in 1999, to 813,600 in 2002. It rose to 865,400 in 2006, then began to decline in 2009.



Cole often discusses recidivism in his music, like on his December 2016 song, “Change”:

Know I got a angel cause I’m supposed to have a halo
Right now, my lifestyle destined for a federal facility
For my ability to make them birds fly']]), ('I got a few mil’ but not all of them rich
 What good is the bread if my niggas is broke?
 What good is first class if my niggas can’t sit?
 That’s my next mission, that’s why I can’t quit', [["Cole mentioned riding first class before on his September 2011 track, “Sideline Story”:

Up in 1st class, laugh even though it’s not funny
See a white man wonder how the fuck I got money
While he sit at coach, hate to see me walk past ‘im
Young black pants sag, headphones blastin’
Know what he askin', “how did he manage?”

His steps towards helping his friends get rich include hiring his college best friend Ibrahim, as manager and current president of Dreamville. Ibrahim’s little brother, Bas, is also a major artist signed to Dreamville."]]), ('The Bentley is dirty, my sneakers is dirty
 But that’s how I like it, you all on my dick', [['On his April 2018 track, “KOD,” Cole raps:

Bentley from his mama’s whip
K-O-D, he hard as shit

Later on the song, he raps:

How ‘bout you just get the fuck off my dick?
How ‘bout you listen and never forget?

To go from his mother’s car to a luxury vehicle illustrates how Cole’s talents earned him success and wealth. However, he does not obsess over material things.

Ibrahim Hamad, Dreamville’s president, tweeted about Cole’s Bentley on the day of the song’s release:

That boy Bentley stay dirty too. No lies on that, I’ll take a picture next time if ya need receipts

This line also comes to life in the music video, as Cole’s Bentley is literally driven through mud.



Cole is a sneakerhead and frequently wears the Air Jordan 1 “Chicago.”']]), ('We coming from a long bloodline of trauma
 We raised by our mamas, Lord, we gotta heal
 We hurting our sisters, the babies as well
 We killing our brothers,', [['Cole is saying we have not yet healed as a people, and as a result we are inflicting pain within our own communities.  Due to multiple circumstances, we see Black on Black violence. Racism has caused an endless cycle of generational trauma that we have not yet begun to heal from.

The Census Bureau reports that over one-third of all Black children in America live with single mothers. Cole himself was raised by a single mother, something he’s touched on numerous times in songs like 2011’s “Breakdown”:

My mother played father cause no other man bothered
Not even my biological, it never seemed logical

On April 2018’s “FRIENDS,” Cole touches on how these traumatic environments can cause long term problems for Black people:

There’s all sorts of trauma from drama that children see
Type of shit that normally would call for therapy
But you know just how it go in our community
Keep that shit inside, it don’t matter how hard it be
Fast forward, them kids is grown and they blowing trees

In turn women of color are more likely than others to suffer both domestic and sexual violence within their communities.']]), ('I just poured somethin’ in my cup
 I’ve been wantin’ somethin’ I can feel
 Promise I am never lettin’ up
 Money in your palm don’t make you real
 Foot is on they neck, I got ’em stuck
 I’ma give ‘em somethin’ they can feel
 If it ain’t ’bout the squad, don’t give a fuck
 Pistol in your hand don’t make you real', [["Cole revisits a prominent theme from his 2018 album KOD. Throughout the project, he attempts to replicate the inner conscious of an addict. For instance, on “The Cut Off” he says:

Gimme drink, gimme dope
Bottom line, I can’t cope

On “Motiv8,” he repeats:

I’m crackin' a smile, I’m dyin' inside
My demons are close, I’m tryin' to hide
I’m poppin' a pill, I’m feelin' alive
I’m feelin' alive, I’m feelin' alive

Cole feels that many of the youth turn to temporary, materialistic things in an effort to feel a sense of fulfillment, which connects to the outro of the song.

Continuing with the message of the track, Cole begins his usual style of a simple storytelling, but then he switches to autotune on the chorus—which is something Cole has rarely or never used in the past. This can be interpreted as implementing a “youthful” vibe to mass with the “middle child” dilemma."]])]

lyrics:
Niggas be thinkin' I'm deep, intelligent, fooled by my college degree
My IQ is average, there's a young lady out there, she way smarter than me
I scrolled through her timeline in these wild times, and I started to read
She mad at these crackers, she mad at these capitalists, mad at these murder police
She mad at my niggas, she mad at our ignorance, she wear her heart on her sleeve
She mad at the celebrities, lowkey I be thinkin' she talkin' 'bout me
Now I ain't no dummy to think I'm above criticism
So when I see something that's valid, I listen
But shit, it's something about the queen tone that's botherin' me
She strike me as somebody blessed enough to grow up in conscious environment
With parents that know 'bout the struggle for liberation and in turn they provide her with
A perspective and awareness of the system and unfairness that afflicts 'em
And the clearest understandin' of what we gotta do to get free
And the frustration that fills her words seems to come from the fact that most people don't see
Just 'cause you woke and I'm not, that shit ain't no reason to talk like you better than me
How you gon' lead, when you attackin' the very same niggas that really do need the shit that you sayin'?
Instead of conveyin' you holier, come help us get up to speed
Shit, it's a reason it took like two hundred years for our ancestors just to get freed
These shackles be lockin' the mental way more than the physical
I look at freedom like trees, can't grow a forest like overnight
Hit the ghetto and slowly start plantin' your seeds
Fuck is the point of you preaching your message to those that already believe what you believe?
I'm on some "Fuck a retweet," most people is sheep
You got all the answers but how you gon' reach?
If I could make one more suggestion respectfully
I would say it's more effective to treat people like children
Understandin' the time and love and patience that's needed to grow
This change is inevitable, but ain't none of us seen this before
Therefore, we just gotta learn everything as we go
I struggle with thoughts on the daily
Feel like a slave that somehow done saved enough coins to buy his way up outta slavery
Thinkin' just maybe, in my pursuit to make life so much better for me and my babies
I done betrayed the very same people that look at me like I'm some kind of a hero
Because of the zeros that's next to the commas
But look here, I promise I'm not who you think
Ran into this nigga outside of the store yesterday
He said something that had me like, "Wait"
He was like, "Cole, 'preciate what you been doin', my nigga, that's real"
But damn, why I feel faker than Snow on tha Bluff?
Well, maybe 'cause deep down I know I ain't doin' enough
The sun is shinin' today
The sun is shinin' today
The sun is shinin' today

Can you walk with me?
I hope we'll find the reason why we often sob, go on, cry
Painful memories fuck up the vibe
Though I be tryin' to let the time heal my mind
I was once a child, I've gotten older
Still, I know I'm just a boy in God's eyes
Fill me up with wisdom and some courage
Plus endurance to survive, help mine thrive105EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy
genius_description:
“Snow on tha Bluff” is J. Cole’s first release of 2020. On the song, which is titled after a January 2011 film about a robbery in Atlanta, Cole delivers a single continuous verse that speaks on various issues facing the United States, including police brutality, wealth inequality, and racism. He also asks for his fans not to idolize him, wanting to instead be perceived as a regular person.

Although not explicitly stated, the first part of the track is likely a response to Noname’s perceived criticisms of Cole on Twitter. She has frequently stated that she is against capitalism and celebrity culture, two things that Cole raps about in his verse.

The artwork displays the beginning of the verse. The date at the top, June 4, 2020, likely indicates the day the song was written. This date is several days after Cole was seen protesting racial injustice in his hometown, Fayetteville, NC.
genius_annotations:
[('Can you walk with me?
 I hope we’ll find the reason why we often sob, go on, cry
 Painful memories fuck up the vibe
 Though I be tryin’ to let the time heal my mind
 I was once a child, I’ve gotten older
 Still, I know I’m just a boy in God’s eyes
 Fill me up with wisdom and some courage
 Plus endurance to survive, help mine thrive', [['In this outro Cole laments on feelings of despair and the disheartening nature of witnessing repeated tragedies–then offering that hopefully we can find the strength to continue in pursuit of change.  The first four lines asking someone to walk with him could be addressed to several different entities:

A) The female referenced in the first part of the song
B) The human population in general
C) God

A or B) Taken more literally, Cole may be asking the woman referenced in the song, or the human race as a whole to walk with him in pursuit of healing.  That through conversation they may be able to both process some of the deep sadness, and share knowledge so that everyone can become more educated.

C) While the last four lines more exclusively comment on a higher perspective, the entire outro may be a conversation Cole is having with God.  Under this interpretation, Cole begins by asking if God can walk with him and try to explain some reason why these tragedies continue to occur.  Second, Cole comments on the relationship of time and healing: that times supposedly heals all wounds, but while he is now an adult, from God’s perspective he is still very young.  This may imply that he has a lot of healing left to be realized or more literally that from the perspective of an infinite being, Cole is young.  Lastly, Cole asks God to fill him with the wisdom, courage, and endurance to continue on fighting the good fight.']]), ('[Outro]', [['Cole’s singing voice has evolved with each stage of his career. Cole’s singing was notably heard on his December 2014 track, “Apparently.” He would be heard continuing to expand his vocal range on his December 2016 album, 4 Your Eyez Only, on songs like “Ville Mentality” and both parts of “She’s Mine.” Cole again sang on his April 2018 album, KOD, on songs like “Photograph” and “Kevin’s Heart.” On that album, he also began manipulating his voice using the alter-ego kill Edward.

With “Snow on tha Bluff,” Cole continues to expand his vocal range, singing in an unexpected falsetto as he harmonizes with his usual tone.']]), ('Now I ain’t no dummy to think I’m above criticism
 So when I see something that’s valid, I listen
 But shit, it’s something about the queen tone that’s botherin’ me
 She strike me as somebody blessed enough to grow up in conscious environment
 With parents that know ’bout the struggle for liberation and in turn they provide her with
 A perspective and awareness of the system and unfairness that afflicts ’em
 And the clearest understandin’ of what we gotta do to get free', [["Continuing in his discussion of Chicago multi-genre artist Noname, Cole explains that she may have had a “head start” in her social awareness from an upbringing that incorporated education on Black liberation in America into the way she was raised.

However, Noname has discussed her familial upbringing in multiple interviews during her career, and revealed that she grew up with her grandparents on the South Side of Chicago until she was 13 and after moved in with her mother. She delved deeply into her upbringing in a February 2017 interview with the Chicago Tribune:

[My grandmother was] the woman who raised me until I was about 13, 14. My mother owned a bookstore, which she started when she was 24 (in 1991), the same age when she had me, and she ultimately didn’t have time to juggle both the store and raising me — she didn’t know how. She was young and a new entrepreneur, and for her it made sense for me to stay with my grandmother. I saw my mom on weekends. My grandparents had full custody, and my mom was like a visiting relative. Once things slowed down with my mother’s business, I moved back in with her. It was a little strange at first, there was a little resentment, because I took to my grandmother a little more. So when I moved in with my mother, it was a little awkward, but we’re good now.

One interesting part of her youth that Noname frequently addresses is her participation in the Chicago youth media group YOUmedia, where she met and befriended fellow Chicago rappers such as Chance the Rapper, Saba, Cam O'bi, and others. On her participation in the group, Noname said:

[YOUmedia] was my safe place to create and feel understood in a lot of ways, to feel like I could create openly, with vulnerability and not to be judged or criticized… [The transition from poetry to rap] wasn’t hard — the environment was so filled with a variety of art forms. There would be someone singing, rapping, reading a poem, doing a short monologue or dancing — it was like a variety show. Being around a bunch of different people who were rapping, I felt like I could do both. We’d have these cyphers after each open mic.

The stories and perspectives that each of her fellow participants may have rubbed off on her during the youth program may have helped give her confidence in both her musical and social voice, allowing her to be as much of an advocate for change that she is now."]]), ('I struggle with thoughts on the daily
 Feel like a slave that somehow done saved enough coins to buy his way up outta slavery
 Thinkin’ just maybe, in my pursuit to make life so much better for me and my babies
 I done betrayed the very same people that look at me like I’m some kind of a hero
 Because of the zeros that’s next to the commas', [["Cole yet again speaks on his disillusion with fame and money, a topic that he has broached numerous times throughout his career and discography. Here, he correlates himself to a slave and even says that he feels as though he has betrayed his black brothers and sisters who are not as fortunate.

On his December 2014 track, “Love Yourz,” Cole discusses how, after receiving wealth and fame, he realized that they were not all that it was made out to be. The entirety of the song discusses this, but here is a portion of the second verse:

Think being broke was better
Now I don’t mean that phrase with no disrespect
To all my niggas out there livin' in debt
Cashin' minimal checks, turn on the TV see a nigga Rolex
And fantasize about a life with no stress
I mean this shit sincerely
And as a nigga who was once in your shoes
Livin' with nothin' to lose, I hope one day you hear me
Always gon' be a bigger house somewhere, but nigga feel me
Long as the people in that motherfucker love you dearly

This topic from Cole is most popularly known from his March 2015 interview with Tavis Smiley:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5tr_9DozAok"]]), ('Shit, it’s a reason it took like two hundred years for our ancestors just to get freed
 These shackles be lockin’ the mental way more than the physical
 I look at freedom like trees, can’t grow a forest like overnight
 Hit the ghetto and slowly start plantin’ your seeds', [['While the exact timeline of slavery in the Americas is unknown, African slaves are estimated to have been first brought to America by Spanish and Portuguese settlers somewhere from 1501 – 1505. Slavery in America was officially abolished on December 18, 1865 by the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, giving the total duration of slavery in the United States a range of 360 to 364 years.

Cole compares the physical shackles African slaves experience while coming to America to the restrictions that systemic racism in America have on the mindset of Black people in the country. Having been oppressed for the many years and having heard many stories of oppression from past generations, Cole says Black people in America are unable to believe that there is an escape from the subjugation that they experience in society, stressing the importance to free themselves from this restriction before further change can be made.

Cole then gives his own input on how education on racial discrimination and inequality should be undertaken in America, saying that it should be a gradual process and cannot be an undertaking completed overnight. He also says education on the topics in communities should start within the communities themselves, allowing people to gradually rid it from their own community and eventually removing it from the country altogether.

This is a stark contrast from Noname’s strategy on education, as she speaks loudly on the issues on her various social media accounts.']]), ('But damn, why I feel faker than Snow on tha Bluff?
 Well, maybe ‘cause deep down I know I ain’t doin’ enough', [["Snow on tha Bluff is a January 2011 movie about Curtis Snow, an Atlanta robber and crack dealer who, in the film, stole a camera from college kids during a drug deal and made an autobiographical documentary.

The film was so convincing that the Atlanta PD tried to link its footage to a string of home invasion robberies from around the time of the film’s release, but the film was ultimately unconnected from the other events. However, Snow was later arrested in May 2016 on charges for aggravated assault.

Cole plays off the film’s realistic filming style, which seemed like documentary footage to many on the surface but ended up being fictional after deeper investigation. He feels that he may be all talk when it comes to the Black Lives Matter movement, as if he has come up short in his support for the movement.

Notably, Cole comes full circle in the last line of the verse. In the first line of the song, he says that he is perceived as “deep” by the public:

Niggas be thinkin' I’m deep, intelligent, fooled by my college degree

While at first he acknowledges that he is deep on the surface, Cole ends the verse by questioning his inner motives, wondering if he really is interpreting the movement to the fullest extent that he can rather than just acting like he is doing so."]]), ('Niggas be thinkin’ I’m deep, intelligent, fooled by my college degree', [['J. Cole graduated from St. John’s University in Queens, New York in 2007, earning magna cum laude honors and accruing a 3.82 GPA over his tenure. He detailed his college lifestyle in his May 2007 track, “College Boy,” which was released right as he was graduating from school.

Cole is implying that, although he may have earned a college degree, that doesn’t indicate that he can’t continue to be educated by others who are more aware of things that he is not. This ties into the ensuing lyrics in which he broaches a discussion with Noname. He is also saying that his fans falsely place him on a higher pedestal simply because of his education, but he’s warning them not to.

Interestingly enough, Cole majored in communications with a minor in business, two paths of study that may have helped with both the lyrical side of his career, as he communicates through music, and the managerial side, as he is the owner and co-founder of Dreamville Records.']]), ('And the frustration that fills her words seems to come from the fact that most people don’t see
 Just ’cause you woke and I’m not, that shit ain’t no reason to talk like you better than me
 How you gon’ lead, when you attackin’ the very same niggas that really do need the shit that you sayin’?
 Instead of conveyin’ you holier, come help us get up to speed', [['Continuing the allusions to Noname, Cole comments on how she should seek to educate as an aspect of her leadership rather than simply putting down the people who do not yet understand the implications of race relations in the country. He calls her out for attacking him and other “conscious” rappers for not tweeting about the racial climate of America.

Moreso, Cole is emphasizing that to truly educate the people, it will require more effort than simply posting on social media or “retweeting.” He knows that actually having in-person discussions can have more permanent effects on uneducated people.

On May 29, Noname tweeted:


Poor black folks all over the country are putting their bodies on the line in protest for our collective safety, and y’all favorite top-selling rappers not even willing to put a tweet up. Niggas’ whole discographies be about black plight, and they nowhere to be found.

(Edited for clarity.)


Given the contents of their discographies, many fans perceived Noname’s tweets as allusions to J. Cole and Kendrick Lamar being silent about the current events.

On May 30, Cole was pictured humbly protesting in the streets of his hometown, Fayetteville, NC, a subtle rebuttal to Noname’s shaming.



Despite Cole’s words, Noname has taken an active role in educating people outside of social media. In July 2019, she started Noname’s Book Club, which strives to educate and empower people of color. The club is also active in bringing these books to correctional facilities. Its website reads:

Noname’s Book Club is an online/IRL community dedicated to uplifting POC voices. We do this by highlighting two books each month written by authors of color. In addition to our social media presence, we feel it is highly important to have free in-person meetups to discuss the monthly picks in a safe and supportive environment. Currently, we have six local chapters with plans for continuous growth.

Ultimately, Cole recognizes that he was partially wrong in his commentary on her work, as he wrote this on Twitter the morning after releasing the song:
https://twitter.com/JColeNC/status/1273229943246409728']]), ('My IQ is average, there’s a young lady out there, she way smarter than me
 I scrolled through her timeline in these wild times, and I started to read
 She mad at these crackers, she mad at these capitalists, mad at these murder police
 She mad at my niggas, she mad at our ignorance, she wear her heart on her sleeve
 She mad at the celebrities, lowkey I be thinkin’ she talkin’ ’bout me', [['J. Cole may be subtly speaking about Noname, a multi-genre artist from Chicago, Illinois who has been extremely vocal alongside the rise in the Black Lives Matter movement during the protests for the death of George Floyd.

During the protests, she has called out the system of capitalism, the American policing system, and the history of America that white people took over, but has also called out many celebrities, both black and white, for not taking part in the movement and using their platform and resources to progress the cause.

With Noname’s especially harsh critique of wealthy black men playing into white supremacy by not directly calling out the different forms of white supremacy, Cole thought she may have been talking about himself, especially after she made multiple tweets about conscious rappers not speaking up on the issue on May 29, 2020:


Poor black folks all over the country are putting their bodies on the line in protest for our collective safety and y’all favorite top selling rappers not even willing to put a tweet up.

niggas whole discographies be about black plight and they no where to be found


However, Cole has been very involved with the movement, as he marched in his hometown of Fayetteville, North Carolina days after Floyd’s death on top of dropping this song to support the movement.

The morning after the song’s release, Cole made a string of tweets seemingly confirming that Noname was the target of these critiques, an excerpt of which directly implicates her vocalness in the song’s content:

Follow @noname. I love and honor her as a leader in these times. She has done and is doing the reading and the listening and the learning on the path that she truly believes is the correct one for our people. Meanwhile a nigga like me just be rapping.']])]

genius_description: “Need Me” is New York rapper, J.I’s breakthrough single. Backed by a bouncy upbeat instrumental, J.I. has his eyes set on a girl–who hasn’t been dating for a while because her exes “did [her] wrong”. Knowing he’s “too official” to “stress a bitch”, he tells her that she can call his phone when she needs him.
genius_annotations:
[('I said you could call my phone', [['J.I is always available to give advice to his girl']]), ('Yeah, I swear this gon’ fuck the summer up
 Niggas hatin’ on me ‘cause I’m comin’ up', [['I’m going to be honest, I love New York, I’m from Brooklyn. I just feel like a lot of people dislike me, and I really don’t know why. I got mad support, cause I really started blowing up in 2016, I was on TV. A TV show called The Rap Game and I’m not going to front, a lot of people was on the wave. Like I went to Atlanta to film the show. In my head I’m just thinking, “Yo, this is going to be a great move for my career”, you feel me. I could get the exposure I need. And I came home and everybody was on the wave, like “Yo Prince of New York, blah blah blah, it’s the Prince of New York, blah blah.” I’m just like, holy shit. That wasn’t even my name. Prince of New York was not my name, that was my Instagram name, but I guess they thought that was my name and everybody filming ran with it, and the support was crazy, but the hatred is just ridiculous. I’m 14 and I’m reading comments like, “Yo I hate this kid, I want to beat this nigga up. When I see him, Imma hurt him,” like the fuck I did to you, I’m 14. And it’s just crazy because I mean I got used to it, and it’s sad because I’m a child. No child should really go through that. I just want to lead by example and show everybody like, yo you can do what you put your mind to. Shit ain’t impossible.']]), ('I gotta be cautious, these niggas like to talk shit
 I remember when I pulled up on your shorty and she lost it', [['Yo, I’ve talked to a lot of girls that had dudes. It should be making me feel crazy about my girl. If I could do it, imagine what could be done to me. But it’s no hard feelings. It happens to the best of us. It be like that. It just goes to show you that a lot of people ain’t shit. I’ll be talking to everybody. Regardless, if somebody’s loyal they’re even going to respond to you and tell you they got somebody, you feeling me? They’re just going to dump you, I done chopped it up with mad people. I’m not the type to break up a relationship, that’s not me. I don’t even pay attention to that type of shit. But if it happens, it happens. If I can swindle and finesse, I’m going to swindle and finesse.']]), ('I swear to God you better never try to leave me
 I want you to myself, I swear to God I’m greedy
 I gotta move a type of way, no, it ain’t easy', [['The hatred, especially when you got clout. I watch social media. I see what be going on, I be seeing rappers getting locked out and shit like that. Getting pressed, all that type of stuff. I got to move a type of ways. Even if it’s not going to happen, even if it never will happen, I still got to move away. Many people have lost their life, and it’s crazy, especially in the streets. I got a name now, I got to carry myself and I don’t even be involved in all the bullshit. I try to stay away from it, and I could still get caught up somehow. I got to move a type of away because a lot of people envy, a lot of people hate. And it’s like, “Nah, I refuse to let somebody get the chance. I can’t, naw you could never play me dawg, it’s not happening.”']]), ('I know it’s been way too long
 I know niggas did you wrong
 I said you could call my phone
 When you need me, hit me when you need me', [['The whole record was freestyle, off the top of my head. And I guess it was just how I felt. I say shit that applies to me but I know other people could relate to, and I just feel like a lot of people in general needed to hear that. Because I mean, yeah it could be, it could apply to somebody, but I’d rather it apply to everybody because it’s like people get caught up in the wrong situations, like I said. And a lot of girls, a lot of boys, they get hurt. Sometimes people feel like nobody’s in their corner. I’m the type of person, I don’t care how long has it been. If we cool, we cool, you can call my phone, you feel me? Imma pick up.']])]

genius_description:
On “GO,“ The Kid LAROI teams up with his late mentor and labelmate Juice WRLD. On the track, both artists talk about their personal struggles with girls and drugs, whilst also touching on their fast paced lives.

The track leaked on YouTube on April 18, 2020, and was later confirmed in the comment section of LAROI’s Instagram post to be  released alongside a music video. However, the leaked version featured a different first verse from LAROI, and he explained the reason for the change in a livestream on Caffeine, on June 12th, 2020, saying:

I wanted to keep it the way that we made it, ‘cause […] I put the [leaked] verse on after Juice had passed. And it just felt bad to not do it like the original was and put it out like that. So, that’s why you guys didn’t get the “leaked version.“ I know that maybe you guys think the leaked one was better. But this is the original one.
genius_annotations:
[('I don’t know no better (I don’t)', [['This is an interpolation of Major Lazer’s 2017 hit “Know No Better,” featuring Travis Scott, Camila Cabello and Quavo. On the chorus of the track, Camila sings:

Yeah, you know no better
Say you different, who you kidding?
Yeah, you know no better
Ooh, save that talk for the ones
Who don’t know no better (know no better)']]), ('[Chorus: The Kid LAROI]', [['Although Juice WRLD’s verse was recorded during Laroi’s 16th birthday in Greece, Laroi had recorded this chorus long before but he discarded it and was not looking to use it.

It was by accident that Laroi airdropped it to Juice’s engineers whilst Juice was looking for a song to record a feature on as Laroi’s birthday present.

Later, this was further explained by Laroi in an interview with Apple Music:

We went for dinner and Juice was supposed to come but he slept through it. So we went back and [Juice] said, “Sorry I missed your birthday dinner, but fuck it – for your birthday I’ll just give you a verse' – like $200,000 worth. I Airdropped his engineer a few songs. I didn’t even really mean to airdrop [“Go“] because I had recorded it so long ago but he was like, "This is the one, this is the one! Come on, load it up, let’s get it!”']]), ('Perky with the lean, it got me slow, slow, slow', [['“Perky” is a slang term for percocet, which is an opioid pain reliever used to treat moderate to severe pain. However when they are abused, they can result in an euphoric experience for the user. Taking percocet in conjunction with other drugs can “slow” ones breathing.

“Lean” is a liquid mixture of codeine, promethazine cough syrup and soda. Drinking lean also results in an euphoric experience for the user but has side effects, these include tiredness, lack of energy and drowsiness. These effects, along with the percocet, explain why Juice is feeling “slow.”

Drug use is a common theme in Juice WRLD’s music, specifically percocet and lean. For example, he also refers to both drugs in his 2018 single “Lean Wit Me”:

Lean with me, pop with me

On December 8, 2019, Juice WRLD sadly passed away after suffering a seizure from a drug overdose. Juice was found to have had toxic levels of oxycodone and codeine in his system. An overdose of oxycodone (present in percocet) and codeine (present in lean) is known to be fatal.']]), ('[Verse 1: The Kid LAROI]', [['Within a livestream LAROI did on Caffeine on June 12th, he talked about the reason why he decided to change his verse on “GO“ since many fans seemed to prefer the leaked version over the newer one. At the beginning of his livestream, however, he clarifies the reason behind this change, stating:

I wanted to put it out with the new verse or the leaked verse, or whatever. But I wanted to keep it the way that we made it, ‘cause like I said I put the new verse on after Juice had passed. And it just felt bad to not do it like the original was and put it out like that. So, that’s why you guys didn’t get the “leaked version”. I know, that maybe you guys think the leaked one was better. But this is the original one.']]), ('[Verse 2: Juice WRLD]', [['This verse was recorded in a home setup before Juice’s tragic death.

It is revealed in the official music video that Juice recorded his verse as a “200 thousand dollar” birthday present for LAROI.']]), ('And I should slide for you
 And that’s my biggest problem, in denial ’bout you', [['LAROI’s frequent problem in relationships is that he can never let them go, always coming back to a girl no matter what they do or how bad their relationship was. He’s touched on this topic within a few of his songs, such as on his December 2019 hit “Let Her Go,“ where he similarly sings:

And if she do, how she say, then I can’t let her go

He touched on that specific line in a verified annotation, saying:

It’s one thing for a girl to look attractive and be cool, whatever. But if she really does what she say she can do, if she keeps all her promises and then she does all that other shit then it’s like, damn, I can’t let her go because I feel like there’s a whole bunch of girls who will say a lot of shit and not do a lot of shit.

He also sings a similar line within another 2019 track “Too Much (Demo),“ where he reiterates:

But I don’t wanna feel how I felt before
I’m running back to you, I’m running back to you']]), ('Won’t let go, I’m the type to show you that you’re too special', [['This line is reminiscent of Juice’s March 2019 track “Won’t Let Go,“ a track in which he expresses his love for his significant other. In it, he similarly sings about her uniqueness:

I’m at my all-time high now
You’re my sunshine through life’s rainclouds
[…]
I won’t let go
I won’t let go
I won’t let go, go, oh']])]

genius_primary_artist: Quality Control, Layton Greene & Lil Baby
genius_description:
In “Leave Em Alone”, Layton Greene enlists Lil Baby, PnB Rock and female duo City Girls to drop an exclusive romantic banger.

She talks about how she can’t leave this one dude alone and that she caught feelings for him.

This is the first Layton Greene and Lil Baby collaboration and it was also featured on QC’s compilation album “Quality Control: Control the Streets Vol. 2”

As of July 2020, they’ve seen a recent resurgence in popularity thanks to video sharing app  TikTok

genius_description: “Walk Me Home” is a song by American singer-songwriter P!nk, released as the lead single from her 2019 album Hurts 2B Human. The lead single and album was first revealed in an appearance on The Ellen DeGeneres Show on February 6, 2019.
genius_annotations:
[('‘Cause there is so much wrong goin’ on outside', [['unless they’re some vampires or something outdoors, problems don’t tend to go away once you get ‘inside’. however, the character instead seems to be figuratively drawing a barrier between the scary, bad, worrying, etc things that are going wrong in most aspects of their life. when they are with the “you” character, it is easier and they can relax, they have found a home to go to, ie the inside.']]), ('This conversation ain’t coming easily', [['the conversation is not described, so it could potentially just be a dip or silence in a conversation between the two characters. however, the reason it’s not coming easily could be because the character is nervous to express something, such as their feelings as they’re going through a bad time, or possibly a confession; perhaps they are awkwardly telling the other character that they like them as more than a friend, or that they love them. this can be inferred as the character wants to be walked home by them, have them stay tonight, and is relying on them in a difficult time of their life.']]), ('Tryna stand up on my own two feet', [['this could possibly taken in a very literal way: since they’re walking home at night, it’s like this voice is kind of intoxicated. however, in a more figurative sense, this person is trying to be independent and stand up for themself, which is likely a reason they seem to be struggling and are going through a hard period']]), ('There’s somethin’ in the way you roll your eyes
 Takes me back to a better time
 When I saw everything is good
 But now you’re the only thing that’s good', [['This is a simple and mostly literal song, yet it can be read in a number of ways, which makes it so universal and appreciated.
In the first few lines, the singer is nostalgic over the “better time”, a theme which is continually repeated in the song. These ‘times’, it’s not clear what was occurring during them, but it’s clear that the singer is going through a significant struggle in life right now and is looking back on when life was simpler and better. The “you” described in the song has known her both in the good and bad times, and while she is struggling, she continues to be close to “you”. This is intended as universal, neither the “I” nor “you” person is given any gender, for example, and it’s not stated whether they are romantically or platonically involved. Most people can relate to experiencing difficulty in life and relying on a good friend or partner to fall back on.']])]

genius_description:
“Relación” es un tema que originalmente habla de una relación fallida entre un hombre y una mujer. Le despreocupación del hombre por la relación hizo que la mujer se cansara de él y a raíz de esto ella se aventura a vivir su vida y los roles cambian. Ahora es el hombre quien quiere volver, pero ya es muy tarde y la mujer no tiene interés ninguno en recuperar la relación.

La intención de hacerle un remix fue dada a conocer por Sech, quien el 22 de junio de 2020 publicó un video en Instagram cantando “Relación” y preguntando lo siguiente:

Si algún día hiciera este REMIX Y TU FUERAS EL PRODUCTOR CON QUIEN SERÍA ? 👇👇

El colombiano Keityn comentó esta publicación, sugiriendo que uno de los artistas con los que usualmente trabaja hace parte de la remezcla. El 28 de junio el panameño volvió a pedirle a sus fanáticos que le recomienden un artista para el remix, pero esta vez confirmándolo.

El primer confirmado fue J Balvin, siendo el mismo Sech el que compartió un adelanto de su participación en el remix
genius_annotations:
[('Y tú (Uh-uh-uh)
 Diciendo que fue falta de actitud
 Pero en esta relación hice más que tú, yeh (Yeh-eh)
 Y en un estado te mandé a decir que (¡Da-ddy Yan-kee!)', [['Sech se refirió a esta línea en una entrevista con Genius Verified:

Bueno, yo tuve una relación [en] que yo puse más. Y eso es bien complicado y al final me fallaron. Yo creo que a veces no es ni amor, ¿tú sabes? A veces yo creo que es costumbre de dormir con una persona, levantarse con una persona, comer con una persona. Es costumbre, pero si le das la vuelta a la manzana siempre hay otra persona que es mejor.']]), ('Que yo siempre estaba cuando tú no estaba’
 Fue tanto dolor que ya no me mataba
 Poco a poco ya no te necesitaba
 Y yo sonreía mientra’ lo enrolaba', [["Sech se refirió a esta línea en una entrevista con Genius Verified:

Ella lo dio todo, todo, todo, todo en la relación. O él lo dio todo. Y se vuelve costumbre a veces que la relación termina y: “Aló, ¿cómo estás?, ¿todo bien? Voy pa' allá”, “ah dale, pues, está bien”. Caíste."]]), ('Ahora todo cambió, le toca a ella (Prr)
 Mari y una botella (¿Qué, qué?)
 Gracia’ al maltrato se puso bella (What?)
 Ahora tú la quiere’ y no te quiere ella
 Ahora todo cambió, le toca a ella
 Party y una botella
 Gracia’ al maltrato se puso bella (D-D-D-D.Y)
 Ahora tú la quiere’ y no te quiere ella (One; yeah; huh)', [['Sech se refirió a esta línea en una entrevista con Genius Verified:

Ahora es ella que no quiere estar contigo, se acabó. Por eso te digo, el diste tanto que se acabó, se acabó, ella se cansó y ya. Después esa persona comienza a llamar, a buscarte, a bloquearte, deshacer. O se dio cuenta que sí te quería, se dio cuenta que era feliz contigo. Pero ya es tarde, it’s late.']])]

genius_description:
“Adicto”, que fue rumoreada como un sencillo del álbum Los Dioses, marca otra de las tantas colaboraciones entre los reggaetoneros puertorriqueños.

Anuel AA y Ozuna se juntan una vez más para cantarle al amor de dos personas que quieren estar juntos, pero no saben cómo amarse. Haciendo referencia en el coro de esta de que por más que se quiera aceptar que es imposible, siguen buscándose el uno al otro.

genius_description:
The Weeknd links up with pop singer and past collaborator Ariana Grande for the remix of his hit track “Save Your Tears” from his 2020 record-breaking album After Hours.

On April 19, 2021, a snippet of the remix was shared by both Ariana Grande and The Weeknd via their social media accounts, with audio showing both of them harmonizing. Ariana later announced via Instagram that the song would officially be dropping on the same week. Both artists confirmed that the song would be released on April 23, 2021.

And even though you put my life through hell
I can’t seem to forget ‘bout you, 'bout you"]]), ('Met you once under a Pisces moon', [['Pisces is the twelfth astrological sign in the Zodiac, and relates to those born between the dates of February 19th and March 20th.

This could be a possible reference to the music video for Abel and Ariana’s first collab, “Love Me Harder” which was released on November 3rd, 2014 – during a Pisces moon.']])]

genius_description:
“A BOY IS A GUN*” is one of the more Kanye-esque tracks out of IGOR, as seen by Tyler’s delivery of the chorus and the clear use of “Bound” by the Ponderosa Twins, which was also sampled by West in his 2013 album, Yeezus. The song was first teased in a 28-second snippet posted by Tyler on May 13, 2019. It is one of the softer cuts on the album with the chorus featuring prominent use of a soul sample, with glittery synths and keys littered throughout the background.

Tyler seems to be alluding to his possible bisexuality, with the lyrical similes of his lover being like a gun and the title of the track being “A BOY IS A GUN*.” Throughout the song, Tyler compares being with his love interest with gun ownership in several ways.

The title “A BOY IS A GUN*” was inspired by the 1971 French western movie A Girl Is a Gun which Tyler confirmed at the IGOR Apple Music concert.

The song’s music video was released on September 16th, 2019.

Clearly, his friends or family do not approve of his gun ownership/relationship, and he in turns agrees with them and feels defiant towards them.']]), ('[Verse 2]', [['In the second verse, Tyler explores the ways in which he can flip flop even moment to moment when it comes to whether he wants the gun/person or would rather get rid of it/them.']]), ('[Verse 1]', [['The first verse describes how Tyler is both aware that owning a gun/being with this person is dangerous and probably unhealthy, but at the same time he feels the need for security because of his wealth and success.
