genius_description:
“EARFQUAKE” is a collaboration between Tyler, The Creator and Playboi Carti. In the song, Tyler sings about a lover he depends on, who he knows he hasn’t treated the best, but needs. This is done over beautiful, cheery piano chords and heavy, distorted drums, mixing styles from his last two albums, Cherry Bomb and Flower Boy.

In an interview with Rick Rubin on his podcast Broken Record, Tyler explains that his inspiration for the title came from there being an actual earthquake when he was writing the song. Then he decided to change the “th” to an “f.”

During Tyler’s concert hosted by Apple Music with IGOR presentation, Tyler said the song is from 2017, and he wrote it for Justin Bieber, but “he didn’t take it.” It was also offered to Rihanna who also declined.
genius_annotations:
[('[Verse 2: Tyler, The Creator & Charlie Wilson]', [['Tyler’s second verse sounds noticeably similar and is reminiscing/alluding to his 2011 track, She featuring Frank Ocean, where he raps:

I just wanna talk, and conversate
‘Cause I usually just stalk you and masturbate
And I finally got the courage to ask you on a date
So just say yes, let the future fall into place

Both of these verses are found later in the song and have similar flows, rhyme schemes, and topics.']]), ('And you don’t want my conversation (I don’t want no conversation)', [['Frank Ocean had a similar line on “Nights” from his album Blonde:

Shut the fuck up, I don’t want your conversation

“Nights” is about coping with relationship problems. Frank is irritated by his lover’s care and would just like to vibe in silence.

On “EARFQUAKE”, Tyler seems to be on the other side of the relationship – throughout the whole song he’s desperate to keep his lover by his side even though his partner doesn’t show much affection.

Tyler and Frank were both members of the LA-based hip-hop collective Odd Future. Although Frank can’t be heard on IGOR, he helped in creating “I THINK” – the third song on the album.']]), ('Don’t leave, it’s my fault
 Don’t leave, it’s my fault
 Don’t leave, it’s my fault (Girl)', [['Keeping with the track’s ongoing theme of earthquakes, Tyler creates a double entendre with the word “fault”.

A fault is a thin zone of crushed rock separating blocks of the earth’s crust. When an earthquake occurs on one of these faults, the rock on one side of the fault slips with respect to the other.



In the same way, Tyler says it’s his “fault” their relationship has failed, and what led to their inevitable earfquake.']]), ('[Verse 1: Playboi Carti]', [['Tyler has notably declared that “CARTI LYRICS CANNOT BE TRANSCRIBED.”

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1142152753474617344']]), ('I just need some confirmation on how you feel, for real (For real)', [['Early on in the album, Tyler establishes his dependency to his lover. He would elaborate this further on tracks like “PUPPET,” where Tyler sees himself being insecure and feels that his emotions are controlled by his lover—since he looks up to them in such a high degree.

This line establishes Tyler’s anxiety towards his partner’s wavering love, asking for confirmation to ease his mind.']]), ('We ain’t gotta ball, D. Rose, huh', [['Derrick Rose, often nicknamed “D. Rose,” is an NBA point guard. Since being crowned the 2011 league MVP, Rose has suffered several injuries, which have caused him to miss over 250 games. However, in June 2017, Forbes listed his net worth at $34 million. Carti may be saying he’ll be rich even if he doesn’t rap.

https://images.app.goo.gl/wqv6SMTDTanNrrGy9']]), ('I’m with Tyler, yuh (Slime)', [['The term Slime is southern slang that’s used to recognize friends or family. Young Thug popularized the term through his Slime Season mixtape series, and it can be heard amongst many rappers, most notably Carti, Ski Mask, Gunna and Uzi. The word slime itself stands for Street Life Intelligence and Money is Everything.



Carti and Tyler performing in LA

In a November 2018 tweet, Tyler gave a shoutout to Carti:

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1061671072938872837?lang=en']]), ('’Cause you make my earth quake
 Oh, you make my earth quake
 Riding around, your love be shakin’ me up
 And it’s making my heart break
 ’Cause you make my earth quake
 Oh, you make my earth quake (Earthquake, ooh)
 Riding around, your love be shakin’ me up
 And it’s making my heart break', [['Throughout IGOR, Tyler explores the topic of heartbreak, like he did on his March 2013 track, “IFHY,” which a May 2018 Complex article calls one of “The Best Hip-Hop Breakup Songs”:

I fucking hate you
But I love you
I’m bad at keeping my emotions bubbled
You’re good at being perfect
We’re good at being troubled, yeah

In a September 2018 interview with Fantastic Man, Tyler was asked if he had ever been in love, to which he responded:

I don’t want to talk about that

Tyler went on to say that he would cover the topic on his upcoming tracks.']]), ('These diamonds not Tiffany, huh, yeah (Woah, woah)', [['Tiffany & Co. is a luxury jeweler founded in 1837. However, Carti may be bragging about his butterfly chain from IF & Co. Diamonds. In November 2016, IF & Co. even showcased Carti’s pieces on their site.

These lines are also similar to his bars on Travis Scott’s May 2017 track, “Green & Purple”:

VVS diamond on my wrist
My diamond not Tiffany, bitch']]), ('And she wicked, huh, yuh
 Like Woah Vicky, huh, yeah (Like Woah Vicky)', [['Victoria Waldrip, better known by her nickname Woah Vicky, is a social media personality who achieved some notoriety in mid 2017 for her claim of being black. She’s also known for her feud with rapper and social media personality Bhad Bhabie.



Carti could also be using the exclamation term, “whoa,” and connecting it to the actions of Vicky from Nickelodeon’s 2001 animated series, The Fairly OddParents. Vicky is the babysitter of protagonist, Timmy Turner, and often antagonizes him.']])]

genius_description:
“I THINK” questions both Tyler’s mental state and his feelings in a romantic relationship. Tyler doesn’t know whether to continue to be vulnerable, because of his partner’s actions and their effect on Tyler, but his curiosity grows and latches on to the bond he has created with this person. This pushes him to believe in love. This develops the theme of love throughout the album, as introduced in the previous track.

Tyler released “a fraction of” the music video for the track on October 24th, 2019.
genius_annotations:
[('Waste of bread, I need your attention (Skate)', [['“Need” sounds exactly like “knead:” a step in the bread-making process in which the baker mixes the ingredients. Tyler says that he is a waste of bread, “kneading” his lover’s attention. Some nice wordplay.
https://res.cloudinary.com/hksqkdlah/image/upload/ar_16:9,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto,w_500/articles/STP_MonkeyBread_KneadingDoughbyHand_05
Bread also refers to money, which could imply that Tyler is wasting money to get his lover’s attention.']]), ('I dread that shit, I am Anwar (Skate)', [["Tyler shouts out his close friend Anwar Carrots by creating wordplay with “dread”, making reference to his friend’s dreaded hair, as well as the dread he feels over falling desperately in love.

Coincidentally, Anwar runs his own skatewear brand, Carrots.



Tyler rapped a similar line on “Yonkers”, the lead single from his debut studio album Goblin:

Wearin' synthetic wigs made of Anwar’s dreadlocks"]]), ('[Bridge: Tyler The Creator]', [['This bridge is one of Tyler’s favorite moments on the album, as confirmed through his Twitter:
https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1146167159652941824
This may also be the bridge that he referred to before the release of the album, when he was asked about what the album was like:
https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1125449471486095360']]), ('You are such a distraction', [['In this line, Tyler seems to be referencing the tee off that occurs at the beginning of a game of golf. Golf requires immense concentration, and even professional tournaments remain relatively silent. In a double entendre, Tyler is also saying that this person “messes” with him on and off, or sporadically; this drives T crazy.

This may also be an allusion to Tyler’s clothing brand, Golf.']]), ('Man, I wish you would call me', [["Tyler references Call Me By Your Name, a 2017 coming-of-age romance film that focuses on the gay relationship between a teenager and his father’s assistant.



Tyler shouted out one of the main actors in the movie, Timothee Chalamet, a while back on his early 2018 single “OKRA”:

Tell Tim Chalamet to come get at me
Skin glowin', clear of acne

Since the movie is about a gay relationship, this may be hinting towards Tyler’s theorized homosexuality. He makes a more apparent allusion in 2018’s “GELATO” where he refers to him and his significant other as the film’s main characters:

What’s the dealio? Ain’t ‘gon lie, I’m feelin’ you
You got me on tippy toe, so who’s Oliv, who’s Elio?

Tyler also was talking about this movie in his 2018 single Peach Fuzz. There was a reference to the scene with peach."]]), ('(Four, four, four, four)
 (Four, skate, four, skate, four, skate, four, skate)', [['Tyler absolutely loves skating — he’s mentioned it in his music before, and has even done an interview alongside the one and only Tony Hawk, a famous American professional skateboarder.

The “four” sampled in the backing vocals throughout the song ends the countdown started in “EARFQUAKE.”

It’s speculated that this vocal sample has something to do with the long-awaited EA game, Skate 4, of which Tyler has previously tweeted. He added to this speculation on May 23, 2019, by retweeting this tweet:

https://twitter.com/SuperCuddles_/status/1131350006110146560

On June 13th, Tyler also tweeted this:

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1139165939658657799']]), ('How can I tell you?
 Take ’em to the bridge', [['This line is inspired by Justin Timberlake, who sung a similar line in his 2006 hit “SexyBack” before the bridge of that song:

Take it to the bridge, ha (Let’s see)

Tyler is a big fan of Timberlake, and the two have had a few experiences prior to this song. The two first met in June of 2013, which prompted Tyler to tweet his excitement.

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/350447467084525568?lang=en

The two later appeared on Pharrell’s Beats 1 Radio Show, and were spotted together in the studio in early 2018, possibly indicating of a future collaboration.']]), ('I’m your puppet, you are Jim Henson', [['Jim Henson, founder of the Jim Henson Company, is the creator of the The Muppets franchise, a long–running puppet sketch comedy known for popularizing characters such as Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy.



By making himself the puppet and his love interest his “Jim Henson,” Tyler is ceding all control in the relationship. This also correlates to “PUPPET,” the eighth track on the album where Tyler carries the sentiment:

I’m your puppet, you control me
I’m your puppet, I don’t know me']]), ('[Chorus: Tyler, The Creator & Solange]', [['The song’s chorus interpolates the 1982 track “Special Lady” by Nigerian disco artist, Bibi Mascel.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TRf4S5_Cx20

On the sampled record’s chorus, Bibi sings:

I feel I’ve fallen in love
This time I think it’s for real']]), ('Curiosity killed the feline, gone', [["This line is a play on the phrase “curiosity killed the cat.” Tyler is possibly hinting that curiosity and experimentation in his sexuality killed his interest in females. He has referenced his sexuality before on tracks such as “Garden Shed,” where he raps:

Garden shed, garden shed, garden shed, garden shed
For the garden
That is where I was hidin'
That was real love I was in
Ain’t no reason to pretend"]])]

genius_description:
“IGOR’S THEME,” the introductory track to the project, was first teased in a 50-second snippet posted on Tyler’s social media platforms on May 1, 2019, shortly after  speculation arose surrounding the album after the release of a Sony Financial Report. The track also features additional guest vocals from Lil Uzi Vert and Solange.

Tyler uses this track primarily to let the listener know what they are getting into by indulging in this album, and that they will indeed, “feel this one,” if they weren’t expecting to do so already. The track opens with a distorted bass playing one note for 24 seconds. This same bass sound reappears in some shape or form on every song on the album.

[('Runnin’, runnin’, runnin’, runnin’
 Uh!
 Heaven, heaven (Ooh)
 He’s coming', [["In live performances, Tyler raps a verse that provides more context to these vocals:

Runnin', runnin', runnin' from the space
Goin, nowhere, let’s get to the place
I got to, Heaven, and he closed the gates
A halo to my heart, and now he’s coming

While vague, the phrase “A halo to my heart,”
ties back to themes of love and heartbreak that appear elsewhere on IGOR."]]), ('Down, down, down, down, down
 Down, down, down, down
 Down, down
 Dow-dow-dow-dow-dow-dow-dow-dow-', [["This is a sample of Dâm-Funk’s 2015 track “Scatin' (Toward The Light),” which can be heard at the 2:32-mark:

https://youtu.be/cbN-lm-y8d8?t=152"]]), ('What? What? What? What? What? What? What? What? What? What?', [['Tyler has had a very similar sound appear in other works such as in the intro of “48,” off of his 2013 album Wolf.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4DZuvcBj70w']]), ('Yeah, ho
 Yeah, ho

 Yeah, ho (What?)', [['‘Yeah, ho’ is very likely a reference to Juicy J’s famous ‘Yeah, hoe!’ in Three 6 Mafia’s “Mafia Niggaz.” Tyler mentioned this line in a tweet the day before the album released:

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1128788710298869760']]), ('Ridin’ ‘round town, they gon’ feel this one
 Ridin’ ‘round town, they gon’ feel this one
 Ridin’ ‘round town, they gon’ feel this one
 Ridin’, ridin’ ‘round town, they gon’ feel this one', [['Upon the release of this album, Tyler tweeted out instructions for the proper way to listen to the album. Among them, he included:

SOME GO ON WALKS, SOME DRIVE, SOME LAY IN BED AND SPONGE IT ALL UP. WHATEVER IT IS YOU CHOOSE , FULLY INDULGE. WITH VOLUME.

To ensure that the full emotional impact of the project is felt, he argued that fans should engage in subconscious activity like driving—or, as this song puts it, “ridin' ‘round town"—where all of their attention can be placed on the album. Themes like this aren’t uncommon for Tyler, as vehicles often consume much of his subject matter in general.

Tyler tweeted these lines just a few hours after the album’s release:

genius_description:
On “NEW MAGIC WAND,” Tyler desperately attempts to convince someone he has feelings for to not leave him. However, the person Tyler is in love with is still thinking about their previous relationship with a woman. In the song, Tyler goes to extreme length such as threatening to kill both his love interest and his love interest’s ex-girlfriend in order to get what he wants.

On September 12, 2020, Tyler determined that “NEW MAGIC WAND” is his best song ever in a tweeted bracket ranking of all his own favorite songs.  The song beat out OKAGA, CA for the number one spot.  Tyler had previously declared it his favorite song on IGOR through Instagram on May 30, 2019.

The song was first teased in a 47-second snippet posted on Tyler’s social media platforms on May 14, 2019. The song opens with grimy beat, and features a soft synth change during the bridge.

Tyler also referenced this track in a numerous tweets[1][2] before the album released.

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1128345413822500864

The song features Jessy Wilson and Santigold.

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1130136278115201026
genius_annotations:
[('Please don’t leave me now
 Please don’t leave me now (Don’t leave)
 Please don’t leave me now
 Please don’t leave me now (Don’t leave)
 Please don’t leave me now (Don’t leave)', [['Tyler’s troubled relationship and his fear of split-up between him and his lover are such important themes carrying on throughout IGOR, and they can be explained by comparing the various tracks and their tones.

For example, Tyler uses this phrase for the first time on “EARFQUAKE,” which depicts the potentially stunning emotional and physiological effects of infatuation, by comparing them to the massively destructive force of earthquakes:

Don’t leave, it’s my fault
Don’t leave, it’s my fault
Don’t leave, it’s my fault (Girl)
‘Cause when it all comes crashing down I’ll need you

However, while Tyler expressed that particular feeling by singing passionately, here he uses a disquieting and almost lifeless voice tone, as the darkest side of his love has come over, revealing the primitive jealousy that’s invading him and leading him to anxiety and anger towards his lover and the third person involved.

This dangerous state of mind, still present on the subsequent song “A BOY IS A GUN*,” turns into obsessive devotion on “PUPPET,” causes Tyler/IGOR’s lash-out on “WHAT’S GOOD,” evaporates into the full awareness of the break-up on “GONE, GONE / THANK YOU” and “I DON’T LOVE YOU ANYMORE.”

Nevertheless, Tyler’s initial condition seems to be restored on the final track “ARE WE STILL FRIENDS?”']]), ('Your other one evaporate, we celebrate
 You under oath, now pick a side and if you don’t
 (Run, run, run, run)
 I’ll pick you both
 (Run, run, run, run)', [['Tyler’s feelings of resentment towards his lover and his ex turn into a more dangerous territory – he warns his partner to either commit to the relationship they already have going, or else he just may end up killing both of them out of anger.

The usage of the phrase “Under oath” of course refers to the act of telling the truth in court, a testimony that is told under the complete truth. Tyler wants his lover to choose between him and her, with full on honesty.

This is not the first time Tyler asks his lover for reaffirmation of their love, as on EARFQUAKE he would remark (in a much less aggressive fashion), “I just need some confirmation on how you feel.”']]), ('Don’t call me selfish, I hate sharin’
 This 60-40 isn’t workin’
 I want a hundred of your time, you’re mine', [['Tyler is telling this person that he wants something on the next level; a committed relationship. He’s done with the casual hanging out and wants something real (100%).

60-40 can also be in reference to the 60/40 Relationship Rule which is when each person should put in 60 percent and, in return, expect 40 percent back. Give 60 percent, take 40 percent .

According to  Dr. Amanda Itzkoff, MD most people think a good relationship is a 50/50 proposition.
If, however, both partners instead focus on giving 60% and taking just 40%, the relationship has an overwhelming chance of being successful.']]), ('I wanna be found, passenger in your car (Don’t leave)', [["This could be a reference to his lines from “911 / Mr. Lonely”:

Five car garage
Full tank of the gas
But that don’t mean nothing, nothing
Nothin', nothin', without you shotgun in the passenger

Tyler says he wants to be the passenger in his love interest’s car to convey that he wants to be a part of their life. He wants to be the one who’s in a relationship with this person."]]), ('Janis Joplin spillin’ feelings, now I’m out here moppin’ ’em', [['Janis Joplin was a late 1960s artist that combined folk rock, psychedelia, and blues to create emotionally charged and gut-wrenching songs. The latter genre especially distinguished her considering she was a white suburban female.

In an interview with Stud Terkel, she said:

All you gotta do is have a throat, the throat’s the difference. Everybody’s got feelings inside of them. It’s just the faculty of being able to transform it into music.

Tyler follows in her footsteps by reflecting and expressing his own emotional journey through his music, a process that began with Flower Boy.

Given Tyler’s oblique (and sometimes less so) references to his sexuality, it’s worth mentioning that Joplin famously had sex and long-term romantic relationships with both men and women, and many speculated that she was a lesbian. In response to these claims, she told personal friend and former Grateful Dead manager, Richard Hundgen:

I hear a rumor that somebody in San Francisco is spreading stories that I’m a dyke. You go back there and find out who it is and tell them that Janis says she’s gotten it on with a couple of thousand cats in her life and a few hundred chicks and see what they can do with that!

By comparing himself to her specifically instead of other similar artists associated with emotionally raw lyrics, Tyler makes a deliberate connection.']]), ('I will not fetch the ball', [['This might be another reference to Tyler’s track “911 / Mr. Lonely”, in which he raps:

I never had a dog
So I’ve never been good with bitches
‘Cause I never threw a ball, fetch']]), ('If you can’t understand, I’m a hawk in the gym
 Eyes on the prize, got weight on my chest
 That I need to get off, or I ain’t talkin’ to them', [['Hawks are birds that are known to have very keen eyesight. This characterizes just how focused he is on the prize, which he describes here as getting a weight off his chest (he’s exercising to be strong enough to lift the weight). It’s just another way of saying he’s dedicated to getting rid of this girl.']]), ('Like magic, like magic, like magic, gone
 New magic, new magic, new magic wand
 Like magic, like magic, like magic, gone (Nigga)
 New magic (Woo), new magic, new magic wand', [['Tyler’s envy drives him to believe that by getting rid of his love interest’s ex, his relationship with the love interest will be fixed—as if by ‘magic.’

The ‘magic wand’ Tyler references may be a metaphor for a gun; Tyler elaborates on this metaphor by alluding to killing the ex to win back his love interest in the third verse with the line, “she’s gonna be dead, I just got a magic wand.”

While it’s not clear that the ‘magic wand’ is necessarily a gun, Tyler’s threatening to ‘blow the whole spot up,’ supports this assumption.

Despite many suggestions that the “magic wand” was a reference to the photoshop tool, Tyler confirmed in a tweet that this is not the case.']]), ('It’s not a joke, murder she wrote', [['Murder, She Wrote was a highly-successful crime drama which aired on CBS from 1984 to 1996. Starring Angela Lansbury as a mystery writer who conducts amateur detective work on the side (often unearthing clues that the police do not notice), the series earned Lansbury twelve Emmy nominations and spawned four TV movies.



Tyler is implying that if his love interest chooses to be with this woman, he may have to resort to killing them both.

Tyler may have drawn inspiration here from frequent collaborator Frank Ocean, who references the show on the chorus of his February 2011 track “Lovecrimes:”

Murder, murder, murder she wrote
Love crimes, love crimes']]), ('You roll the dice, hit a seven, sure you right', [["In the game of craps, rolling two dice such that the sum of their values is seven is often the most optimal outcome (though it can sometimes be disadvantageous), and thus the phrase “rolling a seven” (or, alternatively, “hitting a seven”) is associated with good luck. Tyler’s mentor, Pharrell Williams utilizes this phrase in the song “Rollinem 7s” off N.E.R.D’s 2017 album NO_ONE EVER REALLY DIES, in which he raps:

Every time I turn around, I’m rollin' them 7’s"]])]

genius_description: “PUPPET” is the second collaboration between Tyler, the Creator and Kanye West, the first being on “SMUCKERS” from Cherry Bomb. The track discusses the obsessive and protective nature of being in love, and how controlling it can be. Here Tyler/IGOR acknowledges both the positive and negative sides of being under your lover’s thumb. This is thematically represented in the disjointed second half of the song, where music from the start of the song abruptly cuts in.
genius_annotations:
[('You lost, son, and you’ve been tryna find your way to me
 Ayy, to me, he’s on somethin’ that I hate to see', [['This song presents Tyler at his lowest, both heartbroken and submissively desperate for love. Kanye, being someone who’s had his own fair share of heartbreak, sympathizes with such tragedy. He’s seen similar situations to Tyler’s unfold, notably in 2016’s “Wolves” for example:

You tried to play nice, everybody just took advantage
You left your fridge open, somebody just took a sandwich

It’s worth noting that Tyler cites Kanye as a prominent influence for him in general. Even during his emotional lows, Kanye still maintained a strong confidence, which is what Tyler is searching for at this point.']]), ('[Verse 3: Kanye West]', [['The official lyrics for Kanye’s verse have been heavily debated due to its unmixed, lo-fi sound. On June 19th, 2019, Tyler tweeted an official lyric sheet that didn’t help. In place of Kanye’s verse, he simply wrote:

KANYE LYRICS CANNOT BE TRANSCRIBED



Due to the purposely unverified lyrics, it’s possible that the currently transcribed lyrics aren’t entirely accurate.']]), ('Do you need a hug?', [['https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1136990220535156744
Tyler jokingly uses misdirection here. The rhyme scheme suggests that he’d rhyme this line with “bread”, which would then be completed with “instead.”

However, he abruptly inserts “a hug” to throw the listener off. This most likely implies that he would’ve asked the person “Do you need head?”

When performing this song live, Tyler sometimes does say “head” instead of hug.']]), ('But at some point, you come to your senses', [['Seemingly this is him being freed from a toxic relationship, but it’s actually Tyler lying to himself, and not being able to let go of this person, he does this a couple of times on the album, even on the final 2 lines of the album;

“A BOY IS A GUN”:

I ain’t gon' repeat myself, but stay the fuck away from me").

The next track on the album (WHAT’S GOOD) ends with “I don’t know what’s harder, letting go or just being okay with it” it shows us that even though he seemingly “came to his senses”, he was just pretending and still can’t let go of this person.

On “GONE, GONE / THANK YOU” Tyler seemingly accepts the loss of this person and he never wants to fall in love again, but that is only because how hurt he is:

And now I’m scarred for life

Once again on the next track I DON’T LOVE YOU ANYMORE Tyler says that he is no longer in love and is completely over it, yet he still chases this love (to an extent) on the last track ARE WE STILL FRIENDS? where he admits that he can’t let go, with even the final 2 lines of the album being:

Can’t say goodbye

Tyler clearly still has deep feelings for this person, even though he pretended like he didn’t because he was left scarred. All of this connects back to the track EXACTLY WHAT YOU RUN FROM YOU END UP CHASING:

Exactly what you run from, you end up chasing. Like, you can’t avoid, but just chasing it and just like trying. Giving it everything that you can.']]), ('[Verse 2: Tyler, The Creator]', [['Tyler’s staccato flow during the second verse is very reminiscent of André 3000’s chorus on Erykah Badu’s “Hello”:

Will this bitch click over for me?
I mean will this woman click over for me?

https://youtu.be/KXGqHYNTNHU?t=77']]), ('I wanna talk, I wanna call you and talk
 I wanna walk to your front door and knock', [["These lines connect to the fact that Tyler is crawling back to his lover and also explores the meaning of the skit “EXACTLY WHAT YOU RUN FROM YOU END UP CHASING”, as he ended up running from his love interest in the previous track “A BOY IS A GUN” when Tyler told his lover:

I'ma leave it at that, I'ma leave us as friends
‘Cause the irony is I don’t wanna see you again
Stay the fuck away from me

 Tyler later comes back chasing after his lover."]]), ('A to Z, nah son, I’m gonna take a breathe', [["This may be a subtle nod to East coast rappers AZ and Nas who’re known for being one of the best unofficial rap duos to come out of the New York hip-hop scene. They’re responsible for songs like 2008’s “Serious” and 1994’s “Life’s A Bitch.”



On the left: Nas; On the right: AZ.


Ye’s usage of the homonym “Nah, son” to “Nas son” may also be in reference to Nas' 2002 sixth studio album God’s Son (as the homonym and album title sound phonetically similar.)"]]), ('Then back to my house and we pack up our bikes
 And we ride through the park, chase the sun', [['Tyler has been very vocal about his love for biking. Not only did he deliver a verse about it on Frank Ocean’s 2017 loosie “Biking,” but he even devoted an entire song, 2013’s “Slater,” to his bike of the same name, explaining in a tweet:

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/327255730036035584?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw







In an interview with GQ Magazine in August of 2018, Tyler was asked about his ideal day and responded with this:

I would wake up, definitely make breakfast, go on a fucking long-ass bike ride, and it either ends going to a show from a band or going to see a movie. And somewhere swimming in between that.']]), ('I’m your puppet, you control me
 I’m your puppet, I don’t know me
 (Did I wait too long?)
 I’m your puppet
 (Did I wait too long?)
 You control me
 (Did I wait too long?)
 I’m your puppet
 (Did I wait too long?)
 I’m lonely
 ’Cause I’m your puppet
 (Puppet, oh)
 You control me (Control me)
 I’m your puppet (Puppet)
 I don’t know
 I’m your puppet (Did I wait too long?)
 You control me (Puppet)', [["The chorus and title could be an interpolation of 1966’s “I’m Your Puppet” by James & Bobby Purify where the same metaphor is used:

I’m your puppet
I’ll do funny things if you want me to
[…]
I’m yours to have and to hold
Darling, you’ve got full control of your puppet

Tyler sings of a similar sentiment a few tracks earlier on “I THINK” where he references The Muppets creator Jim Henson:

Wasted, boy, I need your attention (Skate)
I’m off balance, I need some fixin' (Four)
I’m your puppet, you are Jim Henson (Skate, four)

Much like a puppet, Tyler’s emotional spectrum is being entirely controlled by the responses of his significant other. He can’t help but wonder if his romantic gestures are ill-timed or not. Kanye emphasizes this, singing “Did I wait too long?” throughout the chorus. This in itself reflects a similar sentiment found in “RUNNING OUT OF TIME”:

Runnin' out of time to make you love me

Tyler tweeted the chorus a while after the album’s release:
https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1130860927857750018"]]), ('First, light the weed', [["While Kanye has never been known as a huge weed smoker, he has made references to the drug before. Most notably, Ye’s 2004 song “Get Em High” was an anthem for cannabis:

And if you’re losin' your high then smoke again
Keep ‘em high

West also admitted to being high during his 2015 VMA acceptance speech for the Video Vanguard Award."]])]

genius_description:
“RUNNING OUT OF TIME” describes Tyler’s fleeting relationship with a significant other and warn them that a split is imminent.

Thematically, it introduces tension to the love dynamic previously constructed throughout the album.

During Tyler’s Apple Music Concert in L.A, he explained that he showed the album to Kendrick Lamar, where Kendrick praised him about the raw feeling of the album and his overall willingness to ‘sing his truth’. This conversation led him to write this song.
genius_annotations:
[('Spells', [['The word spells here references the next song on IGOR, NEW MAGIC WAND. In this song, Tyler is struggling to find a way to make his love interest love him, but in NEW MAGIC WAND he comes up with a plan to shoot and kill his love interest’s ex-girlfriend.

The word also shows that his attraction to his love interest is relatively one-sided, since he needs “spells” to appease his lover and keep them around.']]), ('Take your mask off', [['A theme which permeates throughout this album is the notion that Tyler’s partner is hiding himself from both Tyler and from the world. This could potentially take the form of him maintaining a relationship with an ex-girlfriend, which Tyler references repeatedly on this album, or it could be that this partner is using heterosexuality to mask his true self.

The phrase “take that mask off” was also used by a BROCKHAMPTON frontman, Kevin Abstract (who includes Tyler as his biggest music influence) as an allusion to men who live their lives in the closet.']]), ('Wade in your water (Wade in your water)', [['This phrase is in reference to “Wade in the Water,” written by John Wesley Work II and Frederick J. Work. The song’s lyrics were used in the Underground Railroad during the age of slavery as instructions to escape dogs and slave owners.

In this phrase and to the end of the verse, Tyler sings about wading in “your water” to the person he is singing to. The theme of escape in the song is a tying motif, as he doesn’t want to be saved by anyone from drowning in the person’s love.']]), ('I need her out the picture (Wade in your water)', [["The line resembles one that appears on the next song, “NEW MAGIC WAND”.

I need to get her out the picture
She’s really fuckin' up my frame

The woman Tyler is referring to is his partner’s ex-girlfriend. Tyler’s partner is hiding himself from the world. One of the ways he does this is by maintaining a relationship with an ex-girlfriend, which Tyler references on the album – most notably on “NEW MAGIC WAND”.

“Wade in the Water” is a Negro spiritual whose lyrics were first published in the 1901 edition of New Jubilee Songs as Sung by the Fisk Jubilee Singers. The lyrics were supposedly used by Harriet Tubman to instruct fugitive slaves to trudge through the water so the dogs chasing them will lose their scent."]]), ('And now they working their all, another track out the DAW', [['“DAW” is short for Digital Audio Workstation. It’s a computerized system for sound recording, music production, mixing and mastering

It can be a single software program on a laptop, to an integrated stand-alone unit, all the way to a complex configuration of numerous components controlled by a central computer.

Tyler, a prominent producer within his music, has previously used DAWs lyrically too, most notably in his verse on the Odd Future posse cut “Oldie” where he plays on 3 different DAW programs:

I never had a Reason, nigga, I was just Ableton
Not a fucking Logic contradicting dick head']]), ('Livin’ in pretend
 Keep it a buck fifty, fuck
 Are you livin’ in pretend?
 Are you–', [["These lines are most likely in reference to Tyler’s partner, who the whole album is about. Tyler claims this person is wearing a “mask” to hide his true self from the world – hence “livin' in pretend”. What he’s hiding from the world is somewhat ambiguous but it seems likely that Tyler’s partner is a closeted gay or bisexual man. This is hinted at with him trying to maintain a relationship with his ex-girlfriend. He perhaps does this to mask his sexuality. No matter what it is that he’s hiding, it is slowly ruining the relationship between Tyler and him.

Tyler tweeted about this line hours before the album dropped, writing:

keep it a buck50 fuck areeee u living in pretend?……… drums

This was also mentioned on “November” from Tyler’s fourth studio album Flower Boy.

What if I got comfortable?
I gotta keep it buck fifty what"]]), ('I drift to the deep end
 Don’t save, don’t save, don’t save
 It’s a low tide (I’ll be fine)
 I found peace in drownin’', [["Perhaps Tyler drew inspiration from frequent collaborator Frank Ocean, for whom this imagery is nothing new. In his track “Swim Good” off 2011’s nostalgia, ULTRA., he sings of driving his car into the ocean, which may be a reference to either suicide or purification. The song’s bridge reads:

I’m goin' off (Throw me a line)
Don’t try saving (Broke my heart)
No flares (Broke my heart)
No vest (Drove my love)
And no fear
Waves are washin' me out

Tyler uses the drowning motif to refer to the inescapable, overwhelming nature of falling in love. He alludes to this idea on Flower Boy’s penultimate track, “Glitter,” on which he raps:

I’m caught in your quicksand, wait
Please don’t save me"]])]

genius_description:
“WHAT’S GOOD” is the ninth track from Tyler’s fifth studio album IGOR. It was first teased in a 48-second snippet posted on Tyler’s social media platforms on May 3, 2019, showing him dancing frantically to the song.

The track makes heavy use of drums and distorted synths, one of the more aggressive cuts from the album. It is also one of the only tracks that Tyler raps throughout.

Up-and-coming UK rapper slowthai, who also released an album on May 17, provides additional vocals for the track.
genius_annotations:
[('I see the light', [['I SEE THE LIGHT!!!']]), ('I don’t know what’s harder, letting go or just being okay with it', [['The dicotomy of choice. By default, every choice you pick denies the rest of the possibilities at that point. Tyler recognizes this throughout the entire album, through the entire relationship, and reinforces it here clearly.']]), ('To pay attention and to keep your motherfucking eyes glued to the man that’s in front of you?', [['This sample is taken from the MTV documentary Scared Straight ‘99. The film follows a group of convicts whose goal is to scare juvenile delinquents about the horrors of prison life to help them avoid a life of crime. Tyler uses these sound clips to add to the dark, aggressive aura of the song, and paint a picture of his Igor character. He is essentially scaring the listener straight.

This sample was removed from all versions of the song about a week after the album’s release after copyright issues arose.

The original version of the song with the sample intact can still be heard on some physical versions of the album, as well as early MP3 downloads of the track.']]), ('Turn my lights on
 How the fuck you quiet with the mic on?', [['Tyler’s partner is suddenly quiet in an argument when Tyler let’s him have the floor']]), ('Everything I deliver special like G. Dep', [['This is a reference to Harlem rapper G. Dep’s signature track “Special Delivery.” Appearing on his 2001 album Child of the Ghetto, the song is better known for its Diddy remix or for its beat being recycled in Lil Wayne’s 2018 hit “Uproar.” Perhaps Tyler was inspired to make this reference because of his previous line about Dracula, as G. Dep refers to himself as “the rap vampire” in “Special Delivery.”

Tyler has also been seen dancing to the song:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1mbuP1KwfOU']]), ('Is that shit clear? Check the aperture', [['“I see the light” is repeated throughout the second part of the song. This mirrors last line from the previous song, Puppet, “But at some point, you come to your senses” and serves to progress the narrative of the album as his love draws to a close.

In photography, changing the aperture affects the depth of field, which could mean that he’s isolating his thoughts and feelings from everything else around him. It also changes the amount of light that enters the camera, thus implying that his eyes have been opened to his true feelings, reiterating that line “I see the light”.']]), ('Niggas turning it up, well, shit, I’m tearing it down', [["A possible interpolation of Kanye West’s song “New Slaves” of his album Yeezus, released in 2013.

Y'all ‘bout to turn shit up
I’m 'bout to tear shit down"]]), ('Had them niggas and the cops looking jigsaw', [['Jigsaw refers to a type of puzzle involving numerous interlocking pieces that all fit together to form a full picture.



The word “puzzle” itself is also often used to describe someone being confused or disoriented. Tyler uses the association between “jigsaw” and “puzzle” to cleverly continue the rhyme and describe how his persona often leaves people looking puzzled.

This is may also be a reference to Jigsaw. Released in 2017, the American horror film directed by Michael and Peter Spierig, written by Josh Stolberg and Peter Goldfinger, is the eighth installment in the Saw franchise.



Tyler could be referencing this film as it consists of police attempting to track down a notorious serial killer.']]), ('And they some Helen Keller-ass niggas
 And I got my eyes open now I see the...', [['Helen Keller (1880-1968) was an American political activist who was known for being both deaf and blind.



Tyler likens his competition to her, saying that they’re practically blind and deaf to the opportunity around them. This is unlike Tyler who, in “IGOR’S THEME,” contrasts himself with such ignorance:

Got my, got my, got my, got my eyes open
Got my eyes open (Oh)

Tyler notably referenced Keller once before on 2009’s “French" off his debut mixtape Bastard in which he rapped:

When it comes to your perception of my shit, I’m Helen Keller']]), ('New album, no repeat, I reset', [['Just hours before the release of IGOR, Tyler tweeted this image, announcing IGOR as a separate project from his previous, and a new sound. He also encourages the listener to listen “all the way through, no skips. Front to back.”']])]

genius_description:
“Go Loko” serves as the second single of YG’s fourth studio album 4REAL 4REAL. On the Jon Z and Tyga assisted track, the rappers describe their wild lifestyles and discuss various topics including their relationships, alcohol, and weapons.

“Loco” is a Spanish term that translates to crazy, which fits the song’s overall theme of going out of control. YG chooses not to spell “loco” correctly, by replacing the ‘c’ with a ‘k’, because of his affiliation with the Blood gang and their rivalry with the Crip gang. YG has done this before on his album My Krazy Life.

genius_description:
“223’s” is a bouncy, joyful collaboration between young rappers YNW Melly and 9LOKKNINE. The song features production from New Jersey producer Rocco Did It Again.

The song was originally released as a song on 9LOKK’s 2018 mixtape Lil Glokk That Stole Christmas, with 9LOKK being credited as the lead artist and Melly being listed as a feature. Later, on August 9, 2019, the song was re-released as a single, with Melly now being the lead artist and 9LOKK listed as the featured artist.

The song has since peaked at number 34 on the Billboard Hot 100, particularly due to a dance challenge that has gone viral on social media app TikTok.

The music video for the track, directed by DrewFilmedIt, was released on November 2, 2019. Melly reacted to the video from his jail cell over a FaceTime call with DJ Akademiks.

The track appeared on Melly’s debut studio album Melly Vs. Melvin, which released on November 22, 2019.
genius_annotations:
[('And the clip is see-through', [['YNW Melly is referring to the Elite Tactical System magazines for Glocks.

The magazines are completely see-through where you can see all of the bullets.



Pictured: ETS Glock see-through magazine']]), ('Pulled a 40 with a dicky, gotta kill up y’all', [['YNW Melly is referring to a Glock 40, a model from Austrian firearm manufacturer Glock.

A “dicky” is an extended magazine, in this case, an original magazine holds 15 bullets whereas an extended one has a capacity of 31 bullets. Melly uses this term in “Maserati”, released on January 29, 2019. He says:

We ride through your house with a whole lot of sticks, with them Glocks with them dicks



Glock 40 with an extended magazine']]), ('Detrimental
 Me and Glokk all on your instrumental', [['The word “detrimental” means to cause harm or be harmful, following up with:

Me and Glokk all on your instrumental

This could mean that Melly is saying that him and 9lokkNine are harmful or cause harm on the track. This is common phrase in the rap industry to say that  the track is good or “fire”.']]), ('Blood walk, baby, this the Blood walk, huh', [['the “blood walk” is a dance performed by blood gang members. It consists of moving your foot around and spelling the word “blood”.

YNW Melly refers to this as it is a known fact that Melly has joined the G-Shine bloods since a young age while even rapping about his affiliation in songs such a “Adam Sandler” released on November 22, 2019. He says:

I’m a real Blood, G shining, ain’t no bitch in me']]), ('Blood Gang, yeah, SuWoop on me', [['The term “suwoop“ is commonly used as slang in the aforementioned Blood Gang as a greeting.']]), ('Rocco did it again', [['This is the producer Rocco’s producer tag. This is the first time Rocco has worked with YNW Melly. It is the second time Rocco has worked with 9lokknine. He also worked with 9lokknine on his song “Xmas Song”.
You can find a full list of producer tags here.']]), ("AR’s and them .223's", [['A .223 Remington is a bullet cartridge with identical external dimensions as the 5.56×45mm NATO.

Melly has mentioned this cartridge on his 2018 hit, “Virtual (Blue Balenciags)” where he said:

Seven point six two, five point five six’s, two-two-three



Pictured: .223 Remington

Meanwhile, AR’s refer to the popular AR-15-style rifles which are lightweight semi-automatic rifles.

Melly has also mentioned AR-15’s on “Virtual (Blue Balenciags)” where he rapped:

Two-two-three, AR-15’s



Pictured: AR-15']]), ('Like apostrophe, Google forgot a comma in the back
 Say I’m worth 250K, we can bet a trey on that, nigga', [["Google is notorious for reporting celebrities' net worth based on inaccurate website estimates, much to the chagrin of a wealthy man like GlokkNine. Google isn’t really to blame for this, but they take the brunt of the complaints.

The website FamousBirthsDeaths lists GlokkNine’s net worth as $250,000, although it also notes that he signed a deal with Birdman’s Cash Money that is reportedly worth $2,000,000.

GlokkNine thinks that this is a woeful underestimate of his wealth and slyly offers to bet $300,000 that he has more than $250,000."]])]

genius_description:
24kGoldn enlists the help of friend iann dior for “Mood.” The two have collaborated in the past, most notably on iann dior’s “gone girl,” which credits 24kGoldn as a co-writer.

Throughout the track, the two reflect on being stuck in a toxic relationship with a woman who is fickle, indecisive, and often manipulative. Despite the tone of the subject matter, the track is upbeat and poppy, carrying a similar tone and structure to “Never is Enough” from iann dior’s debut album Industry Plant.

The song was first teased on an Instagram story from 24kGoldn on May 1, 2020. A few weeks later on May 22, the same date as the release of iann dior’s single “Prospect,” producer Omer Fedi posted a video of 24kGoldn and iann dior dancing to the track on his Instagram story, with the caption

U think they ready?

A snippet of “Mood” was first released on the creator community platform Zebra on June 15, 2020. 24kGoldn later posted a Tiktok four days later, encouraging his fans to join his community on the app.

On July 19 2020, 24kGoldn confirmed the track after uploading a Triller of the song with iann dior to his Instagram.
genius_annotations:
[('Elephant in the room', [['Elephant in the room means an obvious problem that everyone avoids discussing.']]), ('Everything look better with a view', [['24kGolden is trying to point out that in a relationship, you should always look at the point of view of the other person in it.

Thus saying, “Everything look better with a view”.
He’s trying to explain to his significant other that they shouldn’t just jump to conclusions in a situation, and rather see the other person’s perspective.']]), ('Gang sippin’ fourties', [["In the American vernacular, a forty-ounce or simply forty is a glass or plastic bottle that holds 40 US fluid ounces (1,200 millilitres; 2 1⁄2 US pints) of malt liquor. Malt liquors are commonly sold in 40 fluid ounce bottles, among other sizes, as opposed to the standard 12-US-fluid-ounce (350 mL; 3⁄4 US pt) bottle that contains a single serving of beer, although many malt liquors are offered in varying volumes.

Forties are often mentioned in hip-hop and rap culture by rap stars endorsing the “40” Ounce tradition. A similar trend was common around the late 1990s' and early 2000s' punk scene, with such songs as “40.oz Casualty” by The Casualties, “Rock the 40. Oz.” by Leftöver Crack, and “40oz. to Freedom” by Sublime."]]), ('Why you always in a mood? Fuckin’ ‘round, actin’ brand new
 I ain’t tryna tell you what to do, but try to play it cool', [['24kGoldn points out how his girl is always being dramatic and unpredictable, which is ruining their relationship. He wants her to know that he is aware of her causing the problem, and they would be better off if she calmed down.

“Acting brand new” is a slang term for a sudden change in someone’s attitude, especially if they’re acting stuck-up or snobbish.']])]

genius_primary_artist: Anuel AA, Daddy Yankee & KAROL G
genius_description:
“China” es un super junte entre culturas y géneros de Puerto Rico y Colombia. La canción trata sobre una persona que se dejó sobrellevar del ambiente de pasarla bien que se vive en la disco y se tomó un tiempo con su pareja para celebrar.

Este tema es un claro homenaje a la canción “It Wasn’t Me” de Shaggy, el cual es un clásico que ha sido utilizado como referencia en muchos temas, como “Va Segui” de Mark B, canción con la que “China” estuvo fuertemente comparada un mes antes de su estreno debido a que ambas tenían ritmos similares.

Anuel es el propietario de la canción y es quien le pone el nombre al tema, pero no significa nada. Hubo fuertes rumores de que el nombre fue puesto ya que en Puerto Rico, el verde es conocido como color china o color chinita. En cambio, la canción lleva por nombre China ya que la pista original (producida por DJ Snake) tenía rasgos asiáticos según Anuel y por eso este le puso así.

Siguiendo el tema, en primera instancia, el productor de esta canción iba a ser DJ Snake, quien por varios problemas de papeleo con Anuel no pudo ser incluido, entonces, se tuvo que cambiar al productor que hoy en día es Tainy, así mismo como se tuvo que cambiar el instrumental de esta. Todo esto en base a lo que dijo Anuel en una entrevista para MTV.

Cabe destacar que en la mayoría de temas que Anuel ha lanzado este 2019 ha estado envuelto con su novia y futura esposa Karol G. Según rumores, Anuel había dicho a principios del año que Karol G iba a ser la única fémina con la que iba a colaborar, a pesar de haberlo visto junto a Becky G en “Bubalu”.

Originalmente, el junte iba a ser el mismo sin J Balvin, este por su parte, fue añadido a último minuto. Por lo que se puede ver en el video, las tomas en donde Balvin aparece fueron grabadas en Cartagena, donde estuvo él sólo, ya que no se le ve en ninguna toma junto a los demás.

Tanto así que existe varias escenas en donde se usó una pantalla verde para aparentar que Balvin se encontraba en el set con los demás:

[('Yo tengo un problema de alcohol
 Yo no sé por qué soy así (Así, así)
 Pa’ mí que el doctor estaba bebiendo
 El día que yo nací (Mami, mami)', [["Desde pequeñito escondío' de mi mamá, tú sabe', a los die' o doce, cuando uno es bien presentao', y estás por la casa, que tu pai dejó en la nevera una botella o lo que sea, y tú, bien presentao', te mete' a robarla y te robas la botellita.

 – Anuel AA para Genius Verified."]]), ('Dios mío, perdóname

genius_description:
For the seventh track from her sixth studio album, positions, Ariana recruits Ty Dolla $ign. “safety net” marks the first collaboration between the two artists. In an interview, $ign talks about the track calling it “a melodic and amazing tune”.

In early October, rumors of the collaboration circulated on the networks after the supposed tracklist of the album was leaked under a different name as “no remedy”. And on October 24, 2020, Ariana uploaded a photo on her Twitter of the album’s tracklist, thus confirming the collaboration and the title of the track.
genius_annotations:
[('You’re making me forget my past
 Never thought I’d feel like that again', [['Before dropping this album, Ariana had her longest period being single in the public eye. From “I ain’t looking for my one true love, yeah that ship sailed away” and the following tweet, it seemed to Ariana and us that there was no moving on from Mac.']]), ('You know we hit that jewelry store and we gon’ ball out
 Ups and downs, we had some fallouts (Ooh, yeah)
 Put some ice on you, girl, let it thaw out (Ooh)', [['To “put ice” on Ariana has a double-meaning, referring to buying her expensive jewels, or metaphorically putting ice on her to treat wounds of a broken heart. The first meaning is punctuated by the previous line on going to the jewelry store while the second is punctuated by saying they’ll have a “fallout.” Either way, Ty Dolla $ign indicates that they can move past arguments.



“Put some ice on your girl, let it thaw out,” is ironic because in “Obvious”, Ariana sings:

Don’t put the bands, put the bands on me
Oh, my love, oh, my love is free,

Basically stating that she doesn’t want her partner to apologize with jewelery or other richities because her love is free and so is her loyalty to him.']]), ('I came to peace with my path
 Now you got me off track', [['This part of the song was teased by Ariana on her Twitter, hours before the song released:

https://twitter.com/ArianaGrande/status/1321858186748420102

It refers to the fact that she’s been strayed from the path that she led in her past relationships, and now she’s afraid of the new things that she’s experiencing with her current partner, since she’s not used to those things in a relationship.']]), ('Boy, it must be something that you said
 Is it real this time or is it in my head?', [['This is a callback to Ariana’s February 2019 track “in my head,” from her previous album, thank u, next, where she realized she loved a fake perfect construct of her truly imperfect partner:

I thought you were the one
But it was all in my head

On “safety net,” Ariana uses this same line to wonder whether her new relationship is worth staying in.

During an interview with the Zach Sang Show, Ariana spoke on incorporating nods to her past songs on positions and mentioned that this lyric was her favorite:

One of my favorite [references to past songs] is in “safety net” – is it real this time or is it in my head? I like the “in my head” reference']]), ('Mmm
 Tripping, falling, with no safety net', [['“Safety Net” is a prevention method for a person, it consists of placing a large net between a person and the ground, basically it is used in the trapeze for the protection of an acrobat in case of a fall. The net is placed below where the acrobat performs the show, at a height of 6 meters or more.



Trapeze with a safety net




Ariana compares this to the feeling in a relationship, referring to the fact that she is giving everything to make that relationship work and taking a leap, and even though she doesn’t know if the relationship will work, she is willing to try and she risks it all for him. She’s giving this fresh relationship a try, even though she knows the complications that can come from that situation.

It could also be a reference to her 2019 track “in my head”, where she sang:

Falling, falling, but I never thought you’d leave me
Falling, falling, needed something to believe in, oh

It is practically the same, because of the way in both songs she says talks about love without “safety net”.']])]

Ty did his thing but idk why I hear Khalid killing a remix of this', 'leon thomas iii has writing credits on this?‽‽', 'my fav so far', 'this about to go hard, I already know', 'now me tell why did you snap this hard ari', 'YALL BETTER GLUE YOUR WEAVES 🔥🔥🖤 SHE IS COMING', 'Ngl, this song crept on me and now has become my fav', 'I LOVE THIS SONG OMG', 'this is my top 1, the production is literally so good omg', 'so far my favorite', 'I can’t even express how much I love this girl fr']

genius_description:
“SOS” is the first single from Avicii since his tragic passing on April 20, 2018. The track, which features Aloe Blacc, serves as the lead single for TIM, his posthumous third album. This marks Avicii and Aloe Blacc’s third collaboration, after “Wake Me Up” and “Liar Liar.” The track details some of Avicii’s personal battles, including drug usage and struggles with love, over a synth-heavy instrumental.

The song was teased in a YouTube video on April 5, 2019, promoting TIM.
genius_annotations:
[('I can feel your love pullin’ me up from the underground, and
 I don’t need my drugs, we could be more than just part-time lovers
 I can feel your touch pickin’ me up from the underground, and
 I don’t need my drugs, we could be more than just part-time lovers', [['The melody and Blacc’s flow here resembles that of the chorus of TLC’s 1999 track, “No Scrubs”:

No, I don’t want no scrubs
A scrub is a guy that can’t get no love from me

Which explains why its co-writers, Kandi Burruss and Tameka “Tiny” Harris, are given writing credits, similar to how Ed Sheeran’s team gave the two credits on his own “Shape of You” after fans noticed similarities between it and “No Scrubs.”

https://youtu.be/FrLequ6dUdM']]), ('Two times clean again, I’m actin’ low', [['Avicii was hospitalized twice. The first time (in late January 2012), it was for acute pancreatitis, a side effect of what, for Avicii, was apparently too much drinking.

https://twitter.com/Avicii/status/167351779921633280

The second time was because his gallbladder needed to be removed, which Tim explained further in a series of Tweets.

A later update from Tim revealed that his treatment was for more than just his gallbladder.

https://twitter.com/Avicii/status/450065982909087744']])]

genius_description:
“Supalonely” is the third single from the EP Stella & Steve. The song gained popularity in March 2020, after it went viral on TikTok.

The song was written during a trip to Los Angeles, following a break-up that inspired BENEE to write “Supalonely” and “Blu.”. She explained the song’s sound to i-D in February 2020:

Sometimes when you’re sad you’re just like, ugh, get over it! I think when I listen to music like “Supalonely” where it’s making fun of the feeling of being sad, in a way it kind of makes me feel good in a very weird way. When I hear “Supalonely” now and when I perform it I feel happy.

During Elton John’s Rocket Hour radio show on Apple Music in March 2020, he expressed his love for the song, inviting BENEE to join him on-air. In an Instagram post Elton said:

Supalonely by @beneemusic is my top tip for the next global smash. Love her and her music. #NewZealandRocks
genius_annotations:
[('So I don’t slam my Irish buck', [['‘Irish Buck’ is a cocktail.

To ‘slam a drink’ is to gulp the drink down and slam the empty glass on the table.

Said action could presumably hint to not enjoying the drink, and just wanting to go to alcoholism to drown sorrows.



Gus Dapperton is referring to not wanting to end up an alcoholic due to bad love experiences, he hates love not because of the ‘now’, but because of the ‘what if’.']]), ('La-la-la-la (Woo), la-la-la-la
 Lonely (I’m a lonely bitch)
 La-la-la-la, la-la-la-la
 Lonely (Super lonely)', [['Speaking with Invertebrate Music she described that she approached making the song differently than others. Since she was heartbroken and sad, she felt like she didn’t have anything to lose, especially in inserting these adlibs:

Even when I did the ad-libs in the song, like the screaming and the “I’m a lonely b*tch” it was kind of like “why not?” You know what I mean? I didn’t really have anything to lose (laughs) when I was in the studio. I didn’t really feel like anything was going my way so I was just like, “you know what? Stuff it. I’m just going to have fun doing this.” And I feel like that’s sometimes when the best stuff can come out, when you’re not caring too much.']]), ('Now I’m in the bathtub cryin’
 Think I’m slowly sinking
 Bubbles in my eyes now', [['When I’m saying, “I’m slowly sinking”, it’s like when you know that you’re going to be sad for ages. It’s like, I don’t know, it can make you a lot more upset I think, just thinking, “Oh my God, I’m going to be sad for so long.” I don’t know, I was in this kind of hole, where I don’t know, I could just feel that I was sinking. I was just sinking at the time.']]), ('La-la-la-la, la-la-la-la
 Lonely (I’m a lonely bitch)
 La-la-la-la, la-la-la-la
 Lonely (Super lonely)', [['Dude, I mean, I think when we recorded these “La-la-la-la”, I kind of just went in there and freestyled, and it was like, “La-la-la-la, la-la,” and then it was like, “I’m a lonely bitch,” and then it got a little bit more aggressive when I was saying bitch.  I think I ended up having more fun with it around the end of the session, which is when we recorded these, and I was kind of just, I was kind of like, “Okay, I’m just going to be super animated here.” And I don’t know, I think super lonely is when I’m realizing, like, “I am hella lonely right now.” Then, we had lots of auto-tune in the verses and stuff, and I kind of wanted to get, like, “My lonely bitch,” the kind of rapper vibes.']]), ('All of my friends know what’s happened, you’re a bad thing (Ah)', [["I think that my friends' opinions definitely impact how I go about everything I do. And in this situation, they knew that I wasn’t happy in the relationship and they knew that it wasn’t working for me. I was always talking to them about it and stuff, and I had gotten back into a relationship two times with this same person, and they were kind of over him by then, and they were like, “Dude, if you were happy all the time, I’d say try making it work, but it’s not.”"]]), ('I’m a sad girl in this big world, it’s a mad world', [['I just felt very little and insignificant I think, especially going to LA and not really knowing anyone. I think for me, at the time, I was kind of like, “This world is so huge and my problems are so small, but I still feel like the whole world is against me right now and nothing is going as I want it to.”']]), ('Maybe I’m dramatic, I don’t wanna seem it
 I don’t wanna panic', [['I fully embraced the whole sad girl vibes in this song. I think that’s that thing of me just hating to be sad and feeling sorry for myself and stuff. I thought that I was being quite dramatic at the time because I was like, “God, I’m so bloody sad, what the heck is happening?” And I think that whole thing of still hard to believe it, I think, I had a feeling it would happen, but it didn’t really feel like it was actually happening to me, and was kind of like, “Why?” I think it was so fresh out of it that I was very confused.']]), ('Water pouring down from the ceiling
 I knew this would happen, still hard to believe it', [['It kind of felt like everything was just falling on me, and I felt very heavy-chested and very much like the world was squishing me, and I think that the water, the amount that I cried, I think that’s kind of where that came from. Just didn’t know that I could cry that much before I went on this trip. But I mean, it felt good, and I feel like crying feels really damn good when you really get into it. I definitely think that the water pouring down from the ceiling is just the weight being pushed on you when you’re sad, and just feeling like everything is out to get you.']]), ('While you’re out there drinkin’, I’m just here thinkin’
 ’Bout where I should’ve been
 I’ve been lonely, mmh, ah, yeah', [['That was completely where I was at when I wrote it, was. The fact that they were at home with all of their mates, partying. I feel like even when you’re the person who ends the relationship and you go out and get drunk all the time and you party, let loose, nothing matters, stuff it. And in my case, I was in LA by myself, and I’m not 21, so I was just stuck at home being miserable, but obviously feeling jealous that they were out there just having a good old time, and I was lonely.']]), ('I know I fucked up, I’m just a loser
 Shouldn’t be with ya, guess I’m a quitter', [['I think the whole mood of the song is that I was just going to be super self-deprecating and just, I hate feeling sorry for myself. I just hated that I was so sad about something. I broke up with him, so it felt like it was my fault, and I was like, “I’m an idiot. I’m so dumb. Why would I do that when I’m about to go to LA for a month and be by myself?” So, I don’t know, I just wanted to make it seem like I was the one in the wrong.']])]

genius_description:
“Ice Cream” is the second single by BLACKPINK off their debut studio album, BLACKPINK THE ALBUM and marks their first collaboration with American singer-songwriter Selena Gomez.

This dance-pop track compares the sweet charms of the five singers to ice cream, telling that even it’s cold on the outside, they are feisty when you taste it. The dessert-themed video also finds Selena dressed in a sailor suit as an Ice-Cream truck’s employee, with the K-Pop stars in stylish and colorful outfits, showcasing their choreographed moves.

Rumors of a collaboration between the two circulated for a while on various websites. On August 12, the collaboration was confirmed by Selena and BLACKPINK. On August 21, the song title was revealed by both artists.
genius_annotations:
[('Millis, billis 매일 벌음 한여름 손목에 얼음', [['Millis, Billis every day, night and summer ice on your wrist']]), ('미친 미친듯한 속도 in my La Ferra’
 너무 빨러 너는 삐끗 원한다면 그냥 지름', [["[EN]

Pedal to the metal in my La Ferra'
 So fast, you keep slippin', if you want it, I just get it

LaFerrari (referred to as LaFerra'), is an exclusive and very limited model of a sports car manufactured by Ferrari. These cars were produced between 2013 and 2018, and only around 700 were made, with the most recent model being the 2018 LaFerrari Aperta. It’s top speed is estimated at 350 kilometers per hour (217 miles per hour).

Keeping with the bad girl theme established in the previous line, Lisa says that she is going as fast as she can in her car, racing off from boys chasing her.

She has made pervious reference to fancy sports cars in Blackpink’s 2016 hit, “BOOMBAYAH,” where she raps:

90’s baby, I pump up the jam
Step on it, step on it, oppa-ya lambo"]]), ('Chillin’ like a villain, yeah, ra-ra-ra', [["“Chillin' like a villain” the word “chilling” refers to the concept of cold or frozen; with this, we return to the comic-themed references, as happened in their previous single, “How You Like That”, with:

Look up in the sky
It’s a bird, it’s a plane

With reference to Superman.

But this time around, it could be referring to Batman’s icy villain, Mr. Freeze. Keeping with the cold theme, Lisa compares her personality and her climatic environment as depicted in the music video to the calm snow cold nature of villains.

It could also be a reference to the 2017 song “Chillin' Like a Villain” for the Descendants 2 soundtrack.   Aside from the full track talking about cold ice cream, it’s related too."]]), ('Play the part like Moses, keep it fresh like roses (Oh)', [['Moses parted the Red Sea for anyone not familiar with that story. So basically… I’m gonna need you to top that if you’re my man. That is the standard. If you can’t part a sea… then you can’t party with me. “Keep it fresh like roses” has two meanings in a way. Like obviously roses are known for smelling fresh but also keep things fresh between us and don’t get boring, buy me roses, surprise me. All that.']]), ('Get it, flip it, scoop it, do it like that, oh yeah, oh yeah
 Like it, love it, lick it, do it like la-la-la, oh yeah', [['An ode to Cold Stone Creamery sizing. They also “flip it and scoop” candies into the ice cream.']]), ('Ice on my wrist, yeah, I like it like this
 Get the bag with the cream', [['Stay getting money!!']]), ('[Verse 3: Lisa]', [['This song noticeably has a lot more English in it than prior releases. Blackpink songs are usually written in English before being translated, so it worked out that this time with the Selena feature and it being aimed more for the American market, that extra translation wasn’t required. A great opportunity for the girls to show their talent and growth especially in language. I wrote the majority of Lisa’s rap verse in Korea and then Teddy added some spicy Korean lines to it to seal the deal. In the future, they’re going to continue to keep incorporating more English in their lyrics, where it makes sense.']]), ('Keep it movin’ like my lease up
 Think you fly, boy, where your visa?
 Mona Lisa kinda Lisa
 Needs an ice cream man that treats her
 Keep it movin’ like my lease up
 Think you fly, boy, where your visa?
 Mona Lisa kinda Lisa
 Needs an ice cream man that treats her (Hey)', [['When I wrote that [Mona Lisa] line I loved it and really hoped Lisa would too and I’m so glad she did. I think it speaks specifically to her originality and uniqueness but also as a fan singing it to yourself just feeling like you are a work of art and need a man that sees that and treats you that way. Even if your name isn’t Lisa you are your own Mona Lisa. There will never be another. I think it’s important women view themselves in that way.']]), ('I know that my heart can be so cold
 But I’m sweet for you, come put me in a cone (In a cone)', [['Teddy wrote the main melody for this while I was in Korea. I ended up writing the lyrics over that melody. It’s a play on the main theme of the song, how different this person is from everybody else. As with everything, we were trying to be intentional with our songwriting in relating everything back to the song title.']]), ('Look so good, yeah, look so sweet (Hey)
 Lookin’ good enough to eat', [['I wrote this line to show off the vocal range of the girls and kind of have that climax note. As much as I love having songs that are cool and swaggy, I also love songs that just make you want to sing-scream the lyrics while you pretend you’re shooting a music video in your car or bathroom.']])]

genius_description:
“작은 것들을 위한 시 (Boy With Luv)” is the lead single from BTS' 2019 album Map of the Soul: Persona featuring American artist Halsey, who has been a fan of the group since 2017. The pop anthem recalls how love is one of the strongest forces for someone to have.

Halsey hinted the collaboration back in November of 2018 by saying the following:

I think we both have this conceptual thing that we really like to do so it can be cool to find some kind of like bridge, like that you know it’s really great for their mo and my ma that it kind of like signify the whole thing together.

Its English title is reminiscent of their 2014 hit “상남 (Boy in Luv)” similar to how the intro song for Map of the Soul: Persona, “Persona,” is reminiscent of their 2014 intro song  “Intro: Skool Luv Affair.” Both are throwbacks to BTS’s Skool Luv Affair era, and both indicate growth from that time.

The translation of its Korean title, “A Poem for Small Things,” hints toward the emotional message of the album.
genius_annotations:
[('때론 도망치게 해달라며 기도했어', [['Sometimes I prayed, let me run away

RM tells the listener that, at times, he felt a desire to escape, this escape probably being from his life as an idol.

This is likely due to the various pressures created by constantly being in the spotlight, as the members of BTS would be. The members are perpetually subject to hate, criticism and unnecessary remarks, and must constantly meet the expectations enforced on them by the public in order to fulfil an “idol” image.']]), ('높아버린 sky, 커져버린 hall', [['Elevated sky, expanded halls

The “elevated sky, expanded halls” that RM speaks of refers to the high ceiling and wide space provided by a concert arena.



It is possible the sense of importance afforded by the volume of such venues contributed to RM being “a little stuck up” as he admits in the previous lines.']]), ('You got me high so fast', [['Colloquially, the word “high” is often used to describe a feeling of euphoria, and is said to be “often caused by a feeling of success”.

BTS may be continuing to address ARMYs, telling them that it is thanks to them that BTS are high on the success they have achieved.']]), ('난 내 눈에 널 맞추고 싶어', [['I want you tuned in to my eyes/I want to be on eye level with you

This may imply that though their accrual of wealth and fame may indicate otherwise, BTS don’t wish to be above ARMYs, namely wanting to be on the same level as their fans.']]), ('이제 여긴 너무 높아', [["Now it’s so high up here

In the years closely preceding the release of “Boy With Luv”, BTS' fame has reached new heights—to the point that their rise to success has been described by numerous news source as “world domination”."]]), ('다 말하지 너무 작던 내가 영웅이 된 거라고 (Oh no)', [['Everyone says that I used to be so little and now I became a hero (Oh no)

j-hope challenges the concept that by having helped so many people through their music, the messages they convey through said music and even their use of social media, BTS are heroes.

Themes of heroism and all it entails are prevalent in the lyrics of several BTS songs, particularly in the form of self-comparison with Anpanman, a Japanese cartoon character who has no superpowers but is made of red bean bread, and chooses to offer pieces of himself to those in need:

I don’t have biceps or pecs
I don’t have a super car like Batman
The ideal hero is my fantasy
But all I can give you is Anpan
I’ve dreamed of becoming a hero like Superman
I ran with all my strength, jumping high up in the sky
I’m not afraid of little things like bruising my knees
A innocent fantasy of my childhood



“Anpanman”, j-hope, 2018





However, in “Boy With Luv”, j-hope counters this idea. He does not consider their deeds to have made such a great contribution to humanity that they warrant him being labelled a hero. Rather, j-hope is content with simply bringing happiness, peace and strength to those who need it.

If I
Someone’s strength
Someone’s light
I wish I could be a
Piece of peace



“P.O.P (Piece of Peace) pt.1”, j-hope, 2018']]), ('네 전부를 함께하고 싶어', [["I want to be with you for everything

Jungkook expresses his appreciation of ARMYs and their companionship. BTS' fans have been with the group despite numerous struggles, such as claims BTS members did not fit the standards of idol beauty, rumours that BTS' company, BigHit Entertainment, had bought their own group’s albums to boost official numbers, and accusations of BTS plagiarising their better-known seniors.

For that, Jungkook is grateful, and he conveys this by telling ARMYs he “[wants] to be with [them] for everything”, just as they were for him and his members."]]), ('I’ve waited all my life', [["BTS sing that they have “waited all [their] life”, perhaps to be able to connect to a fanbase and share messages of not only sociopolitical criticism, but comfort and hope.

BTS' fanbase was initially small and their music of poor visibility, but in 2019 their fanbase is vast enough that they are able to communicate “the things that someone needed to say, but that no one did”, as Suga said in a 2018 interview."]]), ('Your one, your two', [["Though at a glance these numerically based phrases may seem similar, individually they have subtly different connotations.

“The one” is a phrase used to refer to the destined life partner of any given individual.

Meanwhile, one’s “number two” refers to a person’s second-in-command, and can be compared in this way to the phrase “right-hand man”.



By deeming himself “your one, your two”, Jin designates himself as both ARMYs' life partner and their second-in-command. Thus, he indicates the relationship between himself and ARMYs as mutual in a way that might not be as evident if he had deigned to sing, “my one, my two”."]]), ('Come be my teacher
 네 모든 걸 다 가르쳐줘', [["Come be my teacher
Teach me everything about you

Jin continues to address ARMYs as Jimin and V have in previous lines. In a similar vein to Jimin, who remarks that he is “curious about everything”, Jin expresses an intrigue in “everything about you”, namely ARMYs.

Jin wishes for ARMYs to communicate to him this information so he can familarize himself with them on a level more personal than that of a typical celebrity-fan relationship. He seeks to learn even seemingly insignificant details, or “every little trivial habit of [ARMYs']” as Suga raps later on in the song."]])]

Halsey sings about a moment but i think that first chorus doesnt say that', 'They’re always be my inspiration', 'i love the song', 'In the album version Halsey sings more I think.', 'I love this song!!!!']

genius_description:
Backed by synths and a simple repetitive instrumental, the song details the desire to better the world and improve relationships.

The title seems to recount Jin’s monologue from 2017 Love Yourself Highlight Reel ‘起承轉結’:

If we could turn back the clock, where should we go back to? Once we reach that place, can all our mistakes and errors be undone? Will happiness be ours forever?
genius_annotations:
[('끝도 보이지 않던 영원의 밤
 내게 아침을 선물한 건 너야', [['“Make It Right” seems to follow the narrative of Bangtan’s ongoing storyline, specifically the one recreated with their 2019 Save Me Webtoon.

In this universe they’ve created, Seokjin repeatedly wakes up on the same day, April 11, to attempt to save his friends from their fates. From committing suicide in the short film Euphoria : Theme of LOVE YOURSELF 起 Wonder to murder in the “I Need U” music video, the members are all haunted by their fates. After every failed attempt, Seokjin reawakes to the same morning and has yet to find a way to save those he cares about.']]), ('사막과 바다들을 건너
 넓고 넓은 세계를', [["This line is reminiscent of BTS' 2017 hidden track “바다 (Sea),” a song that identifies failure as the desert and success as the sea. The song speculates that, perhaps, the two are the same:

Ocean, desert, the world
Everything, the same thing
Different name
I see ocean, l see desert
I see the world
Everything’s, the same thing
With a different name
It’s life again

By referencing these metaphors they first created in 2017, BTS express how, regardless of the success and failure they face, they will continue to travel the world and its endless deserts and seas if it means finding a place to belong."]])]
