genius_description:
On “South of the Border,” the artists implore their significant others to leave the United States and go on a romantic trip with them.

Both Cardi B and Camila have Latino lineage. In a 2017 article, PopSugar.com broke down Camila’s Cuban background. She spoke Spanish as her primary language for years before learning English.

While Camila has an unreleased 2018 track co-written by Ed Sheeran, this song marks the first collaboration between any of the featured artists.
genius_annotations:
[('He want the lil’ mamacita, margarita (Margarita)', [['Mamacita is the Spanish word for “mommy”, reflecting the Latin theme of the track. It’s used in a sexual context, as opposed to a literal mother (mamá or mamita).

According to cocktail historian David Wondrich, margaritas are related to a popular Mexican drink called the Daisy (margarita is Spanish for “daisy”), which is made with brandy instead of tequila. Daisy cocktails became popular during Prohibition as people drifted over the border (ooh, that sounds familiar!) for alcohol.']]), ('You want the lips and the curves, need the whips and the furs
 And the diamonds I prefer, in my closet, his and hers, ayy', [['In contrast to Camila, who’s looking for a more casual encounter with the man, Cardi’s after a more substantial relationship, but only if he can fund her expensive tastes.

That seems to reflect aspects of Cardi’s personal life, as she was scratching a living as a stripper before her hip hop career kicked off. It’s an occupation she speaks candidly about – how it empowered her to fund her education and music career.

Because of this, Cardi hasn’t always been taken seriously when it comes to her interest in politics and history.']]), ('Jump in that water, be free
 Come south of the border with me
 Jump in that water, be free
 Come south of the border with me', [['“The border” in this case is the U.S.-Mexico border, which is nearly 2,000 miles long (1,954 miles to be precise) and stretches from California to Texas; whilst “that water” is the body of water which stretches along the border from the Pacific Ocean to the Gulf of Mexico.



And South of the border, you’ll find Latin America and the Caribbean.



Camila and Cardi are both Latina and come from Spanish-speaking, Caribbean backgrounds. Camila was born in Havana, the capital city of Cuba, to a Cuban mother and a Mexican father – and she still holds Cuban citizenship to this day.



Cardi’s father, meanwhile, is originally from the Dominican Republic, and her mother is from Trinidad and Tobago.

https://twitter.com/iamcardib/status/723232018004361217']]), ('“Te amo, mami, ah, te amo, mami”', [['The English translation is:

I love you, mama, ah, I love you, mama

“Mami” is a term of endearment that can be used in a romantic manner.']]), ('A little crazy, but I’m just your type (Okurrr)', [['Cardi mentioned her “crazy” side on Maroon 5’s May 2018 remix of “Girls Like You”:

You don’t want a girl like me, I’m too crazy

Interestingly, she tried to trademark the term “Okurrr” in March 2019, and the application was rejected in July.']]), ('Kiss me like you need me, rub me like a genie', [['A genie is a mythological being that is fabled to emerge from a lamp whenever someone rubs it. Legend has it that they are able to grant wishes.

Coincidentally, Camila’s 2017 single, “Crying in the Club,” interpolates Christina Aguilera’s 1999 breakout hit, “Genie in a Bottle,” which revolves around the concept of being “rubbed the right way.”']]), ('In a green field near Buenos Aires', [['Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina—one of the southernmost countries in South America. Ed performed in Buenos Aires in February 2019.

In March 2018, Camila visited the country to perform at Lollapalooza and confessed in a tweet that she was “obsessed” with the country.']]), ('I think that Ed got a lil’ jungle fever, ayy (Woo!)', [['“Jungle fever” is a slang term originally applied to Caucasian women who’re attracted to black men. The phrase has evolved to mean Caucasian men and women who’re attracted to people of color, in general. The phrase was popularized in the 1991 Spike Lee film, Jungle Fever, which chronicled an interracial relationship between a married black man and his Italian secretary.



While Cardi may be implying that Ed is attracted to her—a similar claim which she made toward G-Eazy on his September 2017 track “No Limit”—Ed has been happily married to his high school sweetheart Cherry Seaborn since December 2018, and Cardi has also been married to Migos‘ Offset since September 2017.']]), ('Ven para acá, quiero bailar, toma mi mano
 Quiero sentir tu cuerpo en mí, estás temblando', [['The English translation is:

Come over here, I wanna dance, take my hand
I wanna feel your body on me, you’re trembling']]), ('Legs open, tongue out, Michael Jordan, uh (Uh)', [['Michael Jordan is arguably the greatest basketball player of all time. He is known for sticking his tongue out while playing.



Cardi applies this to a woman receiving oral sex.

Camila also name-dropped Michael Jordan on her August 2017 single, “OMG”:

Jordan, twenty-three
Guarantee you’re gonna wanna leave with me']])]

genius_description:
“Beautiful People” is the third promotional single from Ed Sheeran’s No.6 Collaborations Project. The track is about remaining true to yourself and not trying to become one of those so-called “beautiful people” obsessed with material things and stature.

It opens with pretty vocal harmonies: “We are, we are, we are” floats over a winsome melody and handclap-enhanced rhythms. Sheeran and Khalid each sing a verse about uncomfortable social situations, where a person can feel “surrounded but still alone.” “We don’t fit in well/We are just ourselves."

Sheeran shared a short clip via Instagram on June 27, 2019, letting fans know that the video will drop at 3 a.m. ET Friday, three hours after the song’s midnight release.
genius_annotations:
[('Champagne and rolled-up notes
 Prenups and broken homes', [['These lyrics see Sheeran contrasting glamour and pleasure with darker, more emotional themes.

Snorting drugs through the nose with “rolled-up banknotes” is an age-old tradition that has long been associated with casual drug use.
The most commonly nasally ingested substance is cocaine, which is also considered to be a “rich man’s drug” due to it’s expense and popularity among wealthy people.

Another symbol of status and opulence is drinking alcohol in the shape of Champagne; a sparkling wine named after the region of its production in France.

  


A prenuptial agreement or just “prenup” is a contract agreed by two people before they enter into a marriage or civil partnership. Its purpose is to set out what would happen to each party’s finances in the event of relationship breakdown or divorce.

“Broken home” is a name given to mean a family in which the parents are separated or divorced.']])]

genius_description:
On “No Regrets,” Eminem teams up with rising star Don Toliver, on a smooth, melodic track. On the track, Em revisits his troubled past and difficult come-up, while also coming to the realization that “he wouldn’t change [anything]” if he could go back and do everything over again, while Don delivers the track’s emotional chorus, which serves as an introspective look into their own origins and the way they impact their loved ones.

Em also addresses some of his more recent and prevalent beefs over the past few years, calling out rappers such as Nick Cannon, Machine Gun Kelly and Tyler, The Creator. Don addresses his sadness in being alone, but still is trying very hard not to have any regrets.

The song’s production is handled by D.A. Doman, whose hard-hitting instrumental highlights Em’s transition to a more modern trap style. This marks Doman’s third production credit on Music to Be Murdered By, following “Those Kinda Nights” and “Godzilla.”
genius_annotations:
[('I been on the bench
 Forgive and forget is the only thing I’d ever live to regret
 Hell-bent on revenge, you left me for dead
 I crawled out my grave, you better be ready and set
 My enemies ain’t put an end to me yet', [['The audience turned away from Eminem several times.


When he released the infamous Encore album in 2004, which was received coldly by critics and fans alike. The quality of the lyrics has dropped significantly compared to the two previous classic albums: The Marshall Mathers LP and The Eminem Show. The reason for the deterioration of the lyrics was Marshall’s drug addiction. Later, in 2008, he will recover from it.
When he released his second infamous album Revival in 2017. In particular, the Pitchfork edition noted the tastelessness of the choruses on the album, the lines, some of which are embarrassing, and also mentioned the fact that this album plays almost no role in Eminem’s legacy.



But Eminem was not and is not going to give up. After an unsuccessful return to the stage in 2009, along with Relapse, Marshall released his seventh album, Recovery, which was well received. And after the release of Revival, Eminem fired back with Kamikaze album, which sold 434,000 copies in the first week, and this is given the fact that there was no advertising campaign before the release of the album.



Eminem posted this picture on his Instagram

Nothing can stop him.




Also noteworthy that there is even to these days the theory Eminem has died from 2005 to 2007 in a car crash and was replaced by a clone. So the line about leaving him for dead may be taken literally. Eminem has mentioned that on an unreleased track Fly Away that was recorded for the Recovery album but it didn’t make to it.

Eminem “crawled out his grave” in 2007 after he overdosed when he was 2 hours from dying and doctors gave up on him saying that his liver and kidneys are shut down. More about his 2007 overdose Eminem vented on Arose of his ninth studio album Revival.']]), ('D.A. got that dope', [['“D.A. got that dope” is the catchy, well-recognized producer tag of “D.A. Doman,” a songwriter, producer and publisher of hip-hop music from Chicago. He’s best known for his production efforts on Tyga’s 2018 hit, “Taste,” and Kodak Black’s collaboration with Travis Scott and Offset, “ZEZE.”

D.A. worked with Em three times on Music to Be Murdered By, also producing “Those Kinda Nights” and “Godzilla.”']]), ('Misplacin’ my anger enough to give Earl and Tyler, The Creator the brunt (Yeah)
 Shoulda never made a response, shoulda just aimed for the fake ones
 Them traitorous punks, ’cause snakes are just cunts
 They can get fucked with eight hundred motherfuckin’ vibrators at once (Yeah)', [["On his August 2018 album Kamikaze, Em drew scrutiny from the media for a derogatory lyric on “Fall” that attacked Tyler, the Creator’s sexuality:

Tyler create nothin', I see why you called yourself a [censored], bitch
It’s not just ‘cause you lack attention
It’s because you worship D12’s balls, you’re sack-religious
If you’re gonna critique me
You better at least be as good or better

On September 13, 2018, Em discussed his line about Tyler during an interview with Sway, where he admitted that “the word that I called him on that song was one of the things where I felt like this might be too far; because in my quest to hurt him, I realize that I was hurting a lot of other people by saying it.”

He also took shots at Earl Sweatshirt on “Fall,” where he intentionally messed up Earl’s name:

Get Earl the Hooded Sweater
Whatever his name is to help you put together
Some words, more than just two letters"]]), ('I had to go see the doc like Kool Moe Dee (Yeah)
 Never took much to convince Dre
 Never been swayed by color or skin shades', [['Eminem sheds light on his friendship and professional relationship with his mentor and long-time producer Dr. Dre. Dre discovered Eminem in the late ‘90s and would help his career take off, producing tracks on his albums beginning with 1999’s The Slim Shady LP.

Since the start of Eminem’s career, he has received criticism for taking advantage of a historically African-American art form and becoming extremely successful. However, Dre has never judged Em for his ethnicity.



Note the wordplay with “swayed” and “shades”. Eminem gives a shout-out to Sway Calloway, who hosts a show on Em’s hip-hop radio station Shade 45.

Going to “see the doctor” refers to getting help from Dr. Dre and this is not the first time this expression has been used, and is notably focused on in Dre’s 2011 track “I Need a Doctor,” which also features Eminem.

Additionally, Em gives a shoutout to 1980s rap pioneer Kool Moe Dee and his gonorrhoea-themed 1986 song “Go See the Doctor.” He also gave Dee a shoutout on his verse from another track on this record, “Yah Yah.”']]), ('Slim Sha— mind’s in the gutter, but insane
 Pen game like I just struck in the tenth frame (Screamin’ out no regrets)', [["Em uses the homophones “pen” and “pin” for wordplay about bowling. The “tenth frame” is the last frame of a bowling game, while “gutters” are the  trenches located on either side of the lane. Additionally, “pin” is a callback to Hellraiser four lines earlier.

Em used wordplay on bowling before on his 2014 track “Die Alone”:

Useless, rather pick up the phone, not at all, followin' protocol
I get bold like bowling balls
Grow balls and go to call to talk, forget what I want to say"]]), ('All the hate, can’t tell exactly where it stems from
 But it’s happening again, huh?
 Y’all used to be in my corner
 Now you just backed me in one
 Innocent bystanders, I’m bound to hit some', [['He seems to face a mountain of criticism and hate from everywhere, which he deems unfair and undeserving.

Despite controversies, Eminem used to be considered one of the greatest artists of all time. That opinion isn’t as wildly held anymore, and media that used to adore him, has now turned on him.

When he talks about innocent bystanders, he’s talking about when he lashes back at critics of his, he tends to also hit people who are only guilty by association.']]), ('Yeah, they miss the old me
 I think they want me to OD on codeine
 They want my life in turmoil like in ’03
 They want front row seats, I give ’em nosebleeds', [['When people say they miss the old Eminem, they are talking about a point in time when his life was falling apart. He was an addict, dealing with controversy around his ex wife, and was facing legal trouble regarding him pistol whipping a bouncer.

People want to know every intimate detail about his life. Instead, he remains private and doesn’t reveal as much detail as he used to about his personal issues. “Nosebleeds” refers to cheaper seats very high up in a stadium or theater, the opposite of the “front row”. In the literal sense, he says he will give his critics a bloody nose.']]), ('And for any of those who may have come close to about dyin’
 And can’t listen to “Arose” without cryin’', [["Referring to Arose, the final track of Eminem’s 2017 album, Revival. The song is an emotional one, being about Eminem’s near-death in 2007 due to a pill overdose. He raps about his family, friends and career in his dying moments before the song switches to an alternate ending of the previous track, Castle, where he dumps his pills down the toilet, rather than taking them and overdosing.

He is also talking about how his music is said to have kept people alive in suicidal moments. He talks about this in “Sing for the Moment” with the lyrics:

Or for anyone who’s ever been through shit in they lives
So they sit and they cry at night, wishin' they’d die
‘Til they throw on a rap record and they sit and they vibe

He knows how powerful his music is and how many people he’s helped, and for that, he would go through all the pain in his life again instead of changing anything, he literally has no regrets."]]), ('But sometimes it’s like dropping’ an anvil on a house of cards
 Or Godzilla squashin’ a crouton with combat boots on
 Or droppin’ a goddamn nuke bomb on top of an anthill', [["Eminem uses three similes to show the extent he’s willing to go to obliterate his adversaries and overproportionalize their affronts. These lines may sound familiar to the faint ear, as Eminem made a similar comparison on September 2018’s “Killshot,” his response to Machine Gun Kelly’s diss “RAP DEVIL”:

But you’re a fuckin' mole hill
Now I'ma make a mountain out of you, woo!

The producer of “No Regrets,” D.A. Doman, also produced fellow Music To Be Murdered By track “Godzilla,” to which Eminem alludes in these lines."]]), ('For some adversaries, I carry big guns
 So some targets’ll get the kill shot
 Some, I just barely nicked ’em', [["“Big guns” and “kill shot” refer to Eminem’s widely publicized conflict with Machine Gun Kelly, while “Nicked ‘em” is a word play on Nick Cannon’s name, whose diss tracks Eminem mostly ignored. “Carry” likely alludes to Cannon’s ex-wife, Mariah Carey.

Eminem began feuding with MGK after he called Em’s then 16-year-old daughter “hot as fuck” in 2012. Em discussed the incident and his distaste for MGK on his 2018 surprise album Kamikaze, particularly on “Not Alike”:

You already know who the fuck you are, Kelly
I don’t use sublims and sure as fuck don’t sneak-diss
But keep commenting on my daughter Hailie

MGK responded with “RAP DEVIL,” and Em ended the series of diss tracks with “Killshot.” MGK alluded to the song on July 2019’s “Floor 13”.

Shortly after concluding his conflict with MGK, Em got involved in a feud with Nick Cannon. Cannon wrote “The Invitation” as a diss track, which received very poor reviews, and he released “Used to Look Up To You” just days before Music to Be Murdered By came out.

Cannon spoke about Em’s three daughters on “The Invitation,” focusing on his adopted daughters, Whitney and Alaina:

Call Kim, somebody get Hailie
And that other kid you raisin', that ain’t even your baby (Daddy)

Cannon elaborated on the line on Instagram:"]])]

genius_description:
“Lucky You” marks the first collaboration between Eminem and Joyner Lucas, whom people have pointed out, shares many characteristics with Em in terms of rhyme and flow.

Their verses are polar opposites, a thematic structure often employed by Joyner in his songs to show opposing perspectives of the same topic (see “Ross Capicchioni” and “I’m Not Racist”).

Here, Joyner comments on how he hasn’t received any awards, although he is steadily gaining recognition. For instance, the video for his song “I’m Not Racist” went viral in 2017.

Em’s verse, on the other hand, is about how he’s at the top in terms of awards and status but is being overlooked in the current rap scene. This is a recurring theme throughout this album as well as other 2018 releases, such as the remix of “Chloraseptic.”
genius_annotations:
[('Man, I used to risk it all, now I got too much to lose', [['This line refers to how in the beginning of Eminem’s career he was careless of what he said. He was known and criticised for using words like “fagg*t,”
Now in the later stages of his career he has gained an amazing legacy and respect that he can’t affford to lose.']]), ('When I die I’m goin’ out as the underdog who never lost hope', [['Joyner has been professionally rapping since 2011, but he only began attaining mainstream success in late 2017 with the contemplative music video for “I’m Not Racist,” as well as his remixes of “Gucci Gang” and “Bank Account.”

Joyner considers himself to be an underdog, which can be best defined as a competitor thought to have little chance of winning.']]), ('The inability to pen humility', [['A large percentage of hip-hop artists only write songs bragging about themselves. Em is pointing out that these artists are unable to write about anything personal. They all just stick to a script.']]), ('I done said a lotta things in my day, I admit it
 This is payback in a way, I regret it that I did it', [['Em’s entire career has been marked by controversy. For instance the LGBT community demonstrated against him, for his usage of the word “faggot”, in songs like “Marshall Mathers” and “Criminal.”

He also made fun of a lot of celebrities. For instance,  Em parodied Michael Jackson, and referenced his child molestation case on “Just Lose It.” Jackson threatened to sue him over the incident, which Paul told Em about on his Encore skit.']]), ('“We’re on the upswing like we’re punchin’ the ceiling!”', [['This is a double entendre with “Upswing”, as in the general meaning: “On an upward trend”, and as in punching upwards, as if to punch the ceiling.']]), ('Back on my bullshit, my back to the wall', [['This line gets a nod from Em at the end of his verse later in this song:

That they say as a writer might’ve fell off
I’m back on that bull like the cowboy']]), ('And actually comin’ from humble beginnings', [["Em had a challenging childhood, being raised by his single mother, after his father abandoned the household when he was a baby. His mother, Debbie, struggled to keep a job, which resulted in the two constantly moving around.

He was bullied by neighbourhood kids, and class mates, due to him constantly being the “new kid”, and because he stood out in predominantly African American areas. His mother was addicted to prescription pills, leaving Em to care for himself. He has detailed his childhood on songs such as “My Mom, “Cleanin' Out My Closet”, and “Headlights.”"]]), ('I’ve been eatin’ long enough, man, my stomach should be full', [["In the first bridge Joyner Lucas states:

“Y'all been eatin' long enough, it’s my turn to cut the food”

This verse is the exact opposite, as Eminem contrasts his statement by saying he has had enough opportunities and career advancements, but he’s still not satisfied."]]), ('Back to these bullets, it’s back to the job
 Pull my MAC out and all of you runnin’', [['MAC stands for Military Armament Corporation, a defunct firearms manufacturer known for making rapid fire machine pistols. The most popular models are the MAC-10 and MAC-11.

https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/856096476631514848/273426EDD16D7014C7E9C4731C436C88342A3A2D/']]), ('I’m that cracker, bend the law, fuck the rules', [['Eminem flips Joyner’s intro line:

I’m that nigga, bend the law, cut the rules

Being one of the very few white rappers to achieve respect in the hip-hop community, he has worked to  gain respect in a genre, dominated by African Americans.']])]

genius_description: On “You Gon' Learn,” Eminem teams up with Royce da 5'9" and White Gold to stress the importance of resilience and determination. Royce and Em present themselves as products of survival despite the calamitous trials and tribulations they’ve been confronted with, while acknowledging the demons they’ve battled on their respective journeys to stardom.
genius_annotations:
[('Never sold dope for no gold rope
 Wanted one though, they were so dope (Yeah)', [['Em is referring to the gold rope chain worn by the multi-platinum rapper LL Cool J, as seen on the cover for Bigger and Deffer.



Em went on to mention the same chain in a Paramount+ clip posted July of 2021, where he revealed Cool J actually gifted him a chain inspired by the same ones Cool J wore in the I’m Bad music video.

The first time we saw Em rock the gold ropes was in 2017, during the BET Hip Hop Awards Freestyle Cypher']]), ('Singin’ fuck all of you in Autotune', [["Auto-tune is an audio processor that was made in 1997. It uses a proprietary device to measure and alter pitch in voice. It makes your voice sounds better than it actually is and can also make cool effects. Eminem has said bad things about autotune many times. This is a line from Eminem’s song “The Ringer” the first song on Eminem’s “Kamikaze” album.

“But yall' are acting like I
tried to serve you up a slider
Maybe the vocals should have been auto-tuned
Then you would have bought it”

This is also from the “Killshot” diss against Machine Gun Kelly

“Im sick of you being whack
And your'e still using that motherfucking auto-tune
So lets talk about it”"]]), ('As I got a little bit older, my hate
 Was making me get cold, and began to get a chipped shoulder
 Started to spit vulgar,', [['Em’s past experiences as a child, detailed in this song, gave him a cold, bitter and angry attitude which he would eventually unleash in his music – like on The Marshall Mathers LP.

A person donning this behaviour would be labelled as having a chip on their shoulder. Literally speaking, however, exposing human skin to cold temperatures continuously can eventually lead to it drying out and cracking or chipping.']]), ('Targettin’ my kids and babies through population and gun control
 Shit make me wanna make a hunnid more
 Make a bigot racist uncomfortable', [['Royce takes aim at racial discrimination in America, specifically in the field of medicine where he believes black people receive a neglectful level of healthcare by medicinal practices in their attempt to control the ever-growing population.

These alleged acts, however, only serve as a prompt for Royce to father a hunnid [a hundred] more children.

A HUNNID is a song by North Carolina rapper, Stunna 4 Vegas. Coincidently, both Stunna’s track and Music to Be Murdered By were released on the same day – January 17th 2020.']]), ('I’m walkin’ across a suicidal tightrope intentionally', [['An analogy Royce uses to describe his state of mind during his past years of alcoholism.

The tightrope represents the narrow and unstable path he knowingly forced himself down when choosing to drink. Whilst on this path, falling off the tightrope (an almost inevitable outcome) portrays Royce’s belief that his suicide would have been the final outcome.']]), ('I’ll get to doing what a leaky faucet do
 But I ain’t talkin’ drip when I say that I’ll get the drop on you', [['Both “drip” and “drop” are connected to a “leaky faucet”. “Drip” is also a slang term similar in meaning to “swag”.

“To get the drop on someone” means to catch someone in a vulnerable position or situation,  especially when you are competing over some outcome.']]), ('Better haul ass, don’t be no slow poke (Nope)
 Through the tall grass, run your ass off (Yeah)', [['While talking about his childhood, Eminem includes references to Pokémon video games. Slowpoke is one of the original Pokémon. A character would encounter wild Pokémon while walking through tall grass. Nintendo, a co-founder of the franchise, is mentioned later in the same verse.']]), ('Right there since ’9-6, worse nightmare to side chicks, some things are just meant to be', [['Royce da 5'9" started dating his future wife around 1995:

I met my wife in Oak Park High School; we had Spanish class together. She was in the 10th grade and I was in the 9th grade. We didn’t become a couple until around 1995, when I was supposed to graduate.']]), ('While the demons comin’ out of me
 Wifey’s on the side of me talkin’ sense into me
 Without she, I feel incomplete mentally, she’s been sent to me', [["“While the demons comin' out of me” means that the feelings of anger, negativity and any other negative emotions are coming out. Comparing his emotions to a demon sets up the next lines.

Angels are the opposition of demons in some religions that are sent from God.
He is not saying that his partner/wife is an angel but he’s alluding to it. This is setting her up as a shoulder angel, a plot device used for dramatic and/or humorous effect in fiction, mainly in animation and comic books/strips. The angel represents conscience and is often accompanied by a shoulder devil representing temptation. They are a useful convention for depicting the inner conflict of a character.



Royce’s wife has been sent to him like an angel because she can talk sense into him, therefore, neutralizing the negative angry emotions coming out of him and tempt him to act out, which of course Royce is referring to as demons. (Fighting demons is typical action that angels do)."]]), ('Was a have-not (Yeah) ’cause my pockets (Uh)
 Didn’t have knots, I was so broke', [['Here Eminem creatively describes his lack of wealth growing up. He was a “have not,” someone without access to sufficient financial resources.

Em then uses the homophone “knot” to refer to a wad of cash wrapped in a rubber band, often carried by drug dealers and others forced to limit their business to the cash economy.']])]

genius_description: On “Leaving Heaven,” Eminem reflects on his success and what turned him into the man he is today. Accompanied by a soulful chorus by Skylar Grey, Eminem raps of his extreme resilience after being thrown “in the deep end” by the cards life dealt him, over a triumphant beat with intense drums. He also talks about his father who abandoned him when Em was a toddler. His father passed away on June 26, 2019.
genius_annotations:
[('But I get it, how it feels to be judged by pigment
 Besides getting it from both sides of the tracks', [['The tracks literally refer to train tracks that went through 8 mile implying that his friends lived on both sides of the nearby tracks as well as the common phrase meant to depict a demarcation between the poor and rich areas of a city. In this context it refers to either side of the racial divide as he got hostility from the black and white community when initially attempting to make it as a rapper.']]), ('Now the sky’s nothing but black', [['The sky above has literally turned the color black since there is a pile of toy soldiers so high that Marshall is now in space on his way to “rise up” to heaven before leaving at the end of the song. Also used as a double entendre to reference Black Lives Matter in relation to woke culture in the rest of this verse as well as thematic tie in with the next verse’s racial lyrics.

The word black could also be a triple entendre used as a play on Skylar Grey’s name to say that Skyler’s(shortened to sky) tone as an artist is now darker and black is darker than Grey(gray). She sings the chorus.']]), ('Couple that with the fact my mother was batshit', [['Eminem’s mother, Deborah, suffers from Munchausen Syndrome.

Due to his upbringing, Eminem also believes that his mother has Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy – which he comedically describes in My Mom.']]), ('Only guts you had was from your stomach fat', [['Guts is a common slang term for courage. But having a gut means you have belly fat. Here Em is saying that his dad did not have any courage, but had a lot of belly fat.']]), ('(I wouldn’t have went through half the shit I went through, so I blame you)', [['He is saying that if he had his father in his life everything would change. With a father, having a stable relationship, he wouldn’t be Eminem. We wouldn’t get songs like “Stepdad” or “My Mom”, he may not have been heavy on drugs, he probably wouldn’t even get into rap. Without his father, he went through a heap of shit and it’s all his fault. However, as the next line shows, Eminem is thankful for this because without having a deadbeat dad and bad mother he wouldn’t be Eminem; he would just be Marshall.']]), ('And as long as I’m breathing, I vow to outsmart ’em and beat ’em
 My God, what a heart of a demon, go at ’em and I’ma get even
 Like I’m in the Garden of Eden, I’m ’bout to go off of the deep end
 This evil is calling, I’m already seething and', [["Eminem describes his hatred and his thoughts of getting back at “Malcolm, Isaac, and Boogie” with the devil and the Garden of Eden as its theme.

The Garden of Eden, which is also called Paradise, is the place described in the Hebrew Bible where Adam and Eve lived.

Eminem uses some great wordplay here with Adam and Eve by saying:

go at ‘em and I'ma get even

With “at ‘em” being a homophone of Adam and “even” for Eve

Following the biblical narrative there was a tree in the Garden of Eden called the Tree of the knowledge of good and evil. Adam and Eve were allowed to eat fruits from all trees except for this one. After a serpent (the devil) persuaded them to eat the forbidden fruits, they were expelled from the garden and eternal life there.

Eminem compares his thoughts to those of Adam and Eve when being persuaded by the devil to eat the forbidden fruits by writing how he has “a heart of a demon” and is “about to go off of the deep end” because “The evil is calling” and he is “already seething”.

These devil/hell themed lines also fit well with the rest of the lines in this song such as the intro being
“It’s all going to hell now, man” and the chorus and title saying “I’m leaving heaven”"]]), ('I’ve been down, kicked
 Like around six thousand times since I was a kid
 As a child, picked on, clowned, been
 Countless times I’ve been doubted', [['Em has touched on this topic several times in his career. This can be seen in songs such as “Who Knew” and “Brain Damage.” In the latter em says:

I was harassed daily by this fat kid named DeAngelo Bailey
An eighth grader who acted obnoxious, ‘cause his father boxes
So every day he’d shove me in the lockers
One day he came in the bathroom while I was pissin’
And had me in the position to beat me into submission
He banged my head against the urinal ‘til he broke my nose
Soaked my clothes in blood, grabbed me and choked my throat']]), ('If Denaun and me find a couple dimes a piece', [["Em is talking about Denaun Montez Porter, also known by the stage names Mr. Porter and Kon Artis, is a close friend to Eminem and a D12 member.

He could also be alluding to the intro off “Never 2 Far” from Infinite:

Denaun, what up, man?
What up, dawg?
You all right?
Chillin', cold as hell
Yes, it is. Hey, bus didn’t come here, didn’t he?
No. Hey look, you got 15 cent?
Nah, I got just enough to get on the bus, I’m broke"]]), ('(Or maybe I should say, ”Thank you”)
 (’Cause I wouldn’t have been me, haha)', [["On the 2013 song “Legacy” Eminem acknowledges that his troubled childhood was crucial for his development as a person and as an artist, concluding:

I used to be the type of kid that would always think the sky’s fallin'
Now I think the fact that I’m differently wired’s awesome
‘Cause if I wasn’t, I wouldn’t be able to work words like this
And connect lines like crosswords

He also “thanked” his father on the song “Arose:”

Oh, almost forgot to do something, thank my father too
I actually learned a lot from you
You taught me what not to do"]]), ('Be triumphant ’cause when I’m looking at my legacy (Leg, I see)
 Bunch of dogs tryna dry hump it
 Like Triumph The Puppet, so I’m like, “Fuck it”', [["Eminem is looking at his “Legacy” (homophonous with “leg, I see”) and sees other rappers and people trying to attach themselves to it, like dogs dry hump the legs of people that they like.

The usage of “triumphant” in the first line in combination with the “bunch of dogs” is also a nod to Triumph the Insult Comic Dog, a recurring puppet character from the Conan O'Brien Show, whom Eminem impersonated years ago for his single “Ass Like That.”



Triumph and Em also had a run-in at the 2002 MTV Video Music Awards, when Triumph tried to troll Eminem about his beef with Moby and ended up with his neck in a brace.  Em later admitted that his anger with the puppet was quite real, causing him to throw a violent fit in his dressing room."]])]

genius_description:
On “Unaccommodating,” Eminem enlists Young M.A to discuss their unaccommodating manner, especially towards the media and critics.

The rappers' intense approach is similar to that of Kamikaze, with Eminem name-dropping various modern-day artists, while also bragging of his own superiority by comparing himself to Avengers villain Thanos and radical political leaders.
genius_annotations:
[('We ain’t the same, you and I', [['In recent years, a common theme for Eminem has been to claim his superiority over mumble rappers – and this occasion wouldn’t be the first time he’s dedicated an entire song to prove his point, either: Not Alike.']]), ('And I hit them pads like a boxing gym', [['A double entendre on the word pad.

first he says he hits the pads (writing pads) so hard when writing, means he writes some dope shit.



And he writing on the pads is as hard as he hitting boxing pads in a boxing gym.']]), ('You can leave this earth, bitch, I’m in rake mode', [['A rake is a term used to describe an immoral pleasure-seeker, or in other words, someone who will do anything to get what they want. Of course a rake is also a gardening tool used to snag up leaves fallen from a tree. This gives Young M.A.’s line another meaning when she says, “You can leave this earth, bitch, I’m in rake mode.']]), ('I won’t topple, I’m giving it to anyone who wanna come and get it and I’m not gonna stop', [['Amongst his disses aimed at Machine Gun Kelly, Eminem includes a similar lyric to his 2010 song with Lil Wayne, “No Love”:

‘Til I’m topplin’ from the top, I’m not gonna stop

The lyrics also warns other rappers of the dangers of wanting trouble with Em. As of this song’s release, the last rapper to callout Em was Nick Cannon, who Em brutally responded to on “You Gon' Learn.”

This line could also be a reference to a similar line in “The Ringer” where he says:

I’m ‘bout to bring it to anyone in this bitch who want it"']]), ('I am the complete opposite of these retards who spit these weak bars, I’ma leave carnage', [['This could be a callback to Eminem’s song “Venom” from the film of the same name. In the comics, Carnage is kind of the opposite of Venom but the same in regards of powers.']]), ('Look at how I’m behaving, they want me gone away', [['In the context of the previous lines, which name-drop infamous enemies of the United States who are all now dead, two killed by US forces or proxies, it is likely Em is framing himself as a pariah who is also a target for the mainstream establishment’s retribution here.']]), ('But it seems like the more they studied my music, the more they remind me of eyeballs
 I’m watching my pupils get cornier (Uh)', [['Em uses the homophones “cornia” and “cornier” and homonyms “pupil” and “pupil” to craft an unlikely analogy between rappers he’s influenced and ocular anatomy.

In the eye, the pupil is the black opening in the center of the iris that expands and contracts to let in an appropriate amount of light.  It is covered by the transparent cornea, which refracts the light and protects the eye’s internal structure.

https://www.aao.org/image.axd?id=f8bf1127-6e24-4493-a428-16137daff804&t=636179207925430000

In another sense, a pupil is a student.  Em feels that those who strive to learn from him and follow in his footsteps are falling short and becoming corny, in the sense of being banal, trite, or laughably amateurish.  Considering the previous lines addressing Machine Gun Kelly, it’s clear Em places him in this category.']]), ('And I made a mil’ without a major deal (I made that)', [['Although she is now a member of Forbes 30 under 30, Young M.A made her first recordings in a self-funded recording studio with local producers while working at Shake Shack and T.J. Maxx.  She has since operated independently of any major label.



Young M.A in a tweeted pic from her retail era.']]), ('I’m about to relapse and I betcha that you won’t know how to react
 But a look of disgust, I don’t doubt it’d be that', [["Eminem comments on the critical reviews of his sixth studio album, Relapse. Em’s opinion regarding his critics has become a prevalent theme in his discography, a notable example being on his 2018 track “Fall:”

You know, everybody’s been tellin' me
What they think about me for the last few months
Maybe it’s time I tell ‘em what I think about them.

This line may also refer to his personal battle with drug addiction. The rapper relapsed several times in his difficult journey of sobering up.

The line may be a subliminal response to Nick Cannon’s track “The Invitation,” where Nick says

Pills and smack, Shady ‘bout to relapse"]]), ('And you’re from the school of Notorious, Puba, Cube and The Poor Righteous Teachers tutored my students
 Showed them all the blueprint and formula', [['Using school as a metaphor, Eminem references classic hip hop artists and records that modern rappers learned from: Poor Righteous Teachers were a group formed in 1989, “blueprint” refers to JAY-Z’s seminal album, The Blueprint, and “formula” probably refers to the 1989 track of the same name by The D.O.C. which was produced by Dr. Dre. The others mentioned are Notorious B.I.G, Grand Puba and Ice Cube.

There are also somewhat similar lines in Em’s “Rap God,” where he states:

Now I lead a new school full of students
Me? I’m a product of Rakim
Lakim Shabazz, 2Pac, N.W.A, Cube, hey Doc, Ren
Yella, Eazy, thank you, they got Slim"']])]

genius_description:
“Lost in the Fire” is a collaboration between French DJ Gesaffelstein and Canadian singer The Weeknd.

On the song, Abel sings about his tumultuous relationship with girlfriend Bella Hadid, assuring her that he “can’t lose” her again. He also sings, in explicit detail, about his illustrious sex life with Bella and other lovers. The “fire” is the time period between their initial breakup and reconnection.

“Lost in the Fire” found additional interest when lyrics in Abel’s first verse were interpreted as shots at Drake.

The track was first teased by Gesaffelstein on January 7, 2019. Abel continued to tease the song on his social media over the next three days. The song ultimately debuted on the third episode of The Weeknd’s Beats 1 Radio show Memento Mori, which aired at midnight on January 11, 2019.
genius_annotations:
[('You said you might be into girls (Into girls)
 Said you’re going through a phase (Through a phase)', [['Bella Hadid is unsure of her own sexuality. In 2015, it was rumored that she was seen kissing model Stella Maxwell. Furthermore, in an August 2017 Star Magazine article, it was speculated that Bella and longtime friend and fellow model Kendall Jenner were dating, something that Kendall denied.

Commentators took offence to the idea that being attracted to people of the same gender is “a phase”.']]), ('I’ll take it off, you’re the one I’ll roll the dice on (Dice on, dice on, dice on)', [['To “Roll the dice” means to gamble or bet. The Weeknd and Bella Hadid are back together and he’s willing to take the condom off while they have intercourse.

On his Memento Mori exclusive Apple Music Beats1 radio show, he mentioned he does indeed plan to have a child with Bella.']]), ('I used to have a girl a day (Girl a day)', [['This is likely a callback to Abel’s 2011 mixtape Thursday and its eponymous track. The concept centered around him spending time with a separate girl each day. On the chorus, he specifically focuses on telling the story of the girl he visits on Thursday:

Not on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday
Sunday, but on Thursday, Thursday
Not on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday
Sunday, but on Thursday, make sure
You are thirsty oh, on Thursday, baby']]), ('Well, baby, you can bring a friend (Bring a friend)
 She can ride on top your face (Top your face)
 While I fuck you straight (While I fuck you straight, yeah)', [['The Weeknd petitions his girlfriend, Bella Hadid, to have a threesome with one of her friends. There have been rumors that she is bisexual.

Abel’s music is typically sexually charged, so it’s no surprise he’s been singing about threesomes dating back to some of his earliest work—like on his March 2011 song “The Party & The After Party,” where he sings:

Girl, bring your friends, if you want we can share

The “fuck you straight” lyric was criticized by some media outlets for being about turning a bisexual or homosexual woman heterosexual. On the other hand, Abel could be singing about a specific threesome where his significant other is having oral sex with another woman while he has sex with her in the same manner that a straight couple would.']]), ('And we lost a lot of things in the fire
 So it took a year for me to find out (Find out, find out)', [['Abel and supermodel Bella Hadid started dating in May 2015 and broke up in November 2016.

In January 2017, Abel started dating singer Selena Gomez, but in October 2017, they also broke up, prompting Abel to release his 2018 EP My Dear Melancholy,, where Gesaffelstein has two features.

After a year of separation, Abel and Bella rekindled their relationship, and it took a year of not being together for him to realize that he cannot lose her.

https://goo.gl/images/FWKziM']]), ('And I just want a baby with the right one
 (I just want a baby with the right—)
 ’Cause I could never be the one to hide one
 (I could never be the one to hide—)', [["The Weeknd takes a shot at Drake who was accused of hiding his son Adonis on Pusha-T’s scathing May 2018 diss track, “The Story of Adidon”:

You are hiding a child, let that boy come home
Deadbeat mothafucka playin' border patrol, ooh

Drake responded on his June 2018 track, “Emotionless”:

I wasn’t hidin' my kid from the world
I was hidin' the world from my kid

Unlike Drake, who has a child with former pornstar Sophie Brussaux following a one-night stand, The Weeknd wants to make sure he’s with the right woman before having a child.

Despite collaborating early in their careers, Abel and Drake have had an on-and-off feud since 2011. With these shots, Abel may be reigniting their feud after Drake seemingly attempted to get with Abel’s then ex-girlfriend, Bella Hadid. The Weeknd and Bella broke up in November 2016, and Drake and Bella were seen leaving an L.A. nightclub together in June 2017. After that, rumors arose that they were in a secret relationship.

On June 2018’s “Finesse,” Drake mentions attending New York Fashion Week with two sisters, which is likely a reference to Bella and her sister Gigi, both of whom annually attend the event.

Should I do New York? I can’t decide
Fashion week is more your thing than mine […]
You and your sister
Too hot to handle

Bella quickly dispelled any rumors of a relationship with Drake after “Finesse” released:
https://twitter.com/bellahadid/status/1012764155458281473"]])]

genius_primary_artist: Gucci Mane, Bruno Mars & Kodak Black
genius_description:
“Wake Up in the Sky” is the third single from Gucci Mane’s album, Evil Genius. The song is an ode to the high life, with Gucci, Bruno, and Kodak discussing drugs, alcohol, and the finer things in life.

The song marks the second collaboration between Gucci Mane and Bruno Mars following Gucci’s remix of Bruno’s “That’s What I Like.” The song also marks Gucci’s second collaboration with Kodak, following Kodak’s “Vibin in This Bih.” This song marks Bruno and Kodak’s first collaboration.
genius_annotations:
[('She lost in the sauce (Woo) ’cause Gucci got the glow (Huh)', [["The line reffers to the legendary, 2013 interview with Gucci Mane, in which he “explained the sauce”

Mane, a bitch, mane, a bitch gon' get lost in the sauce, mane. You know what I’m sayin'?

The video resulted in many memes and different interpretations of the famous quote.

https://twitter.com/KodakBlack1k/status/1039184233305198601']]), ('I’m on Adderall, I be smellin’ Hi-Tech when I piss

genius_description:
After collaborating on Young Thug’s “Hop Off a Jet” just one week earlier, Travis Scott enlists his frequent collaborator for another energetic track. On the flute-heavy track, Travis describes the loyalty that his Cactus Jack Records gang shares, while Thug crudely describes his sexual activities.

The song’s title refers to Los Angeles, California, not to the age of the American Frontier, which lasted from the early 1600s to the early 1900s. While Travis was born in Houston and Thug was born in Atlanta, both have lived in Los Angeles during times throughout the last few years and currently reside there. The two rappers use brash lyricism, an exotic melody and a hypnotizing beat to portray themselves as modern outlaws.

On March 20, 2020, the song’s official music video was released. It features Travis and Thug alongside Travis' Cactus Jack members Don Toliver, Sheck Wes, Luxury Tax, and Chase B, and Thug’s YSL members Yung Kayo and Young Jordan. The video also features a cameo appearance from 21 Savage, a frequent collaborator of both Travis and Thug.
genius_annotations:
[('I eat molly and I take this bitch on a trip', [['Methyl​enedioxy​methamphetamine, commonly known as ecstasy or molly, is a psychoactive drug primarily used for recreational purposes. The desired effects include altered sensations, increased energy, empathy, as well as pleasure. When taken by mouth, effects begin in 30 to 45 minutes and last 3 to 6 hours.']]), ('Ayy, bag it out west (Bag it), slangin’ out west (Yeah)', [["“Slangin'” is slang for selling something, and in Thug’s case it’s probably drugs. “Bagging it” could be talking about the money he made from selling the drugs, or about bagging up the drugs to sell them."]]), ('I just put a drum on a new Kel-Tec (On a)', [['Kel-Tec is short for Kel-Tec CNC Industries Inc, an American firearms manufacturing company founded by George Kellgren. They are most commonly known for their line of semi-automatic pistols.



Pictured: Kel-Tec Semi-Automatic CP33

In this case, Thug uses “drum” in reference to a circular drum magazine used to deliver high amounts of ammunition to the gun very quickly, as compared to a traditional magazine.

Thug seems to be a fan of the brand, as he has mentioned it before. One example of this is in October 2017’s “Real Love” with Future, where Thug raps:

Put a hole on the Kel-Tec, ‘cause I ain’t tryna get killed yet, hmm']]), ('Buddah bless this beat', [['This is the producer tag for Ty-Ron Douglas, better known as Buddah Bless, a producer from Atlanta, Georgia. He works closely with Atlanta artists, most often Migos.

On “OUT WEST,” Buddah samples Bankroll Fresh’s November 2015 track, “Take Over Your Trap,” which features 2 Chainz and Skooly and was produced by Mondo. Buddah also sampled “Take Over Your Trap” on 2 Chainz’s August 2016 hit, “Big Amount,” making “OUT WEST” his second interpolation of Mondo’s beat.

Buddah has previously worked with Travis Scott on his and Quavo’s (HUNCHO JACK’s) December 2017 tracks, “Modern Slavery” and “Saint Laurent Mask.” He also produced Juicy J’s September 2018 track, “Neighbor,” which features Travis.

Surprisingly, this is Buddah’s first collaboration with Young Thug.']]), ('I used to jump off the back of the bus (Yeah), now I jump off of a jet (Yeah)', [['While riding the bus represents poverty, using a private jet on the daily indicates a certain amount of wealth.

Young Thug often reflects on his success by comparing his luxurious life to his past daily life. Thugger is familiar with this bar pattern and has rapped a similar line on his April 2018 song “Now”:

Used to be debt down (broke), hop out the jet now (the jet)

Travis and Thug also have a collaboration named “Hop Off a Jet,” which was released just one week before this song.']])]

genius_description:
On “GATTI,” Travis Scott and rising Brooklyn rapper Pop Smoke team up for the first time on the JACKBOYS record.

On December 23, 2019, a video of Pop Smoke and Travis Scott hanging out in the streets circulated online, featuring a snippet of an unreleased track between the two artists. A day later, UK drill producer 808Melo confirmed a collaboration between the two, revealing that Mike Dean was mastering the track.

An early demo of the track featuring French Montana leaked on October 28, 2019.

On December 30, 2019, Travis Scott released accompanying visuals for the track, which featured Travis and Pop Smoke driving around Houston in a Bugatti Veyron.
genius_annotations:
[('Woo back, baby (Woo back, baby), woo (Haha, yeah)', [['This is Pop’s infamous ad-lib, named after his gang: The Woo’s']]), ('And I’m in that Bugatti, movin’ two hundred (Bah)', [['In the track’s music video, Pop can be seen sitting passenger to Travis in a Bugatti Chiron, which can notably reach speeds of upwards of 260 MPH.

https://images.app.goo.gl/Uefxpr8U94CbLCp47']]), ('Trap House Mob
 Niggas frontin’ their jewels (Yeah, this is a Melo beat)', [['808Melo is a British producer and frequent collaborator with Pop Smoke. Trap House Vibes refers to the fact that he is part of Trap House Mob a UK drill production crew.

The beat was originally produced just by 808Melo
 and vocalled by Smoove L on New Apollos but the license was not exclusive allowing AXL to modify the beatsomewhat for Pop Smoke and Travis to go over the top.']]), ('Young La Flame, how it moves, Pop Flare how it— (Woo)', [['Young La Flame is another name by which Travis Scott refers to himself. This was first mentioned on ‘Blocka La Flame’ and has also been referred to by Drake on ‘Sicko Mode’.

Referring to Pop Smoke as Pop Flare might have to do with the fact that Flares produce Smoke or that he was shining so brightly at the time.

Flare and Woo could also be a reference to the wrestler Ric Flair, whose catchphrase is, like Pop Smoke “Wooo”']]), ('And she got a Louis bag (Yeah), that hold the extendo (Woo, woo)', [['Louis Vuitton is a luxury brand, their famous LV print bags are a status symbol. An extendo is an extended magazine clip for bullets that is bigger than a normal clip.']]), ('It cost me three for the keys (Keys)
 Not the work but the V', [['he’s talking about how it cost him 3 million for the keys for the Bugatti Veyron, and he had to iterate again for u dumb fools for saying he’s talking about keys as cocaine. He does this by saying not the work (work meaning cocaine), but the V (V= veyron) . Woooooo']]), ('Braid my hair down ’til I hide my face', [["Early on in Travis' career, he would constantly obscure his face on camera, either by wearing half-masks or covering his face with his hands.



 Travis in the music video for “Mamacita”"]]), ('They couldn’t be Crips, so they turned Folks (Bah)
 Drivin’ through the ‘Ville, droppin’ the cho (Brr)
 I gotta laugh, ’cause these niggas jokes (Haha)
 Dread like, “Who these niggas?” (Who these niggas?)', [['Pop Smoke mentions rival gang members from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, specifically rival Drill rappers Tay 627 and Chris Elite, who are members of Folk Nation; who are a crew that affiliate themselves with Cho.

“Cho” affiliated crews feud with the “Woo” crews that Pop Smoke affiliates himself with.

Tay627 and Chris Elite remade Pop Smoke’s hit, “Welcome to the Party” with a song titled “Welcome to the Garvey”. Garvey referring to the Marcus Garvey Village section of Brownsville.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8kK9RjAEeOM']]), ('I’m from the Floss where niggas tote (Woah)', [['Pop Smoke is from the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. also referred to as “Flossy” of “Floss”.

A term the rapper Fabolous helped make popular in his 2007 song “Brooklyn”.

Pop Smoke let’s us know people from Canarsie are ready and carry weapons.']]), ('Facts, my bitch love coco (Haha)', [['Pop Smoke’s line here has different possible meanings.  “Coco” is slang for the drug “cocaine,” as well as the designer brand Chanel, as the original designer was named Coco Chanel.



He could also be talking about his skin color because coco is also used for chocolate. We know he’s black which is also known for chocolate.']])]

genius_description: Being produced by the duo of jetsonmade & Pooh Beatz–the primary producers of one of Summer 2019’s hit songs, “Suge”–and being accompanied by a Lyrical Lemonade music video, this playfully grandeur single from Jack Harlow shows he has gained a new level of trust and recognition within the hip-hop community he had not yet seen in prior years.
genius_annotations:
[('Me and my ’migos got that free smoke', [['Jack’s – and his collective Private Garden’s – rapidly-increasing popularity has made it a whole lot easier to enjoy himself at clubs and public space with many people buying him drinks or handing him marijuana joints, or free smoke.

Jack drops the ‘a’ on “amigos” to shorten it to the name of popular rap trio Migos, who are known to smoke a lot of marijuana.']]), ('Eating fettuccine at Vincenzo’s', [['That’s an Italian restaurant in downtown Louisville. I think I went there once as a kid but, it’s fly. Vincenzo, himself heard the song. He wants me to come in so we’re about to bring the art to life.'], ["Fettuccine is frequently regarded, especially in rap, as a high-class food. Examples of this include:

It’s All About the Benjamins by Puff Daddy

Yeah livin' the raw deal
Three course meals: spaghetti, fettuccine, and veal

Do My Dance by Tyga

Order calamari, say she want that fettuccine
5 star bitches, my bitches don’t eat at Denny’s

Vincenzo is both a real restaurant (as Harlow points out above), and a recognizably Italian name. Harlow is saying that he eats high quality food at authentic restaurants."]]), ('On the West Coast, yeah, I’m talking ’bout pre-rolls (Pre-roll)', [['Pre-rolls are pre-rolled joints, made ready to smoke out of the box. They can be bought from dispensaries in various states along the West Coast, where weed is legal.']]), ('I got a B.B. Simon belt on me
 And she tryna get it unfastened', [['In this line Jack is referring to the company B.B. Simon. B.B. Simon is a brand of blinged out belts often adorned by Swarovski crystals.']]), ('My swag, they keep jackin’ (Keep on jackin’)', [['Everybody that en vogue and knows what’s going on is definitely about to be on that. It’s about to happen on a mad scale because the shit I’m on no one else is on. Just the sound, the way I’m doing things, so they’re going to start taking that shit. I genuinely feel that way.']]), ('Brand new sheets for the bed, they satin (Soft, real soft)', [['They say that satin and textures like that are easier on your hair and I really want my curls to have longevity. So, I think cotton when you wear it, messes it up.']]), ('I’m digging her accent', [['Those New York accents. Nothing like being cussed out up here. That’s just what I’m into. I like anything outside the US honestly. Anything that ain’t what I’ve been hearing, fire.']]), ('PG, we getting some traction

We came out together, been a collective since day one. Those are the guys and we’re really building some traction. We’re starting to get after it.']]), ('Got a career and I’m very invested
 Some people call it a scary obsession (Ooh, period, but)

 I can’t be sitting relaxin’ (Nah, I can’t)', [['They ain’t wrong when they call it a scary obsession. I’m obsessed with this, but scary ain’t the word. It’s just an obsession. People always ask, what would you do if you weren’t doing this? I have no idea. I think a masseuse potentially, but aside from that I don’t know. I didn’t go in with a plan B. I ain’t go to college, so I know I was not going to do nothing but this. Partially what made it happen.']]), ('Gotta cherish the present

I’m so forward driven and reflective that I be stuck between here. I’m trying to get better at doing this. It’s something I’m practicing. I don’t have no advice or anything to tell people because that’s what I’m trying to get on myself.  But real talk, I do drink a lot of water. I’m very disciplined about wearing condoms.']])]

genius_description:
“Head & Heart” is the first collaboration between English producer, Joel Corry and English singer-songwriter, MNEK. The duo created a summer dance anthem with upbeat piano chords combined with MNEK’s catchy vocals—the song received acclaim, especially in the UK, reaching the number one spot on The Official Big Top 40 just two weeks after release.

MNEK sings about the conflict of thoughts between his head and his heart—this is shown through the music video, which is split in two halves, illustrating the head and the heart respectively.

In an interview with HollywoodLife, Joel Corry shared:

2020 has been a tough year, so I wanted to give people an uplifting banger and bring the positive vibes. I hope ‘Head & Heart’ becomes the soundtrack to some amazing summer memories across the world.

genius_description:
Written as a protest song against the Vietnam War, “Happy Xmas (War Is Over)” was the end result of two years of activism by John Lennon & Yoko Ono. Backing vocals on the song are also provided by the Harlem Community Choir.

“WAR IS OVER! If You Want It – Happy Christmas from John & Yoko” was the message displayed on numerous billboards in a dozen major cities around the world.
genius_annotations:
[('For weak and for strong (If you want it)', [['yes']]), ('For yellow and red ones (War is over)
 Let’s stop all the fight (Now)', [['Yellow refers, mainly, to Vietnamese people.  It was already a somewhat offensive term at the time, but it was considered acceptable to use it to highlight that the real offense was how American military policy was dehumanizing the Vietnamese far more than any mere words could do.

And red?  Well, it could refer to Native Americans then as now, but in the context of this song, it also referred to the Vietnamese Communists.  Communists of all nations have long been associated with the color red.']]), ('(Happy Christmas, Kyoko
 Happy Christmas, Julian)', [['At the beginning of the song, two whispers can be heard. Yoko whispers: “Happy Christmas, Kyoko” (Kyoko Chan Cox is Yoko’s daughter with Anthony Cox); John whispers: “Happy Christmas, Julian” (Julian Lennon is John’s son with Cynthia Lennon).

Kyoko and Julian are both children that John and Yoko had with other people. Yet, John and Yoko wish both a happy Christmas. This message signifies affection and love beyond borders, in spite of hardship and differences.']]), ('War is over, if you want it
 War is over, now', [["John and Yoko spent a lot of time in the late ‘60s and early '70s working to promote peace. In 1969, they put up billboard advertisements in major cities around the world that said, “War is over! (If you want it).” Two years later this slogan became the basis for this song when Lennon decided to make a Christmas record with an anti-war message. John also claimed another inspiration for writing the song: he said he was “sick of 'White Christmas.’”"]]), ('A very Merry Christmas
 And a happy New Year
 Let’s hope it’s a good one
 Without any fear', [['Recognising the accessibility and popular appeal that made his 1971 single “Imagine” a commercial success compared to the other songs he had released up to that point, Lennon concluded, “Now I understand what you have to do: Put your political message across with a little honey.” He conceived “Happy Xmas (War Is Over)” as a means of elaborating upon the themes of social unity and peaceful change enacted through personal accountability and empowerment that served as the basis of the earlier billboard campaign, trying to convey optimism whilst avoiding the sentimentality that he felt often characterised music of the holiday season.']])]
genius_comments:
['The lyrics on this page for John Lennon’s “Happy Christmas” contain an error.

Your line: “The world is so wrong” is incorrect.

John sings: “The road is so long”

John was a lover of life, people and the world, no matter the problems. He would have never said the world is wrong. Fixing this would be the right thing to do.

Thank you,
C. Love', 'The line “the world is so wrong” is not correct, John Lennon sings “the road is so long”.']

genius_description:
“X” marks the Jonas Brothers' first collaboration with Colombian singer-songwriter KAROL G. The song was released concurrently with the boys' other song, “Five More Minutes.” Both tracks make up their two pack bundle titled XV.

Similar to the brothers' January 2020 single “What a Man Gotta Do,” is an upbeat vibe, which is also Bollywood-inspired.

The official music video for this song premiered to the band’s YouTube channel three days after its release, on May 18, 2020. Everybody in the video is shown dancing on video camera on separate iPhones. This was because the COVID-19 pandemic, was going on at the time of its release, which killed a lot of people worldwide. To take appropriate action, people were predominantly quarantined in their own homes.
genius_annotations:
[('“Bailando”', [["The Jonas Brothers are referring to Enrique Iglesias' “Bailando”, the hit Spanish song of 2014.

genius_description:
“Isis” is the third single from Joyner Lucas' 2019 album ADHD. The song is named after the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria; one of the most notorious terrorist factions of the 21st century.

On the track, Logic and Joyner Lucas discuss everything from ADHD to haters, women and success. Interestingly, this song marks the end of the feud between the two rappers, which started back in 2017.
genius_annotations:
[('Do it for the love of rap, not for the fame shit, woo!', [["In this line, it becomes clear that Logic entirely loathes fame and popularity. The theme of detesting fame is not new to the rapper. In his track ‘'Ballin’' featuring Shy Grey, he said:

I’m like, ‘Fuck the money, fuck the fame’,
I came here to fuck up the game."]]), ('Fuck the heat and the crime', [['Logic is against the police and the act of crime itself.
In this Los Angeles Times interview, Logic was questioned about his decision to keep quiet on social media during several national reports of police brutality. He responded:

I’m not going to hashtag it, talk about it on the Internet for it to live for two seconds. I’m going to make a whole … album so it lives forever']]), ('Everybody livin’ on the surface
 But we came from the underground, yeah, we deserve it', [['In 2009, Logic went by the name “Psychological,” and sold physical copies of his music, specifically Psychological: The Mixtape, in his hometown of Maryland. He gained some notoriety in December 2009 when he gave a fan permission to upload his songs to YouTube. Subsequently, he released four mixtapes, which gained him more recognition on the internet. Three studio albums later, Logic found commercial success with his April 2017 hit single “1-800-273-8255” off of his third studio album, Everybody.

Joyner released his debut mixtape Listen To Me in May 2011, and released two mixtapes afterwards, one of which earned him attention with the song “Ross Cappichioni” off of his third mixtape, Along Came Joyner, which released on April 1, 2015. He later found commercial success with his November 2017 single, “I’m Not Racist.”']]), ('Two times for them bitches in the South Shore (Whoa)', [['The South Shore is the geographical region of Massachusetts that lies south of Boston.

While Joyner’s hometown of Worcester is not in the South Shore, he makes note of the wealthy ladies from the area.']]), ('Six times for the kids like me who got ADHD just to— (Brap, brap, brap)', [['Joyner Lucas has ADHD, and he’s rapping for people with the same mental disorder. Lucas intentionally cuts off this line, representing one of the signature symptoms of ADHD, which includes inattention and lack of focus.

Lucas posted about his condition and new project on his Facebook page in May of 2019:

Since I was 5 I was diagnosed with ADHD and I often struggled in school and at home… The older I got the worst it got. I’m proud to say that overcame so many obstacles and reached massive success and I STILL have ADHD.']]), ('Two times for the homies in the chow hall (Whoa)', [['A “chow hall” is a military cafeteria also known as a “mess hall.” Joyner shows his appreciation for U.S. military personnel who fought the terrorist organization ISIS in Syria. He may also be talking about a prison cafeteria, based on the context.']]), ('Keep the peace like a waistline, woo!', [['“Peace” is a homophone of “piece,” which refers to a handgun. Oftentimes, peace needs to be maintained at the threat of violence, and a handgun is kept close by for fast action. This refers both to Logic’s fast rapping and the sudden, unexpected drop of this track, ending the beef between Joyner and Logic.']]), ('Three times for the street crimes that I committed
 Yeah, I did it, but thank God that I made it out
 Four times ‘cause I’m a fuckin’ bastard', [["Logic’s past has been a hot topic in many of his songs, such as “Gang Related,” “Under Pressure,” and “Take It Back.” In 2014, he told Complex:

Growing up, there were guns in the house, my brothers were out selling crack. I grew up on Section 8 housing, food stamps, welfare and dealing with social services. I never had a Christmas, I never had a birthday.

In “Roll Call,” Logic raps:

Ain’t seen my mama in a minute
‘Cause growing up she called me a nigg​er
That would never amount to nothing

And in “Dear God”:

What about the time I was nine and my mama almost murdered me?
Don’t think I forgot that shit, it still burdens me
Her bare hands tight around my throat
“I can’t breathe” I screamed, “I can’t breathe, Mama
Don’t you want me, Mama? Don’t you love me, Mama?” What the fuck

As for the “bastard” line, this is also a topic that Logic has brought up before in his music, such as in “Warm It Up,” where he raps:

I’m a bastard that mastered the flow
And none of y'all ready for the massacre, though

Logic has gone into great detail with the relationship he and his parents share, and while he is now in good terms with his father (who was featured on “BOBBY” and even “Homicide” with Eminem), there is no recent word on him coming to terms with his mother in their relationship together."]]), ('Niggas throwin’ stones at my glass house (Whoa)', [['Joyner plays on the proverb, “people who live in glass houses should not throw stones,” which means people shouldn’t criticize if they possess the same flaws of which they’re being critical.

An example of someone being critical of Joyner’s work is Tory Lanez, who had a short feud with Joyner. In November 2018, the two traded diss tracks. Tory Lanez criticized Joyner’s music for failing to achieve mainstream success on “Litty Again (Freestyle)”:

Eminem couldn’t get ya to a million on the ‘Gram
Chris Brown tried, nigga failed both times
I done took ya page to a million in a day
If you ask me, nigga, I’m ya motherfucking cosign']]), ('High and drunk, call that HD vision', [['Here, Logic combines the first letters of the words “high” and “drunk” to create the acronym HD—this acronym is normally used as a reference to high definition video, which has high video resolution.

Being high and drunk can mess up your vision—a symptom of drunkeness is distorted vision, and a symptom of being high is having red eyes.

Although being high and drunk wouldn’t give you HD vision, Logic takes the first two letters of each and creates a juxtaposed acronym with them. This line could also be a tie-in to the “HD” (hyperactive disorder) in the acronym “ADHD”.']])]

genius_description:
“Life’s A Mess” is a promotional single off of Juice WRLD’s first posthumous studio album Legends Never Die. On the track, Juice and Halsey convey their troubles throughout their lives whilst showing appreciation to their desired partners.

The track was released four days before the album, and was accompanied by a music video directed by Chad Ross.
genius_annotations:
[('I’m screaming out, “Lord, help me, I’ve been lonely”
 That’s when you accept me, then you set me free', [["Mentioning God and asking Him for help is a recurring theme in Legends Never Die.

In the first verse of his 2020 track “Titanic,” off his first posthumous album Legends Never Die, he says something that follows the same idea:

They tell me God watchin' over me, I don’t doubt it
But I can see Him gettin' tired of me sinnin' and wildin'

Same can be said for the lyrics in the first verse of “Come & Go”:

I pray to God that he make me a better man (Uh)
Maybe one day, I'ma stand for somethin'
I’m thankin' God that he made you part of the plan
I guess I ain’t go through all that Hell for nothin'"]]), ('And you’d finally let bygones be bygones', [["Juice and his significant have both struggled to live and love on with past mistakes. An example of this can be seen on his Marshmello-assisted “Come & Go, which released within the same week of this track:

Sayin' goodbye to bygones, those are bygones
Head up, baby, stay strong, we gon' live long"]]), ('’Cause when heart breaks it feel like the world’s gone', [["A frequent topic in Juice’s music, demons, devils, and evil girls often plague his love life. Examples of this can be seen anywhere on his music – from his underground tracks, such as the aptly named tracks “Demon Love“ and “Devil Horns“ – all the way to within his two most popular hits, “Lucid Dreams“ and “All Girls are the Same.“

Within “Lucid Dreams,“ he sings:

You left me falling and landing inside my grave
I know that you want me dead
I take prescriptions to make me feel a-okay
I know it’s all in my head
I have these lucid dreams where I can’t move a thing
Thinking of you in my bed

And within “All Girls are the Same“:

Ten minutes, she told me it would take ten minutes
To break my heart, oh, no, she didn’t
Fuck livin', I'ma drown in my sorrow
Fuck givin', I'ma take, not borrow
And I’m still sinnin', I’m still losin' my mind"]]), ('(Rex, you did it again)', [['This is the producer tag for Rex Kudo, who gained popularity after producing Post Malone’s 2016 smash hit, “Go Flex.“ He’s worked with multiple prestigious artists before, with the likes of Lil Uzi Vert, Young Thug, and Roddy Ricch all being featured on his discography.

Although he’s never worked with Halsey prior to this track, he has connected with Juice on his 2019 track, “ON GOD.“ He also informally collaborated with Juice on two unreleased tracks; namely “Life’s a Dungeon“ and “Floor It.“']]), ('My whole world turned upside down, uh
 But for the better', [['Contrasting Juice’s normal struggles with toxic and evil girls, this line relates to Juice’s significant other’s positivity.

It’s worth noting that Juice always lived by the prophecy of “999“ – or the satanic number “666“ upside down – in order to focus on rehab and living a more positive lifestyle.

The number is present nearly everywhere within his social media, merchandise, and even his concerts. Within a July 2018 interview with MTV News, Juice touched on the number and its significance in his life:

999 represents taking whatever ill, whatever bad situation, whatever struggle you’re going through and turning it into something positive to push yourself forward.

Juice also tweeted on February 18, 2018, further expanding on the number:

I took the hell I was going through (666) and flipped it over into something positive (999)']])]

genius_description:
“Come & Go” is the fourth promotional single from Juice WRLD’s posthumous studio album, Legends Never Die. On the Marshmello-produced beat, Juice contrasts much of music and focuses on the positive side of his love and relationships.

The track was first previewed via Juice’s Twitter on November 30, 2018. The video was captioned “Off my chest,” leading people to incorrectly speculate that was the title of the song. An early version of the track was leaked on August 18, 2019, and was eventually released on July 9, 2020, one day before Legends Never Die.

The official music video was released on July 10, 2020. It features animation from Tristan Zammit, whose animation was also featured in the music video for “Righteous,” the album’s lead single.
genius_annotations:
[('I pray to God that He make me a better man (Uh)
 Maybe one day, I’ma stand for somethin’
 I’m thankin’ God that He made you part of the plan
 I guess I ain’t go through all that Hell for nothin’', [["This is not the first time that Juice is talking about God helping him and being on his side.

In the first verse of his 2020 track “Titanic,” off of his first posthumous album Legends Never Die, he says something that follows the same idea:

They tell me God watchin' over me, I don’t doubt it
But I can see Him gettin' tired of me sinnin' and wildin'"]]), ('Tell me ain’t nobody better than me
 I think that there’s better than me
 Hope you see the better in me
 Always end up betterin’ me', [['Juice contrasts claims from his 2017 smash hit “Lucid Dreams,“ where he raps:

You found another one, but I am the better one
I won’t let you forget me

Here, Juice’s significant other has seemingly changed her mind, possibly realizing that he is the best out there. However, Juice also points out his own insecurities, denying his significant other’s praise.

This could very likely stem from his consistent dealing with demonic and evil girls, which can also be seen throughout almost all of his music. For example, on “Lucid Dreams,“ he raps:


You left me falling and landing inside my grave
I know that you want me dead

Who knew evil girls had the prettiest face?']]), ('Oh, oh-oh, oh (Mello made it right, uh)', [['This is the producer tag, voiced by rapper Roddy Ricch, of American music producer and EDM musician Marshmello, famous for his helmet-concealed anonymity and production on songs such as “Wolves,” “Happier,” “Silence,” and “FRIENDS.”

Marshmello has produced on multiple hip-hop tracks in the past, such as  “Been Thru This Before,” “Project Dreams,” “Reverse,” “Light It Up” and “Don’t Save Me.”

He worked with Juice on an unreleased track prior to this entitled “Bye Bye,“ but also connected officially with the Chicago native on another track off Legends Never Die – “Hate the Other Side.“']]), ('Sayin’ goodbye to bygones, those are bygones
 Head up, baby, stay strong, we gon’ live long', [['Juice and his significant other have struggled with accepting past mistakes multiple times before, such as on his recently released track “Life’s a Mess,” on which he similarly sings:

But if the love’s real, you’d feel your soul roar like a lion
And you’d finally let bygones be bygones']])]
