genius_description:
“Real Shit“ sees Juice WRLD touching on his fame and wealth. Expanding on the positive sides of his lifestyle, Juice vows to never tell lies and be honest with everyone around him.

The track marks Juice’s second official release after his first posthumous album, Legends Never Die, and was preceded by August 2020’s The Weeknd-assisted “Smile.” The track’s production is handled by his frequent collaborator, benny blanco.

The track was initially announced on November 30, 2020, through an Instagram post from Juice’s clothing brand, 999 CLUB. The post revealed the track’s cover art. A 15-second snippet surfaced within the same day.

The track’s release date is significant, as it would have been Juice’s 22nd birthday—December 2, 2020.
genius_annotations:
[('Life’s good, so I’m living great (Great)
 I hit up my lady, we should take a vacay (’Cay)', [["As a result of his hard work—recording over 2000 songs according to TMZ during his short-lived career—Juice WRLD looks to celebrate with some time away with his ex-fiancée Ally Lotti. He makes a similar remark in the song “I Want It,” posthumously released in July 2020, where he raps:

Gon' on and ride it, ride it, ride it, gon' on and fuck me (Oh)
Let’s take a vacation, get away from the ugly"]]), ('Big crib, need a new estate, yeah
 Money goin’ into real estate, yeah', [['In March 2020, TMZ obtained documents which valued the estate of Juice WRLD to be in the region of $3.3 million, including a Miami condo worth $1.49 million, highlighting Jarad’s priority to invest in property.

On 2018’s “Realer n Realer” with Future, Juice justifies his tendencies to use money:

Uh, people love to talk about the money that they make
Nobody wanna talk about the money that they save
Who am I to talk about it? I blow money every day
‘Cause I know when you die, you can’t take the shit to your grave']]), ('Tryna ball while they playin’ keep away (Yeah, yeah)
 Tryna ball while they playin’ keep away, yeah (Yeah, yeah)', [["Juice WRLD was a basketball fan, and played the game on multiple occasions, such as in January 2019 at Culture Kings Melbourne:

https://youtu.be/ByR4ZU_5rRM?t=00m23s

Jarad utilizes terms from the sport to illustrate his uphill climb to fame, as “ball” means to succeed or have a great time. This proves difficult when people prevent him from doing so, thus playing “keep away,” which is a children’s game where two people try to keep a ball away from other players.

Juice WRLD had extensive basketball knowledge, as seen on his 2019 song “The Bees Knees,” where he references the 1998 NBA Finals:

I know y'all seen them old videos of Dream Team playin' basketball (Michael Jordan, Game 6, yeah yeah)
We just ran a three man weave"]]), ('Eatin’ good (Ayy), see it on our plate (Yeah)', [['In the later part of Juice’s career, he was often labeled as “fat“ or “out-of-shape.“ Most notably, after the release of the music video for his YoungBoy Never Broke Again-assisted October 2019 hit, “Bandit,“ Juice received many negative comments related to his weight and physique.

However, this seemingly never bothered him, as he acknowledged his physique and often laughed it off, such as in a video reacting to “Bandit“ in October 2019.

He also responded to a comment about his physique, playing on how “comfort food“ was the reason behind his stomach size. The comment stated that Juice was “eating the pain away,” to which he responded:

LMFAO too much comfort food huh?

On May 2018’s “I’ll Be Fine,” Juice touched on how his lifestyle with wealth led to the easy access to comfort food:

Now I’m eating steak and eggs when it’s lunchtime
I remember eating Ramen with a Glock .9']]), ('Labels want my music, tell the studio to bounce it
 This shit isn’t out yet', [['In 2017, Juice WRLD was rejected by multiple labels because he was considered a soundalike of Philadelphia rapper, Lil Uzi Vert.

On November 5, 2020, founder of producer collective Internet Money, Taz Taylor— who is a close and early associate of Juice WRLD – noted on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/taztaylor/status/1324373076188917760

Shortly after the release of multiple of Juice’s hit tracks such as July 2017’s “Lucid Dreams” and December 2017’s “All Girls Are The Same,” numerous labels offered him positions, most-notably Interscope Records, to which he subsequently signed the following year in March of 2018.

Juice WRLD reportedly passed away with over two-thousand unreleased songs recorded, in which many of them have been leaked prior and subsequent to his passing.

In an interview with Forbes, Juice WRLD expanded on this:

I have so much music that I don’t need to bring back something old. I probably have over a thousand songs.']]), ('I’ma make her bawl her eyes out
 While these niggas out of bounds', [['Juice makes a play on words within this line. Since “bawl“ sounds similar to "ball,” he plays on this with the reference to “out of bounds,” using the imagery of basketball. He rapped a similar line on his October 2018 single, “Armed and Dangerous,” where he rapped:

Ballin' hard, you outta bounds (You dig? Swish, ayy)']]), ('Havin’ black hoes snortin’ up the white bitch, uh, ayy', [['Juice raps a similar line to this on his May 2018 track “Black & White” – one that also saw production from benny blanco – which featured on his debut album Goodbye & Good Riddance. On the chorus of the track, he sings:

I’m in my black Benz, ah
Doing cocaine with my black friends, ah
…
Switch up to the white Benz (Okay)
Doing codeine with my white friends, ah (Friends)

Juice opts to refer to cocaine as “white bitch,” a slang term for the white, powdery narcotic.']]), ('One, two, three million, had to stop countin’', [['In March of 2018, Juice signed a three million-dollar partnership with Interscope Records and Grade A Productions.

The same year, Juice was the most liked, streamed, and reposted artist on SoundCloud. At the time of release of this track, his most popular track, July 2017’s “Lucid Dreams,” had garnered more than six hundred million video views on YouTube.']]), ('Main ho found out ’bout my mistress
 Gotta flip the script like a kickflip', [["This line is reminiscent of “From the Bottom,“ an unreleased Juice track in which he similarly raps:

Damn right I'ma hit ‘em with a kickflip
Bad bitch and another fucking mistress

A kickflip is a skateboarding maneuver invented by Rodney Mullen in which the rider flips the board 360º alongside the long axis, as depicted here:"]]), ('Workin’ out my demons, they in better shape, yeah, ayy
 Demons on my back, get them away from me, uh, ayy', [["Demons and devils are a consistent and frequented topic within Juice’s music, with numerous references being found within nearly all of his music. Examples of this can be seen anywhere on his music, such as the aptly named tracks “Demon Love“ and “Fighting Demons.“

Within “Fighting Demons,“ Juice sings:

My demons are breakin' out of their cage
I’m praying that I see another day (Chill, chill)
I said my demons are breakin' out of their cage
On my knees, I pray for better days"]])]

genius_description:
Justin Bieber reunites with Chance the Rapper and kicks off a “new era” on “Holy,” a song that focuses on their love for their respective significant others. It draws a parallel between relationships and the prescriptions, stemming from both religion and outsiders. Chance focuses on both maintaining faith and enjoying life. The song serves as the lead single from Justin’s sixth studio album, Justice (2021).

The official music video premiered alongside the song on September 18, 2020. It also stars actress Ryan Destiny to play Justin’s love interest, while Chance is also present, but only for his verse.
genius_annotations:
[('I know when the son takes the first steps, the Father’s proud (Yes)
 If you make it to the water, He’ll part the clouds (Uh)', [['The sacrament of baptism is a Christian rite that commonly involves either being sprinkling or submerging someone in water. Baptism is considered to be testimony of one’s submission to God, thus it is performed either at one’s birth or conversion to Christianity, allowing God, the Holy Father, to part the clouds for one’s eternal life in Heaven as he did for Jesus in Luke 3:21-22.']]), ('But when you come out of the water', [['“Coming out of the water” is a phrase used to signify baptism, a sacrament and a public demonstration of your Christian faith. By being plunged into the water, you are then being spiritually washed of sins, pain, and your burden, by Jesus’s sacrifice on the cross.']]), ('The first step pleases the Father
 Might be the hardest to take', [['The “first step” in becoming a Christian refers to believing wholly in the Father, God, and asking forgiveness for one’s sins. According to Acts 2:38,
and the Apostle Peter:

Peter replied, “Repent and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins. And you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit."

This step can often be the hardest because it comes from a place of vulnerability between you and God.']]), ('Formalize the union in communion, He can trust (Woo)', [['Christians partake in Holy Communion, also known as the Eucharist, a sacrament in remembrance of the body and blood of Jesus, which were broken and poured at the cross. Consecrated bread and wine are consumed according to Christ’s wish to do this in memory of Him.

Then he took a loaf of bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it and gave it to them, saying, “This is my body, which is given for you. Do this in remembrance of me.” And he did the same with the cup after supper, saying, “This cup that is poured out for you is the new covenant in my blood.']]), ('I’m a believer, my heart is fleshy', [['Chance quotes Ezekiel 36:26:

I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit in you; I will remove from you your heart of stone and give you a heart of flesh.

This means that God removes an obstinate nonbeliever’s “heart of stone,” representing their unwillingness to accept Him, and gives them a living, beating heart, reflecting their rebirth in Christ.']]), ('I know the spots that got the best weed, we goin’ next week', [['Chance quit smoking marijuana (weed) sometime in 2016. However, in the livestream between him and Bieber ten minutes before the song’s release, he announced that he smoked weed and instantly passed out. Bieber then talked about his previous addiction to drugs and showed his understanding of how and why weed is harmful.']]), ('I don’t believe in nirvana', [['Nirvana is the pure and true intention of the Buddhist journey—it gives peace and calm feelings like heaven. It is a state of enlightenment, causing the problems to vanish. Even though this is a Buddhist definition, many people believe secularly in it and follow its steps. However, Bieber is a person who does not believe in it—Christianity, together with the other Abrahamic religions, are strictly monotheistic and now reject syncretism with any other religions, so it could be heterodox or even heretical for a Christian to believe in Buddhist ideas.']]), ('On God
 Runnin’ to the altar like a track star
 Can’t wait another second', [['An altar is a table in a church—offerings and sacrifices are made there for religious intentions. In an altar, mostly bread and wine are made sacred during communion services. People are eager to the donations and they want to  immediately offer and sacrifice items of theirs for God, using the metaphor “running” here.



For many Christian denominations, specifically those that believe that the bread and wine offered at the altar transform into Jesus Christ’s true body and blood, the altar is a place to encounter God. This is why Justin says he is running to the altar like a “track star,” a champion in the sport of track and field, a sport in running, since he is so eager to meet and spend time with God.

This may also be referencing Psalms 43:4:

Then I will go to the altar of God,
to God, my joy and my delight.
I will praise you with the lyre,
O God, my God.

Interestingly, the next line refers to playing the lyre, a musical instrument, so this would be a fitting verse to interpolate into a song.

An altar is also used at a wedding (it’s the structure under which we commonly see the bride and groom affirm their love for one another and a priest pronounce them married). Justin could be talking about his rapid marriage to Hailey Baldwin; the two dated from 2015 to 2016, then reconciled in May of 2018 and got married within six months. Justin didn’t want to wait to marry Hailey; he was certain in his love for her and sought to do so as rapidly as possible, i.e. almost literally raced to the altar.']]), ('(Chance the Rapper)', [['Chance introduces himself in the same, suggestive tone he used when introducing his verse on “Confident” – the pair’s first collaboration, released over six years prior in 2013.

The track from Bieber’s Journals album saw moderate success, peaking at #41 in the United States, where it has since been certified platinum.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=47YClVMlthI']]), ('But they don’t see you how I see you, Parlay and Desi', [['Desi Banks is a comedian, actor, and writer based in Atlanta, he is best known for his characters Parlay, Lil Johnny, Keisha, Grandma Reese, and Uncle Earl in his hilariously relatable online sketches.

Chance plays on the fact that even though Parlay plays a big role in the majority of Desi’s sketches, Parlay has never been seen on camera.']])]

genius_description:
“Get Me” was a promotional single from Justin Bieber’s fifth studio album, Changes. It was released onto streaming at the same time as the album’s official title and cover art. On the track, Bieber and R&B singer Kehlani croon in a call-and-response format to each other about their figurative relationship and the two’s compatibility.

The track continues the R&B feel that Bieber has promised for his fifth studio album, with the duo singing very sexily over a very gloomy beat featuring many artificial percussion and bass that is trademark to the genre.

The track was initially teased the day prior to its official release on January 27, 2020, as it was shown on a potential track listing along with several other tracks in the singer’s docu-series Justin Bieber: Seasons.
genius_annotations: [('Like a chemist, how you finishin’ my sentences', [['Kehlani makes a play on the double meaning of ‘period’ in chemistry and semantics. Most sentences end with a period, while each row of the Periodic Table of the Elements is known as a period.']])]

genius_description:
On “Forever,” Justin Bieber reunites with Post Malone and recruits up-and-coming rapper and singer Clever. This marks the second collaboration between Bieber and Post, following Bieber’s feature on Post’s September 2016 single, “Deja Vu”, from Post’s debut studio album, Stoney, while this marks both Bieber and Post’s first collaboration with Clever.

The track is featured on Bieber’s fifth studio album, Changes.

The song was first teased on December 24, 2019, via a trailer for his album on YouTube, which played a snippet of the track. On January 4, 2020, over two minutes of the track leaked on song-sharing sites.
genius_annotations:
[('I don’t wanna be the one that’s changed since Texas', [['Though he was born in Syracuse, New York, Post and his family moved to Grapevine, Texas when he was nine. His father works as the Assistant Director of Food and Beverage for the Dallas Cowboys football team.']]), ('Currency, it comes so naturally, but I can’t buy your love', [["Post reiterates a notable theme from his 2018 track, “Rich & Sad,” which weighed up money against love:

Ayy, I would throw it all away
I just keep on wishin' that the money made you stay
You ain’t never cared about that bullshit anyway
I just keep on wishin' that the money made you stay

Furthermore, the lyric is similar to that of Bieber’s ex-girlfriend, Selena Gomez’s, track “Naturally:”

Everything comes naturally, it comes naturally"]])]

genius_description:
“Intentions” is the third single for Justin Bieber’s Changes album. The song’s lyrics are full of compliments towards both Bieber’s and Quavo’s love-interests: Hailey Bieber and Saweetie. Both artists express their intentions of caring for their women over a bright and happy beat. This song marks the third time that Justin Bieber and Quavo have worked together, with the previous two taking part in collaborations with DJ Khaled.

The song was previewed on a speculated tracklist along with several other tracks in the singer’s docu-series Justin Bieber: Seasons, which was officially released to YouTube on January 27, 2020. Later, the song was confirmed on Apple Music as track number 4 featuring Quavo.

 Standin’ ovation, they did a great job raisin’ you', [['Hailey Bieber’s parents are the actor Stephen Baldwin and the graphic designer Kennya Deodato Baldwin. Her father has appeared in movies like The Usual Suspects and Born on the Fourth of July.

https://youtu.be/h_IjBp0A7Yk?t=22

Given his acting career, a standing ovation is a familiar form of appreciation.']]), ('Got that ring, just like Toronto', [['Justin compares his wife Hailey Baldwin’s wedding ring to the Toronto Raptors 2019 NBA Championship ring.



Bieber grew up in Stratford, Ontario, just outside of Toronto. He’s tweeted about the city’s NBA team and attended their games, and the Raptors mascot even dressed up like Bieber in 2016.

https://twitter.com/justinbieber/status/460813370955137024?lang=en']])]

genius_description:
On “Water,” Kanye West enlists the help of frequent collaborator Ant Clemons to discuss themes of purity, using water as a metaphor. In Judeo-Christian faiths, water plays a vital role in the ritual of Baptism, a rite that is symbolic of rebirth. The song’s theme bears similarities to those presented in his June 2018 collaborative project with Kid Cudi, titled KIDS SEE GHOSTS, such as the track “Reborn.”

Kanye and Ant have collaborated on several occasions prior to this song, namely on Ye’s June 2018 track “All Mine.” On the morning of Easter 2019, they debuted the song live at his Sunday Service Coachella event, with assistance from Ty Dolla $ign and the Sunday Service choir.
genius_annotations:
[('Let Your light reflect on me
 I promise I’m not hiding anything', [['Kanye is drawing on several themes throughout the Bible: the purity of God, depicted as light, and the futility of hiding sin from God.

In the gospel of Luke, Jesus talks about the need to keep our bodies “full of light” with no dark corners:

Your eye is the lamp of your body. When your eyes are healthy, your whole body also is full of light. But when they are unhealthy, your body also is full of darkness. See to it, then, that the light within you is not darkness. Therefore, if your whole body is full of light, and no part of it dark, it will be just as full of light as when a lamp shines its light on you.” (Luke 11: 34-36 NIV)

And Jesus warns elsewhere that anything we think will remain hidden from God will, in fact, be shouted from the rooftops:

There is nothing concealed that will not be disclosed, or hidden that will not be made known. What you have said in the dark will be heard in the daylight, and what you have whispered in the ear in the inner rooms will be proclaimed from the roofs. (Luke 12:2-3 NIV).

Psalm 32 talks about the value of confessing one’s sins to God, how it brings peace to the soul:

Blessed is the one
whose sin the Lord does not count against them
    and in whose spirit is no deceit. (Psalm 32:2 NIV)

And finally, a proverb of Solomon rather neatly ties together this line with the song’s water imagery:

As water reflects the face,
    so one’s life reflects the heart. (Proverbs 27:19 NIV)']]), ('Jesus is our rock', [["In Christianity, Christ is often referred to as “The Rock,” which refers to the parable of the man who built his house on a rock. Matthew 7:24-27 reads:

Therefore everyone who hears these words of mine and puts them into practice\xa0is like a wise man who built his house on the rock. The rain came down, the streams rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house; yet it did not fall, because it had its foundation on the rock.\xa0But everyone who hears these words of mine and does not put them into practice is like a foolish man who built his house on sand.\xa0The rain came down, the streams rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house, and it fell with a great crash.

The passage describes two men: one built his house on a rock and the other built his house on the sand. The house built on the rock describes a person who “builds” their life on Jesus' teachings, whereas the house built on the sand describes someone who “builds” their life in beliefs other than Jesus.

Jesus is also described as “The Rock” in Psalm 18:2:

The\xa0Lord\xa0is my rock,\xa0my fortress\xa0and my deliverer; my God is my rock, in whom I take refuge, my shield\xa0and the horn of my salvation,\xa0my stronghold.

And Psalm 62:2:

Truly he is my rock\xa0and my salvation;
he is my fortress,\xa0I will never be shaken."]]), ('Jesus, clean the music', [['In the days leading up to the album release, West’s pastor Adam Tyson stated that Kanye considered quitting rap because “it’s the devil’s music”.

“One time, he told me that he wasn’t going to rap,” Tyson said. “I said, ‘Why not?‘” to which Kanye replied: “‘That’s the devil’s music.’ I said, ‘Hey, man. Rap is a genre. You can rap for God.’

Rap music, often infamously and including Kanye’s own music, contains profanity and lyrics referencing premarital sex –\xa0two topics considered to be sins in Christianity.



JESUS IS KING is free of profanity and what could be called “sinful” lyrics. Instead, the album’s lyrics focuses purely on spreading the word of God. Songs like “New Body”, which ultimately did not make the album cut, were drastically altered to remove any sexual themes that would contradict the album’s gospel message.

West has only previously released one entirely clean album, 808s and Heartbreak (2008). Not only does it refer to Kanye cleansing and purifying his own music, but prays to Jesus to reform the music in current circulation.']]), ('Take the chlorine out our conversation', [['Chlorine is an element. It is often put into swimming pools to keep the water free of bacteria, but if ingested can be extremely harmful.

Ant Clemons says that he eliminates the bacteria, or the meaninglessness, out of the conversation to demonstrate the fact that the “conversation” that is taking place is “pure”, similar to the filtration method that chlorine provides. This is demonstrated later in the chorus where Ant explains:

I promise I’m not hiding anything

This is yet another Biblical allusion in the very religious album – much like Chlorine; in the Bible, Jesus purifies water.

This song particularly focuses on the symbolism of water. Kanye and Ant describe water as the physical manifestation of the concepts of ‘purity’ and perfection. In the religion of Christianity, Jesus is the only one to be described as perfect, stated in Peter 2:21-22.

Another common way to disinfect water is by using UV radiation, or light. In the next line, Ant Clemons says the following:

Let Your light reflect on me

This could be a possible hidden message, saying that rather than using an industrial, scientific way to purify ourselves and our relationships, use the light of God and his purity to better our lives.']]), ('Jesus, heal the bruises', [['In Christanity, Jesus Christ gives people strength and even has the ability to heal the sick. This is depicted in various passages in the bible, including Matthew 9:35:

Jesus went through all the towns and villages, teaching in their synagogues, proclaiming the good news of the kingdom and healing every disease and sickness.']]), ('Jesus, please forgive', [['The name “Jesus” means ‘savior:’ someone that saves or rescues people. In this case, Jesus saves people from their sins.

Forgiveness is a large part of Christianity. According to the bible, when someone commits a sin, he/she can repent and be given forgiveness because of the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ. There is a plethora of bible passages which talk about forgiveness, an example being John 1:9:

If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness.']]), ('It’s water
 We are water
 Pure as water', [['In Judeo-Christian religions, water is used during ritual Baptism, which represents rebirth or purification. Kanye visited this topic before, in an April 2018 Twitter post:

https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/989154899140096000?lang=en

He also tweeted something similar in December 2018:

https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/1073445021456719872?lang=en

He may also be referencing John 4:13, 14 which reads:

In answer Jesus said to her: “Everyone drinking from this water will get thirsty again. 14  Whoever drinks from the water that I will give him will never get thirsty at all,+ but the water that I will give him will become in him a spring of water bubbling up to impart everlasting life.”']]), ('The storm may come
 But we’ll get through it because of Your love', [['Storms are sometimes used to represent obstacles in life, a concept established in Psalm 107:28-29:

He maketh the storm a calm, so that the waves thereof are still.

Another biblical example can be found in three out of the four Gospels, when Jesus Christ calmed the storm. The story appears in Mark 4:35-41:

He got up, rebuked the wind and said to the waves, ‘Quiet! Be still!’ Then the wind died down and it was completely calm.

Interestingly, in July 2019 a leaked Kanye West track surfaced, titled “The Storm.” It was presumed to be from the previously cancelled Yandhi tracklist. The song ended up being the sixth track on Jesus Is King, titled “Everything We Need.”']])]

genius_description:
“Use This Gospel” is a spiritual track from Kanye West and rap group Clipse—a former duo that was comprised of Pusha T and No Malice—which is centered around asking God for forgiveness and showing gratitude for his many blessings.

This track is an updated version of the scrapped Yandhi track, “Law of Attraction.” While the two share many similarities, noticeable differences include a different chorus and vocals from the aforementioned rap duo. It also removes the original vocals from Ant Clemons, a then rising artist who was heavily involved in the creation of the original Yandhi.

This track marks the first joint effort between No Malice and Pusha T since No Malice’s August 2013 track “Shame the Devil.”
genius_annotations:
[('Caught with a trunk of Barry Manilows
 They sing a different tune when the slammer close', [["Barry Manilow is an award-winning singer-songwriter and producer.



It’s not unheard of for dealers to use celebrities' names as slang for certain drugs; especially ones that come in powder form. For example Miley Cyrus has become synonymous with MDMA, while both Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera were used interchangeably as code for crack and cocaine. The term “white girl” is also common.

No Malice uses Manilow’s name in a similar way, playing on his known affinity for showtunes and the phrase “sing a different tune,” denoting a tendency to snitch once someone is behind bars."]]), ('They all say they real ’til it’s time to appraise it
 I seen them come and go, you only the latest
 But who am I to judge? I’m crooked as Vegas', [['Pusha T utilizes some clever wordplay surrounding jewelry appraisal, which seeks to determine the value and authenticity of diamonds or metal. The concept of being “real” or earning “street cred” is a significant part of hip-hop history.

Pusha also plays on the idea of judgment—perhaps in the religious sense of the word—using Las Vegas as a metaphor for his own shortcomings. Interestingly, he also has a song called “Alone In Vegas,” which appeared on his debut mixtape, Fear of God, released in October 2011.']]), ('How could He not be the greatest?
 In my bed, under covers when undercovers had raided
 My presence is happy belated
 Fashionably late, I’m just glad that you made it
 The best is yet to come, I’m just glad that you waited', [['Pusha T is well known for his coke lines and history of drug dealing. He juxtaposes his success as an artist and vice president of G.O.O.D. Music with his previous position in life—one of vulnerability as a pusher of illegal substances—attributing his good fortune here to the titular Jesus Christ. This comparison sparks some wordplay between the word “undercover,” meaning a clandestine government agent, and the image of being comfortable under a blanket.

While there is no record of a federal drug raid orchestrated against the rapper, he has discussed hypothetical scenarios throughout his extensive catalog. For example, on March 2011’s “Raid” he says:

Every time a nigga wanna try and turn a profit
Folks rush in, three letters try and stop it
F-B-I-R-S, D-E-A']]), ('A lot of damaged souls, I done damaged those
 And in my arrogance, took a camera pose', [['Echoing some of the sentiments his younger brother, Pusha T, expressed on his latest album Daytona, No Malice confesses that his past history of drug dealing has ruined the lives of those who were consumers of his product.

Pusha T infamously used the photo of Whitney Houston’s bathroom at the height of her drug addiction for his Daytona album cover.



Although Push did not offer an explanation for why the photo was chosen, it may be clarified by his brother’s line here. While drug dealing offered an avenue to opulence and financial success, it ruined the lives of many, including Whitney Houston.

However, No Malice is ashamed that his arrogance caused him to repress the feeling of guilt of damaging the lives of others and continue living the life of a celebrity in front of a camera.

This sentiment, along with fear of being caught by law enforcement, lead No Malice to retire as a rapper. Like Kanye, he later mended his relationship with God and started recording gospel music.']]), ('Just hold on to your brother when his faith lost', [['No Malice’s brother, Pusha T, and Kanye collaborated on the 2013 song “Hold On” which explores the tribulations of sinning and losing faith while trying to survive in disenfranchised environments.

When one of them begins to lose faith, Push and No Malice always have each other to lean on.']]), ('They give you Wraith talk, I give you faith talk', [['The Wraith is an iconic car model made by British automobile manufacturer Rolls Royce. The car is frequently mentioned in hip-hop and can be seen referenced in the tracks of rappers like Takeoff and Meek Mill, who flex the car as a sign of wealth due to its enormous price tag.

However, No Malice contradicts the materialistic ideologies given off by these rappers by explicitly stating that this track and record are from a pure, spiritual standpoint.']]), ('Blindfolded on this road, watch me faith walk', [['No Malice compares himself to the likes of Saul, who was blinded by a grand light on the way to Damascus, recorded in Acts 9:3:

And as he journeyed, he came near Damascus: and suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven.

Through this journey, he aims to “walk by faith,” a phrase from 2 Corinthians 5:7-8 meaning to fully depend on God:

7 For we walk by faith, not by sight. 8 We are confident, yes, well pleased rather to be absent from the body and to be present with the Lord.

Note that the story of Saul’s transformation into a devout Christian was one inspirational element for Kanye’s 2016 album The Life of Pablo.']]), ('From the concrete grew a rose', [["No Malice alludes to 2Pac’s famous lyrical poem, “The Rose That Grew From Concrete,” from his posthumous November 2000 album of the same name. The poem is an allegory about finding unlikely success in spite of a troubled past:

The rose, it grew from concrete
Keepin' all these dreams
Provin' nature’s laws wrong
It learned how to walk without havin' feet

No Malice also employs the imperfect homonym of “Rolls” (compared with “rose”) to foreshadow the next bar, which references the Wraith, a car model made by Rolls Royce."]]), ('We call on Your blessings
 In the Father, we put our faith
 King of the kingdom
 Our demons are tremblin’
 Holy angels defendin’
 In the Father, we put our faith', [['In James 1:17, the writer shares all blessings come from God and Him only:

Every good and perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of the heavenly lights, who does not change like shifting shadows.

Kanye brings up both sides of the spiritual battle: demons, who are angels that have rebelled against God and serve Satan, and angels, who are servants of God, the King of the kingdom. James 2:19 gives us a picture of demons, trembling in fear of the almighty God:

You believe that there is one God. You do well. Even the demons believe—and tremble!

Psalm 91:11 shares that God sends angels to defend His children:

For He will give His angels charge concerning you, to guard you in all your ways.']]), ('Use this gospel for protection
 It’s a hard road to Heaven', [['From the first live experience playing of JESUS IS KING in Detroit, Michigan, to the third and final listening experience in New York, the lyrics were changed from “Grab your armor for protection” to “Use this gospel for protection.”

The gospel, the good news of Jesus Christ, gives protection against the schemes of the devil. The armor of God is a metaphorical image of protection in spiritual warfare, seen in Ephesians 6:10-18. The specific pieces of the armor are synonyms for the gospel truths.

Verses 11-17 encourage Christians to fight the battle against the devil and his evil schemes with the gospel, specifically using the armor of God:

11 Put on the full armor of God, so that you can take your stand against the devil’s schemes. 12 For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the powers of this dark world and against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms. 13 Therefore put on the full armor of God, so that when the day of evil comes, you may be able to stand your ground, and after you have done everything, to stand. 14 Stand firm then, with the belt of truth buckled around your waist, with the breastplate of righteousness in place, 15 and with your feet fitted with the readiness that comes from the gospel of peace. 16 In addition to all this, take up the shield of faith, with which you can extinguish all the flaming arrows of the evil one. 17 Take the helmet of salvation and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God.

Matthew 7:13-14 talks about the difficult road to heaven:

13 Enter by the narrow gate. For the gate is wide and the way is easy that leads to destruction, and those who enter by it are many. 14 For the gate is narrow and the way is hard that leads to life, and those who find it are few.']])]

genius_description:
“Hands On” continues the spiritual themes seen all over Jesus Is King, and features Kanye speaking on God being “hands-on” in Kanye’s life. The track features gospel singer Fred Hammond.

The track was first previewed by Kanye at his Fox Theatre performance on September 27, 2019, where he announced Fred would be featuring on the track.
genius_annotations:
[('Told the devil that I’m going on a strike', [['Kanye could be making a reference here to The Temptation Of Christ, which is a story from the bible describing how Jesus went into the desert and fasted from food for 40 days, while the Devil tempted him to turn stones into bread. This likely means that Kanye is telling the devil that even though he has been working for him his whole life, that now he is going to go on a hunger strike, and the devil still wont be able to tempt him. This of course all symbolizes the fact that he is leaving his old secular and indulgent ways behind to become more Christ-like, and that he will not be tempted back into a life of sin.']]), ('Hold it down, all fallen down', [['Possible reference to his 2004 song ‘All Falls Down’ where in the chorus he says “when it falls down who you gon call now?”
By saying “all fallen down” he can be saying that all his issues he’s been dealing with are finally taking a fatal toil on his mental.
In the song he asks “ who you gon call now… when it all falls down”.And in the song he never got a definite answer who will be there for him in his darkest hour.
He could be impying that he realized hes the only person that can be there for him at the end, another illusion to the theme of existential loneliness .
At the end he still pleads for someone to pray for him and save him from his thoughts.']]), ('Change, he ain’t really different', [['This is a double (maybe triple) entendre that goes with the previous line.

1) This is how onlookers refer to those that have gone through the BS “Born-Again Christian” experience just to save face in some aspect of his/her life. This is what some will inevitably say about Ye.

2) Ye is telling us that his least favorite thing is a hypocrite.  He is also letting us know that, although he has been down a crazy path, his message has remained unchanged. Do not forget that this man’s first single was “Jesus Walks”.

3) Although things have changed drastically since Jesus walked the earth, the message from God remains the same.']]), ('Man, you’re never seein’ home and you never see the domes', [['The domes built on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem and in particular the Dome of The Rock are icons of Jerusalem in the modern mind. These domes were built by Muslims starting in the 7th century but visually they have come to be synonymous with Jerusalem.



Ezekiel 5:5 So said the Lord God: This is Jerusalem; in the midst of the nations I have placed it, and around it are lands.

Jerusalem is considered in Scripture to be the center of the world.

In this lyric, Kanye says that Christians have made him feel like he has been cast out of his home and cast out from Jerusalem to the outskirts of the world.']]), ('To sing of change', [['Most will be skeptical that Kanye is changing nor believe Kanye has changed. However, most Christians know change is difficult and slow. Becoming Christian doesn’t instantly grant you a new brain that knows all the teachings of Christ. Christian means following Jesus, which means taking up the cross of crucifixion by those whom you are trying to save, and desiring to become like Jesus, which means perfection. This can only be achieved by the aid of the Holy Spirit and via the deep knowledge of Christ’s infinite forgiveness so you can aim for infinite heights like perfection. Without Christ, this is impossible. Philippians 1:21-24, If one isn’t interested in that, they define themselves as no longer Christian.']]), ('Only if they knew what I knew, uh
 I was never new ’til I knew of', [['Following the previous line where he is called a “halfway believer,” Kanye states that he was never “new” until he knew the True and living God. Therefore, prior to fully knowing God and accepting Jesus Christ as his savior, he had not yet died to himself and born again in Jesus.  While he may have been dabbling in Christian themes and beliefs, he himself was not yet “new” and therefore remained susceptible to incongruous behaviors.']]), ('We get called halfway believers
 Only halfway read Ephesians', [["Many who profess their faith publicly in Jesus are incorrectly judged based on past behaviors and not viewed as “fully” Christian, as if their faith is a work in process or merely an act.  Kanye is noting that he is considered by some as a “halfway” believer, which is technically impossible.

The book of Ephesians is roughly halfway through the New Testament and largely deals with how the gospel story affects believers' everyday lives.  The first half of Ephesians (chapter 1-3) are mainly theological (belief), the second half (4-6) is more life application (practice). Kanye may be stating that he is still working through the application of his faith to his everyday life."]]), ('Nothing worse than a hypocrite', [['Kanye has been called a hypocrite by the Christian community for having an explicit, materialistic discography while claiming to be a Christian.

This line can be viewed from either Kanye’s perspective: that he is denouncing being a hypocrite, or the Christian perspective: Kanye is referencing this to point out how he is treated even though JESUS IS KING is a clearly gospel-oriented album.']]), ('[Verse 1: Kanye West]', [['Multiple lines in this verse have drawn parallels to lines in Drake’s contribution on Travis Scott’s 2018 track “SICKO MODE.” In his second verse on the track, Drake supposedly disses and threatens Kanye.

For example, the first line of this verse draws very many similarities to Drake’s line:


Cut out all the lights, He the light (Kanye)

Cut the lights (Yeah, what?), paid the price (Yeah) (Drake)


Another example include of parallelism is:


Made a left when I should’ve made a right (Kanye)

I crept down the block (Down the block)
Made a right (Yeah, right) (Drake)


A final example is:


Told the devil when I see him, on sight (Kanye)

Niggas think it’s sweet (Nah, never), it’s on sight (Yeah, what?) (Drake)


Lines in Kanye’s verse also seem to represent a response to the situation Drake raps about in general, threatening to come to Kanye’s house at night but not ending up committing any acts in the end:

Nothing worse than a hypocrite']]), ('Made a left when I should’ve made a right', [['“A wise man’s heart inclines him toward the right, but a fool’s heart toward the left.” (Ecclesiastes. 10:2)']])]

genius_description:
“Every Hour” is the opening track of Kanye West’s ninth album, JESUS IS KING. The intro details how important the Lord is in every waking moment of believers' everyday lives.

This is the only song on the record that does not contain any vocals from Kanye, exclusively featuring vocals from the Sunday Service Choir. Kanye initiated Sunday Service as an ongoing worship event in Calabasas, California on January 6, 2019.
genius_annotations:
[('Praising the Lord, praise God in the sanctuary', [['A direct quote from Psalm 150:1.

Praise the LORD! Praise God in his sanctuary; praise him in his mighty heaven!

Kanye and his choir want to sing and worship so loud, that it reaches God in His highest, most sacred location.']]), ('Sing ’til the power of the Lord comes down', [['“Sing ‘til the Power of the Lord Comes Down” is a traditional Gospel hymn. It is also known as “Oh Let Us Sing” or “Now Let Us Sing”. The original composer is unknown.



The image of singing and worship is a strong biblical theme. In the Psalms, worshipers sing of God’s power, as well as calling it down, and in Revelation, there are visions of mass choirs of the redeemed singing God’s praises in heaven.


But as for me, I will sing about your power. Each morning I will sing with joy about your unfailing love.
- Psalm 59:16 (NLT)

Open the heavens, LORD, and come down. Touch the mountains so they billow smoke.
- Psalm 144:5 (NLT)

This great choir sang a wonderful new song in front of the throne of God and before the four living beings and the twenty-four elders.
- Revelation 14:3 (NLT)']]), ('Let everything that have breath praise God', [['A direct quote from the book of Psalms.

Let everything that has breath praise the Lord.
Praise the Lord.
- Psalm 150:6

This line and theme is a common inspiration for worship songs. It is a traditional Gospel hymn, popularised by recording artists such as Twinkie Clark-Terrell in 1996 or Matt Redman in 1998.']])]

genius_annotations:
[('Tell me who, who’s the other girl?', [['“The Scarlet Letter” is a novel by Nathaniel Hawthorne that tells the story of Hester Prynne who conceived a child through an affair and learns to cope with her guilt. Because she has committed adultery, she is required by law to wear a scarlet “A” on her chest for the rest of her life to show that she is an adulteress. Prynne is also forced to stand on a scaffold for three hours to be ridiculed and shamed by the townspeople.

Throughout the novel, Prynne’s husband searches for the identity of the father of her child so that he could have revenge. Both singers seemingly allude to this when they ask, “who’s the other girl?” Similarly, the pearl mentioned in the chorus may be an allusion to Hester’s daughter, Pearl, who is a constant reminder of her “sin.” In addition, in chapter 7 of the novel, Pearl is portrayed as “the scarlet letter endowed with life,” which was a description of her red dress. As the singers have confirmed that the song is about a cheating partner, these lines also reflect their dislike and distrust of their partner.

Later in the novel, the “A” that Hester is forced to wear comes to stand for “able” instead of “adultery,” removing all the negative connotations of the letter. Prynne later voluntarily wears the “A,” as it now signifies dignity and grace instead of guilt. She artistically embroiders the “A” into her clothing, which many people come to admire. This idea of dignity ties in with the theme of the song, which Halsey explained in an interview with The Boot:

…there’s so much music in the world about cheating partners…People wanna pin it on the other girl, and make it the other girl’s fault, so it was so cool for us to be coming together and being like, “You know what? Forget him. We’re not gonna hate each other.” To be clear, this is a fictional event. But just us representing those two sides of women in the equation, being like, “No, we’re not gonna let misogyny turn us against each other, instead we’re empowered.”



Halsey wearing a shirt with the scarlet “A” from “The Scarlet Letter”']])]

genius_description:
In this song Khalid is singing about a girl who is going through tough time, has family issues and her parents don’t care. They are absent and Khalid cares about her in ways her parents don’t care/didn’t take the time to learn about her.
He could also be talking about a girl who is a stripper or an escort, with the second verse supporting such a theory by sounding like a cliché stripper story. Khalid understands her and cares despite her situation and job.

This song could also be about the negligence of her parents. They let her do whatever, and never really took time to bond with her and understand her.
genius_annotations:
[('Saturday nights, light gray Silverado
 You drive it ’cause you have to', [['In these two lines, Khalid is referring to the Chevrolet Silverado. The Chevrolet Silverado is a series of full-size and heavy-duty pickup trucks manufactured by General Motors.

General Motors introduced its first pickup truck in 1930. It took 40 years of manufacturing vehicles before the term “Silverado” was first created.']]), ('Saturday nights, blueberry cigarillos
 Swishers make my throat hurt
 Rolling OCB’s on the side for me
 Light ’em up and let ’em both burn', [['In the opening lines of his first verse, Khalid sets the mood with a reference to Swisher Sweets Cigarillos, a brand of cheap tobacco products that first surfaced in 1959. Swisher is known for their sweet, sometimes fruit flavored, cigar products.

He also mentions OCB brand rolling papers, established in 1918 and considered one of the world’s largest rolling paper manufacturers. In the song, Khalid describes the activities that him and a girl, presumably his girlfriend, do without her parents knowing. In this instance, it is tobacco— or marijuana use.



A blueberry Swisher Sweets Cigarillo']]), ('Family feuds, say your mom’s confused
 Off of shit she doesn’t wanna learn
 But daddy’s gone, say he’s never home
 And wishing only makes it worse', [['Using a play on words, Khalid expresses the current culture at home by giving a nod towards American game show ‘Family Feud’.

The show originally launched in 1976 and still aired at the time of the track’s release, hosted by Steve Harvey.']])]

A year after Khalid and Disclosure released their blockbuster collaboration “Talk,” the trio return with “Know your Worth,” an electro-R&B earworm about staying positive and refusing to settle.

“Know Your Worth” is expected to be the third single from Khalid’s upcoming third studio album. He first teased the track on Twitter and Instagram on January 24, 2020, 12 days before it’s release.

genius_description:
“Don’t Pretend” is the sixth official release from Khalid’s second studio album Free Spirit, released on April 5th, 2019.

The track was released just two days prior to the album’s release, with fans around the world having the opportunity to hear the full album earlier by watching the ‘Free Spirit’ short film in select cinemas on the same day.

genius_description:
Kodak Black enlists Offset and Travis Scott for “ZEZE,” a song on which the trio discusses their decadent lifestyles on the song. Produced by Chicago-native d.a. got that dope, this track heavily features steel drum instrumentation.

Following “If I’m Lyin, I’m Flyin” two weeks prior, this is Kodak’s second single since being released from jail in August 2018 and the second single from Dying to Live.

In early September 2018, Kodak posted a now-deleted short clip of him and Travis Scott dancing to the song’s instrumental in the studio. This video became a viral sensation known as the #WaitingChallenge that inspired numerous memes. Kodak later posted another video of just himself dancing to the instrumental.

Kodak performed during the Florida A&M University homecoming festivities on October 5, 2018, and announced the song’s name and release date. One day before the song’s release, Kodak posted the cover art, which revealed that Offset was on the song, which was previously unknown. The song was released as expected on October 12, 2018.

The official music video was released on November 23, 2018. Travis Scott directed the video by himself. The video depicts the three rappers having a problem with the original film director, and hence things are the way they are. It is basically a behind-the-scenes twisted video, showing the three under a green screen and editing their effects.
genius_annotations:
[('Self-made, I don’t owe a nigga nann favor', [['Kodak uses Trick Daddy’s track “Nann N*gga” to express that he made it to the top of the rap game on his own (He’s self made) and he doesn’t own anyone anything, because he did it on his own.']]), ('I don’t say much, I just let the heat talk', [['“Heat” is a commonly used synonym in rap for a weapon, usually a pistol or some other firearm. The word “heat” could also be a reference to Kodak’s costly possessions.

Rather than bragging or starting trouble with his words, Kodak would prefer to let his actions and his weapon speak for themselves.']]), ('Sleepin’ on the palette turned me to a savage', [['He is referring to how he a common occurrence in the projects – sleeping on a bed made from industrial palettes. This lifestyle is destined to harden anyone, in this case turning Kodak into a savage person.']]), ('Your jewelry water whip, diamonds like re-rock', [["Kodak is calling his diamonds abundant, like “re-rock,” a term used for a large slab of cocaine. This creates wordplay on both diamonds and rocks. However, others' jewelry are not iced out but simply water, therefore lacking diamonds."]]), ('Mean-muggin’ got me clutchin’', [["“Mean-muggin'” is a term used for when someone gives another person a threatening look. In this sense, Offset says that others glaring at him results in him “clutchin'” or in other words, having a gun on him at all times."]]), ('Pop pills, do what you feel, I’m on that zombie (Hey, hoo)', [['Here Offset is saying that everyone has their vices, for some it’s pills, and in Offset’s case it’s zombie, which is another term for lean. Lean also commonly referred to as “Purple Drank” and “Syrup” is a recreational drug that has grown in popularity and has been endorsed by several rappers. It is a Codeine based drug that mixes Sprite (or other drinks) with cough-syrup and may include lollies such as Jolly Ranchers.

“Zombie” could also be a reference to Kodak’s mention of the Zoe Pound gang in the chorus.']]), ('I’ma bust her wrist down ’cause she cute (Ice, ice)', [['“Bust” or “bust down” is slang for adding diamonds. He uses a similar phrase on his October 2017 track, “Ric Flair Drip”:

Going to the jeweler, bust the AP, yeah']]), ('When I pull up in the Buick, you know what I’m doin’', [["Buick may be scoffed at as a B-rate car company nowadays, but the company has a historic relationship with rap. The 1973 Buick Regal is referenced in Rae Sremmurd’s “Black Beatles”:

I’m a fuckin' black Beatle, cream seats in the Regal

It was also mentioned in Lil Uzi Vert’s song “Enemies” and even Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright”. This Hypebeast article discusses the Regal and other common cars in rap.

The Buick is also considered a “burner car” that can be gotten rid of after participating in illegal activities."]]), ('We from the Nawf, straight out of the dungeon (We from the Nawf, hey)', [['“Nawf” and “Nawf Atlanta” are phrases coined by the Migos referring to North Atlanta, namely Gwinnett County. The concept is delved into in more depth here on his hit, “Ric Flair Drip” and the Migos have dedicated a whole track to it, named “Nawfside”. On “Bad and Boujee” Offset raps:

We from the Nawf, yeah, dat way']]), ('And we got more stripes than the ref, he foul, TEC him (Bow, stripes)', [['To earn one’s stripes is to gain acceptance in a group such as a gang.

Often earned by killing someone, someone with more stripes than the traditional black-and-white outfit of football referees likely has their share of respect.



Using the same referee terminology, Offset threatens that any misstep (“foul”) will result in meeting the “TEC”, short for the Tec-9, a firearm popular among criminals.

https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-7e5ee2336fc20a40a8bcc923114becb6

This latter term “TEC” however, is a play on words, referring also to a “technical” foul in basketball, often referred to as “techs” and “Ts” and usually gained through undue violence, as would occur when gaining your stripes.']])]

genius_description:
“Higher Love” marks Whitney Houston’s third posthumous release, and her first in over six years, following her death in February 2012.

Houston originally covered Steve Winwood’s signature song in 1990, but the track was only included on the Japanese edition of her third studio album, I’m Your Baby Tonight. It wasn’t until 2019, when the song was re-worked with production from Kygo, that her cover gained worldwide attention.

genius_description:
Lil Baby and DaBaby team up on “Baby,” a song which marks their third official collaboration following “Baby Shower” and “Today (Remix).” Released as a single for Quality Control’s compilation album Control the Streets, Vol. 2, “Baby” turned out to be the most popular track on the project—it performed high on the charts and was supported by the release of a music video that has quickly garnered tens of millions of views.

On the Wheezy-produced track, the two “Baby” artists trade bars about their upbringing, accomplishments, and relationships with women. The two artists rap about representing their respective cities and address their lifestyle: their tough come-up in a difficult environment has left its marks on their daily lives, which are marked by dangerousness and opulence.
genius_annotations:
[('You would think it’s Mardi Gras, I got these bitches showin’ titties', [['Mardi Gras is held in New Oreleans and there is a tradition where you buy beaded necklaces and if you give a female the necklace, then she has to show her breast to the person who gave her the beads']]), ('[Verse 2: DaBaby]', [['In December 2020, an old snippet of Lil Baby previewing the song resurfaced. The unreleased version includes a second verse from Lil Baby, but it was left off the final track for unknown reasons.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hUZshup3rYk']]), ('’bows', [["‘bows, especially with the apostrophe, suggests 'elbows,’ a shorthand for LB, or “a pound of marijuana.” This serves as a tie-in with Baby still selling reefer in spite of having a couple million, makin' classics, and hanging with four or five killers."]]), ('On stage with the Glizzy', [['Glizzy is a slang for a Glock, a semiautomatic handgun, ubiquitous among gun enthusiasts for its famed reliability, ergonomic superiority, and relative affordability. While Baby continues to keep it real with his people, he is prepared, should he have to cap somebody– even during a stage performance.']]), ('Baby prolly still sell reefer', [['Despite having amassed fame and fortune, Baby nonetheless is suspected to keep it real by remaining close to his humble roots selling cannabis, the lowest-grade of street drug.']]), ('We was in the hood, sellin’ bags, shootin’ choppers
 Fucked around and tried to go and lease a helicopter', [["Whilst in the trap, Lil Baby reflects on “shootin' choppers,” that is, firing AK-47’s or a similar semiautomatic rifle (designed to “chop” down enemies), but he turns this into a pun about presumably being sufficiently fucked up (or audacious) as to try and rent the other kind of chopper, a.k.a. a helicopter."]]), ('Yeah, rest in peace to Bankroll, show ’em how to do it', [['Lil Baby pays tribute to Bankroll Fresh, who was a rapper who blew up after releasing his tracks “Hot Boy” and “Walked In.” Unfortunately, he was tragically gunned down on March 4, 2016.

Coincidentally, both Lil Baby and Bankroll Fresh are from Atlanta, Georgia. This line is also a reference to Bankroll’s September 2014 track “Show Em How To Do It.”']]), ('Private plane, Wi-Fi, on the FaceTime with Johnny
 I told him ice my wrist up, I like to hold my fist up', [['DaBaby shouts-out famous celebrity jeweler Johnny Dang, owner of Johnny Dang & Co. and best known for creating diamond studded grills and customized diamond watches for rappers such as Travis Scott and Kanye West.

DaBaby’s current grill that is featured in his album cover on his debut album Baby on Baby was made by Johnny Dang.



Speaking to DJ Small Eyez he mentioned why he chose Johnny to create his grill saying:

All the rappers go get they shit done you know, people spend a lot of money with him and it gotta be for a good reason.

This isn’t the first time Johnny Dang has been featured in a Quality Control song. In 2017’s “Ice Tray,” Johnny appeared in the music video.']]), ('Wheezy outta here', [['This is the producer tag of Wheezy, who has collaborated with Young Thug and Migos on numerous tracks previously including “Guwop,” “Floyd Mayweather,” “White Sand,” “Chanel (Go Get It)” and many more.']]), ('I’m really a millionaire, still in the projects', [["Lil Baby boasts about his exorbitant wealth, which is evident due to his net worth of approximately $4 million. Despite his newfound wealth, Baby still lives in Atlanta, Georgia and reps his impoverished neighborhood. On his August 2018 track, “Need Mine,” he described his come up in the game and his faithfulness to the streets:

Came up out the trenches a millionaire, a nigga damn near made it
Ran it up and lost it all again, damn near drove me crazy

In a verified annotation on his November 2018 track, “Global,” Lil Baby described his transition to fame and fortune:

The adjustment from coming where I come from to where I’m at now is like I’m still adjusting. I haven’t even made the full adjustment ‘cause it happened so quick. But still, I ain’t get like a deal then I’m like a millionaire. I grinded up on a million dollars. That shit felt great ‘cause I’m like 400, 500, 600, 700, 750, go back down, go back up, then you become a millionaire. You be almost a millionaire before you be a millionaire 'cause you already in the midst of it then once you really become a millionaire, you already be grindin’ so hard you damn near be like, “I deserve it, I deserve it.” The way I got mine. That first million."]])]

genius_description:
Released on September 17, 2019, as the second single from his second studio album Certified Hitmaker, “Stuck in a Dream” became one of Seattle rapper Lil Mosey’s biggest hits to date. The track features fellow rapper Gunna and production from frequent Mosey collaborator Royce David. The song’s lyrics address Mosey’s blinged-out lifestyle and drug usage, with the “dream” being the result of taking xanax and lean. Lil Mosey later addressed his drug usage:

I don’t take drugs no more. Xanz, drugs in general, just be killing people. That shit just, mentally and physically, is not good for you. It’s just putting people in bad ways of how they think and I just seen it happen to a lot of people. So, I’m just trying to figure shit out before it’s too late.

“Stuck in a Dream” peaked at #62 on the Billboard Hot 100, spending a total of 4 weeks on the chart. A music video for the song premiered on September 17, 2019, the same day as the song’s release.
genius_annotations:
[('Ayy, Royce, you did it right here', [['This line is the producer tag of Royce David, the producer of this track.

The producer tag doesn’t have any significant meaning. Royce David spoke upon his tag in his “Noticed” Deconstructed video:

That tag is from this old ass song that’s not even released. Mosey just, I don’t know why he said it, but he just said “Ayy Royce, you did it right here"
https://youtu.be/zd6DXrsO25Q?t=4m2s']]), ('My young niggas pull up and shoot like the Magic (Prrt)', [['I’m trying to bring the Sonics back though. However, by the time I get enough money for me, I’m going to bring it back as if nobody else brought it back. Then I’m going to be the one to bring it back for sure. I shoot like the team, it’s like Magic how the way he pulled up and just push him away that fast.']]), ('Last year was broke, this year flooded a Patek', [['I made that song like a year or longer ago. So like a year from that time I was really broke. Yeah, I got it. Before that, before I signed it, I had not even fucked, since I was like sixth grade, fifth grade, like how old is that? Like I was probably like 11, 10 or something. I used to tell my mom like, “Mom, you, I don’t want you to pay for this. I got you mind. I don’t want you to do that.” I’ll just tell her like, “You wonder why I do this? You got things you got to focus on. I want you to start spending your money on yourself. Like you don’t need to fuck. Like I got myself.”  I knew my family didn’t have shit. I tried to do what I do. That’s why I feel like I grew up faster than a lot of other people because I didn’t have nothing like my whole life. I was broke for real.']]), ('Never been a lame, ain’t shit to make her top drop', [['I think I was just born with it. Partly my dad might’ve been a pimp, but I think I was just born with it. I love the females and they love me so I ain’t being disrespectful.']]), ('I was off a bean, the Tech made me Wock’ talk (Talk)', [['But like when you off a B, I talking about Molly and it only happened one time. One time I was off a B and then I had some green high tech and pour that bitch up and these is like in a real like daydream for like just hearing like I was hearing my Bose talk and I was just replying, like they was hearing me talk, they was hearing each other to talk and we just kept talking like, “What you say? You ain’t saying nothing?” It’s like damn, this shit crazy.']]), ('Six on a new fit, fifty for a drop-top (Drop)', [['I be styling a lot from stylists, so I don’t really be knowing a lot of prices and I don’t even really look at the receipt for real cause I’m like, I’m just going to buy it anyway so it don’t even matter. I’m going to see my card afterwards. I’m going to know how much I spend. In the Gucci a tennis, the tennies on. I don’t know specifically which one it was just the Gucci drip.']]), ('Then I got a new Patek, yeah', [['I don’t got the Patek on me right now, but the Patek Phillipe, if you compare the different watches, like the AP Rolex, the Patek, is to me it looks better and it’s more expensive than some of the other ones you feel me? To me, having that one is like, you’re the boss.']]), ('I got these bands, ain’t shit changed', [['It’s been a year, two years I been signed the deal, I been already did that. For me, nothing’s changed. I still bring my same niggas around. I still got the same brothers, but, if I’m not near you no more, if I’m not around you, that means you did something wrong. Because I definitely wouldn’t have snitched on you for no reason because this money don’t mean shit to me, it don’t bring happiness. You got to find happiness in whatever you can, you know, whatever makes you happy.']]), ('I got these diamonds, my chain swang', [['I always looked at jewelry like art, that shit different. That shit fire, that shit makes you look different. You just look better. Not better than other people, but you know, you just look good. It just feels good to have it on, you feel me, but I’m not, I’m probably not going to keep buying jewelry. It’s not even worth it. I want to still buy some more pieces, but once I’m really racked out and I just got, I don’t really care no more.']]), ('Been knew I was the one (One)', [['Even before this music shit, I always knew I’m definitely different, if they’re not thinking how I’m thinking these other kids, they’re not sitting here thinking, “Oh, by the time I’m fourteen I’m trying to be this, I’m trying to do that.” They’re not thinking that. I had to work to be the best because you got to be, you always want to be the best and you got to be the best because you obviously can’t be the best, but if you think you’re the best and you know you’re putting in work to be the best, then you’re going to be up there, but you want to be the best.  I’m definitely different and my minds on some whole different level. I just knew I was different than everybody else, as a little kid from like a while ago.']])]

genius_description:
“Ransom” is the sixth single released by Lil Tecca. The music video was filmed by Cole Bennett and the track was produced by Nick Mira and Taz Taylor.

Throughout the song, the teenage artist shares some braggadocious lines about designer gear, diamonds, and riding in multiple luxury cars, like a Ghost and a Phantom.
genius_annotations:
[('I got lots of shawties tryna pull up to my place
 But you ain’t want me last year, so just get up out my face
 They all up in my inbox, so I know they want a taste', [['To all the girls that have slid in my DMs and I haven’t responded, I’m not your type. We both know this. Leave me alone. I’m not texting you back. They ain’t want me three weeks ago. Last year, or all that.']]), ('I know they want my downfall, lil’ nigga, are you laced?', [['Everybody want my downfall but, I mean, it’s not in your control. You feel me? You laced. You out of here. Like, “Bro, leave me alone.” Like, “Where did you come from, bro?” That shit.']]), ('I want all the diamonds, I want that shit to weigh a ton
 The opps, they tryna line me ’cause they hate the place I’m from', [['I don’t think I get hate from being from New York. I don’t really know where my hate comes from. I don’t really see a lot of it. I just be chilling, for real. Niggas just be watching. People don’t support you but they won’t even hate on you, but they still just watching. They plotting. “All right, what’s his next move? We don’t care but we just want to watch.” Just in case, niggas be just trying to plot.']]), ('I started from the bottom, you could see the way I stunt', [['I didn’t really have a rough upbringing but it’s just everything that I have now, I didn’t have that at a point. Everything that I have now, my parents didn’t have at a point. It’s a difference. Got to appreciate everything.']]), ('I needed me a die or rider, I need me the one', [['I said “die or rider” because I was going to say “ride or die” but the syllables didn’t fit so I just flipped it and then it fit.  And then I don’t do multiple girls. You feel me? I’d rather just one instead of a bunch. It’s not really all that.']]), ('The Chanel or Balenciaga, Louis and Vuitton
 She know I got the Fendi, Prada when I hit Milan', [['I like fashion brands, clothes, but I don’t be wearing hella of it. But I like it. They’re nice, but I was just adding wordplay. Just fitting what works together.  I have never been to Europe or nothing.']]), ('I got red, I got blue, what you want?', [['That’s just adding to the spectrum. That’s just showing black and white, red and blue. You feel me? They both two at the ends of each spectrum, red and blue at the end of each spectrum.']]), ('I see two twin opps, leave ’em on a banner', [['The opps is people that be hating and I don’t even know them. I’ve never even met them, never seen them in person, nothing, and they just hating on me. They know everything about me and I don’t even know these people. “Where did you come from?” type shit. You feel me? The opposition. Those the opps.']]), ('Turn you to a dancer', [['Bro, I don’t have no straps for nobody. I don’t got no straps. No, no straps around here.']]), ('I know that I’m gone', [['In the sense that I know I’m going, I always had that mentality, even since people doubted me and everything. I was like, “All right. You don’t want to support me? Don’t try to swim on the wave when it’s going.” You feel me? I know what I’m doing. You niggas don’t see the vision. I see it.']])]

genius_description:
With assistance from The Internet co-founder and former Odd Future member Syd, Uzi raps about needing love on “Urgency”, the 13th track from his long awaited project Eternal Atake

Prior to the release of EA, this track had already been hinted at in the “Renji” cover art, which revealed that Syd was featured on the record.

This track ends the “Renji” section of the album and marks the beginning of the “Uzi” section. Uzi confirmed this on Twitter the day of the album’s release.
genius_annotations:
[('Treat my darkskin like my redbone, yeah
 Tell my redbone call my red phone
 It’s emergency
 I hit you up just with that urgency', [["The term redbone refers to a light-skinned (mixed race, a black and white offspring) person. Lil Uzi is saying he’s equal with how he treats his girls. Hittin' up his light-skin girl for an emergency booty call.

These lines also serve as reference and a sequel to his 2017 song “20 Min” where Uzi sang:

She call my phone with emergency (Ayy)
She call my phone with that urgency (Ayy)"]]), ('Keep on tryna take my persona (Huh?)
 Bite me up like a piranha (Bite)', [['Lil Uzi Vert, who is one of the biggest names in modern hip-hop, has helped bring popularity to emo rap and has become an inspiration for many rappers who thus attempt to “bite” his style, with “bite” being a slang term which means to copy or to imitate something.

Uzi compares these rappers biting his style to the teeth of a piranha, an omnivorous fish that is known to have razor sharp teeth which are capable of tearing flesh from bone when biting. This is not the first time he has mentioned the fish, as on his unreleased track “Stay,” he raps:

Told that bitch bite on my dick like piranha (Yeah)']]), ('I’m outside in the black truck, jump in', [['Syd references Uzi’s Rhino GX here.



Uzi is known to have bought the Rhino GX in August 2018. https://twitter.com/rapallstars/status/1026701688407842816?lang=en

Other notable artists have bought the Rhino GX including 2 Chainz and the late XXXTentacion.']])]

genius_description:
“Homicide" is the third single released from Logic’s 2019 album, Confessions of a Dangerous Mind.

The track exhibits Logic and Eminem’s rapid-fire flows. The title seems to assert that they are lyrically murdering their detractors and non-lyrical rappers.

In a 2018 interview with HardKnockTV, Logic shared his thoughts on Eminem and his desire to collaborate with him:

It was awesome […] to be recognized by one of my favorite MCs of all time, one of my favorite artists […] I fuck with him. I want to work with him. I want to do a song with him. I think that could be pretty cool.
genius_annotations:
[('Big bills like a platypus', [['“Big bills” refers to having a lot of money, as Eminem acknowledges in the previous line, while a platypus is an Australian animal noted for its duck-like bill.']]), ('You gon’ make Bobby attack
 You gon’ make Bobby Boy snap
 You gon’ make Bobby Boy snap (Bobby Boy!)', [['Logic’s legal name is Sir Robert Bryson Hall II, but he goes by Bobby—a common nickname for Robert. Logic released a mixtape in 2016 under the moniker Bobby Tarantino, and a sequel in 2018.

In 2019, Logic also changed the name of his record label, originally Elysium Records, to BobbyBoy Records. This joint venture with Def Jam includes artists John Lindahl, Damian Lemar Hudson, Big Lenbo, Kajo and Silas. When discussing the change on social media, Logic said:

I really feel like BobbyBoy has become an empire. From books, film, television, and it’s just been a beautiful creative space. And I want that name and brand to mean something, so I’d rather have all of my endeavors, kind of, in one place.']]), ('Your shit is ass like a tailbone', [['A tailbone refers to the coccyx. This arrangement of bone is located at the lower part of your spine and also considered to be vestigial, or without function.']]), ('No, this ain’t a diss to the game, this a gas to the flame
 Nowadays, everybody sound the same, shit’s lame
 Like a moth to the flame, I’ma reel ’em in and kill ’em', [["Logic isn’t throwing shade at members of the game itself, he’s instead hyping it up to bring more attention to the style that he sees as repetitive.

After all, this is something he’s been saying since the days of Young Sinatra: Welcome To Forever. Specifically on “5AM,” he raps:

These rappers' records comin' out, they so repetitive

He also utilizes the idiom “like a moth to a flame,” which concerns being attracted to things that are destructive."]]), ('Or you’re trapped in your cell phone
 Or my chicken scratch, or my self-loathe', [['“Chicken scratch” is a slang term for writing. It’s sometimes hard for others to read it. Eminem mentioned his chicken scratch before on October 2013’s “Rap God”:

So I wanna make sure somewhere in this chicken scratch I scribble and doodle enough rhymes']]), ('I stay on my toes like the repo, a behemoth in sheep’s clothes', [['A repossession occurs when an owner of a vehicle misses too many payments on his car loan, and the bank that issued the loan comes to take the car. “Toes” is a homophone of “tows,” and connects to the repo man, who typically tows the car away.



Eminem also plays on the phrase “a wolf in sheep’s clothing”—someone who appears nice but has ill intent. However, the Behemoth—a creature found in Job 40:15, is much larger.']]), ('From the East Coast to the West, I’m the ethos and I’m the G.O.A.T
 Who the best, I don’t gotta say a fuckin’ thing, though
 ’Cause MCs know', [['Fans and media outlets like HipHopDX consider Eminem to be one of the “Greatest Of All Time.” In fact, Neilson Soundscan named him the “Artist of the Decade” between 2000 and 2009.



Meanwhile, “ethos” means the ‘spirit of a culture, era, or community,’ and it’s also one of the Aristotelian modes of persuasion—the appeal to authority. An ‘ethos’ argument attempts to convey that the speaker is credible because of his status, skills, or experience. It may also be worth noting that a ‘logos’ argument is one that applies logic, or an appeal to reason.']]), ('Y’all couldn’t hold a candle at a prayer vigil
 When I vent, they compare me to a fuckin’ air duct', [['“Can’t hold a candle” is an idiom that dates back to the 1600s, when incompetent apprentices who lacked coordination couldn’t hold a candelabra properly for their master to see things in the dark. In modern times, the phrase means that one thing doesn’t compare to another.

Em also compares his venting—which is the act of releasing stress or anger through words or actions—to a ventilation system, which never stops releasing air.']]), ('Fuck rap', [['Logic first expressed this distaste for the hip-hop community on his November 2015 song “City of Stars,” and again on his September 2018 song “ICONIC”:

Real talk, fuck rap
I hate and I love it ‘cause it’s so negative
Everybody selfish, nobody wanna give
A helping hand to the next man, well, fuck you then']]), ('Hol’ up, I said “Rover” because now your Rover is red
 Like Red Rover, so you know what I meant
 But I roll over my opponents instead', [['These bars may relate to Suge Knight, who ran over two men in March 2015 while driving a red Ford Raptor, which some media outlets mistook to be a red Range Rover.

Red Rover is a game where people hold hands and an opponent runs in between the linked hands in an attempt to breakthrough. If the player breaks through, he can take either of the two people, whose link he broke, back to his team. If he fails to break the link, he must remain on the side where he failed. The game ends when one side has all the players.

Rover is also a common dog name, and dogs perform tricks like roll over.']])]

genius_description:
For the third single off Tickets To My Downfall, Kelly enlists the support of rapper blackbear as they both sing, as the title states, about hooking up with his ex’s best friend.

The song sees MGK questioning if it’s okay to get it on with this girl but being too drunk to worry about it. Musically, the song features live guitars and live drums (a staple of pop-punk) from Travis Barker while incorporating classic hip-hop sounds like autotune and fast programmed high hats.

This isn’t ​blackbear’s first venture into pop-punk. In early 2020 he was featured in All Time Low’s single “Monsters”.

And treat this night like it’ll happen again']])]
