genius_description:
The existence of the remix of the original “Girls Like You” was initially confirmed in a tweet by the band:
https://twitter.com/maroon5/status/1001866378100359168

Leaving the original vocals & production intact, Cardi adds a Bronx-flavored verse to the pop record, rapping about having danced for dollars & being the life of the party among other things.

The remix also gained its own music video featuring several idolized women across an array of fields.

In September 2018, the song topped the Billboard Hot 100, becoming Cardi’s third #1 single, and Maroon5’s fourth. The song dethroned the uber-popular “In My Feelings”, by Drake, which led the pack for ten weeks.

On February 11, 2019, “Girls Like You” logged its 33rd week in the top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming the sixth single in the chart’s history to stay in the top 10 for that long. The song currently matches Ed Sheeran’s 33-week run of “Shape of You” in the top 10.
genius_annotations:
[('Know it’s really real if I let you meet my mama (Eeoow)', [['Usually when couples meet each other’s parents things seem to be getting serious.']]), ('I don’t play when it comes to my heart, let’s get it though', [['Carbi B already made a similar statement in her song “Be Careful":

Be careful with me, do you know what you doin'?
Whose feelings that you’re hurtin' and bruisin'?']]), ('I’m sure them other girls were nice enough
 But you need someone to spice it up
 So who you gonna call? Cardi, Cardi', [['Cardi directs these lines toward her then-fiancé Offset; his past girls satisfied him, but he needs danger and fun in his life, which she can bring.



Cardi addresses these unique qualities in her recent collaboration with Bad Bunny and J Balvin, “I Like It”:

They call me Cardi Bardi, banging body
Spicy mami, hot tamale']]), ('I’m coming to you now doin’ 20 over the limit (Wooh)
 The red light, red light stop, stop (Skrrt)', [['Cardi got engaged to Migos rapper Offset in early November of 2017. As soon as she found her other half, she quickly accepted the ring.

However she realizes that she may be rushing it and she needs a moment to think it through. The “skrrt” ad-lib resembles the sound of screeching tires.']]), ('Roll that backwood, babe,', [['Backwoods are a brand of cigar notable in the 1970s and 1980s for their heavy advertising, at a time when public perception on smoking health was changing.



In recent years, Backwood cigars have become notable for their use in marijuana culture. The combination of marijuana and tobacco scent makes users feel extra buzzy. Rapper Mac Dre has become known for popularizing them.']]), ('But every other girl you meet is fugazy (Okurrrt)', [['Cardi is saying that most girls in today’s society aren’t real, they are fugazy, which means fake or damaged beyond repair. This term was created during the Vietnam War and it was used to describe anything that was “fake” or “counterfeit”.

Cardi is implying that unlike these other girls, she is real. This line may also be a reminder to her husband Offset, of the Migos, that she is better than any of the other girls that he has allegedly cheated on her with, which is something Cardi discussed in her interview with Cosmopolitan.']]), ('Come and rev it up like a Harley, Harley', [['Harley Davidson is a prestigious motorcycle company established in Milwaukee, Wisconsin founded by William Harley, Arthur Davidson, William Davidson, and Walter Davidson in 1903. Esteemed by both bikers and rappers for its spectacular power, this motorcycle group has been popularized in the rap game primarily by Illinois-based artist Ludacris.']]), ('I play with this kitty like you play wit’ your guitar, ah', [['This is a rather lewd term to describe masturbating. Cardi is claiming that the technique she uses to masturbate is similar to the stroke of someone playing guitar – fast-paced and finger intensive, just like strumming.



She uses the word kitty as a synomym for pussy, which is actually a synonym when talking about cats.']]), ('I don’t really want a white horse and a carriage (Carriage)
 I’m thinkin’ more a white Porsches and carats', [['In this line, Cardi is referencing a popular conception of marriage: a white horse and a carriage. Cardi is saying she doesn’t want that lovey-dovey type of wedding–she would rather have materialistic goods and money. Porsche is a famous German luxury vehicle manufacturer whose cars can run you up to $2 million.

In the Regency era, owning a carriage was a sign of wealth, and having a well-matched team of horses to pull it was akin to having “his and hers” Porsches and a massive wedding ring as a sign of wealth in the 21st century. Cardi may be interpreted as saying here that she doesn’t want an old-fashioned kind of love, she wants something new and modern.



A carat is a unit of mass for gemstones, while karat is a fractional measure of purity for gold alloys. Cardi is likely referring to carats as the size of her diamonds, as she flashes her ring to the camera during this line.']]), ('Why is the best fruit always forbidden? (Huh?)', [['Forbidden Fruit is a phrase that originates from the Book of Genesis. In the book, Adam and Eve eat the fruit of knowledge of good and evil, despite having been commanded by God not to. As a metaphor, the phrase typically refers to any indulgence or pleasure that is considered illegal or immoral.']])]

genius_description:
Miley Cyrus teams up with British singer Dua Lipa on “Prisoner,” the fourth track from Cyrus' seventh studio album Plastic Hearts. The song was released as the album’s second single on November 19, 2020, a week before the album’s release.

The song, which interpolates Olivia Newton-John’s 1981 track “Physical” (just like the Dua Lipa track of the same name), is about being in an abusive or controlling relationship in which one person manipulates the other to stay, causing them to feel like a prisoner.

“Prisoner” was also included on Future Nostalgia – The Moonlight Edition, the re-issue of Dua Lipa’s highly successful sophomore album. The re-issue was released on February 12th, 2021 via Warner Records, and is featured as the fourteenth track of the record.
genius_annotations:
[('I tasted Heaven, now I can’t live without it
 I can’t forget you and your love is the loudest', [['This is not the first time Miley has hinted that she has tasted the sweetest love. On her 2017 song, “I Would Die For You”, she has compared her lover to the sweetest of the tastes:

You’re sweeter than candy and better than any childhood dreams

In contrast to the rest of the song, which implies that she’s been a prisoner, here she hails her lover, implying that she can’t forget them because their love is the best.

Although it is not confirmed that the song is about them, Miley and Liam were the OTP. Their relationship lasted for almost 10 years, and several magazines has named them “the cutest” when together.



Therefore, it is safe to say that these lines where Miley implies that “their love is the loudest” may be a reference to her longest and most enduring relationship (since in the end of the accompanying music video, she gives a nod to her exes, meaning that the lyrics were inspired by her personal life).']]), ('I try to replace it with city lights', [["While Dua provides vocals for this line, it bears a striking similarity to Cyrus' 2019 hit “Slide Away,” written about her breakup with ex-husband Liam Hemsworth:

Back to the ocean, I’ll go back to the city lights

Dua emphasizes how she tried to replace her feelings towards him by returning to the city-scene and lose herself in energetic moments."]])]

genius_description:
Moneybagg Yo and Megan Thee Stallion go all out for their collaborative track “All Dat.”

The Southern pair rap about how there’s no better match for them in a defensive delivery.

From the moment Megan Thee Stallion and Moneybagg Yo went public with their relationship, they haven’t been shy when it comes to showing off their affections toward one another. The rappers often take to their social media pages to fawn over each other, so it didn’t surprise fans when they announced that they were joining lyrical forces to drop a collaborative effort.

The pair released their single “All Dat” at the stroke of midnight on Thursday morning, accompanied by a music video. The only people in the video and Megan and Moneybagg as they enjoy spending one-on-one time together in an expansive, luxury, hilltop home. On the track, they each go verse for NSFW verse as they drop bars about what they like to do to—receive from—the other in the bedroom.

So I had to Google his name an then I’m like oh he a baseball player, okay. They run home, you know, I know something about like, first base, second base, home base. Something about home. Sometimes people don’t do their research and I ain’t going out like that.']]), ('Chopper sing like Aretha, might cost your life to meet her', [['I just salute any woman, period. Like, not just Aretha. Any woman period. Rapper, singer, I just feel like any woman in the industry just paved the way for me. But  I did say Aretha’s name a lot, like, dang.']]), ('And I got that KO, I’ma fuck around and sleep ’em', [['I got that good good. You know when Ciara was talking about her Goodies? Yeah, I got that cookie jar, baby. I got that NyQuil. I got that double cup.']]), ('These niggas know that I’m a keeper', [['I’m a keeper because I’m a real ass, rich ass bitch from the South. Come from good foundation, a good home. I know how to cook.']]), ('Ran down on a bitch, all the sudden she got amnesia', [['When you check the little thotpockets in person, they don’t be on that. Period.']]), ('Aretha with them Franklins', [['Shout out to the OGs, all the women that came before me, Actors, singers, rappers, whatever, entertainment business period. Shout out to all them, they made a path for me. And I’m just trying to get them Franklins like Aretha. That’s all.']]), ('Rappers in my DM, I ain’t fucking for a feature', [['People, they laugh when I say that line or whatever. Like, they be like, “Oh that’s what’s up?” But, it’s like, that’s real life. Men in the industry, period–not just rappers, promoters, DJs, producers, whatever-they feel like in order to work with you, you gotta do something. And I’m like, huh? This is Big Latto. What you saying? You little boy. Sit down, boy. On a serious note, that’s how it go in the industry.They just be feeling like females owe them something in return for they work, or whatever. It make it difficult depending on what type of person you is. For me, it’s like my way or the highway. Like, okay then we just won’t work then. Next. See you at the top. You gonna wish you would have worked with me.']])]

genius_description:
NAV and Gunna reunite with Travis Scott on “Turks,” the second collaboration between the three artists all on the song, following the featured artist’s August 2018 song, “YOSEMITE.” The three artists have also each collaborated individually with one another, as detailed below in the Q&A. This song also serves as the lead single to NAV’s third studio album, Good Intentions.

The title of this song refers to Turks & Caicos, which are a group of islands that are located southeast of the British Overseas Territory. The three artists tell a rags-to-riches story over the Wheezy-produced upbeat tune, discussing the transition from them being poor to eventually living a lavish lifestyle. They drop references to many expensive items that they possess, including cars, drugs, jewelry, weaponry, and women.

This song’s official music video premiered on NAV’s YouTube channel three days after its release, on March 30, 2020. Young Thug, a close friend and frequent collaborator of the three artists, makes a cameo appearance. The video was directed by NAV’s XO Records founder and manager, Amir “Cash” Esmailian.
genius_annotations:
[('She sweet, I was movin’ off a Perc’
 I bought her a Birk’ and a birthday cake (Birthday cake)', [['Birkin, a French luxury fashion goods manufacturer, was founded by Thierry Hermès, who also owns the French luxury brand Hermès.

Gunna has expressed his love for the bag countless time on tracks such as “Hot”, “Pink Toes” and “Vibes on Vibes” while also naming a song, “Baby Birkin”, after the accessory.



Jordyn Woods with a Birkin bag in Gunna's "Baby Birkin" music video']]), ('Twenty racks don’t feel like nothin’ to me', [['A “rack” is a thousand dollars so “twenty racks” is $20,000. In 2019, it was estimated that NAV’s net worth was $1.5 million, making $20,000 a small amount of money in comparison.']]), ('Trappin’ on the block, I’d never serve a cop', [['“Trap” means to sell drugs so Gunna could be implying here that he doesn’t want to sell drugs to a cop. He could also mean he wouldn’t “serve” or give information to the cops about anything or anyone.

Gunna has his reasons for not liking the police—in June 2018, he and DJ were arrested after drugs were found in his car.']]), ('Came from the streets, it turned me to a beast', [['NAV is likely calling back to his chorus on the late Pop Smoke’s February 2020 track, “Wolves,” where he similarly raps:

Yeah, I was raised in the jungle, it turned me to a beast

NAV was born and raised in a low-income household in Rexdale, a rough neighborhood in Toronto. Rexdale is notorious for having its high rate of gang-violence and thefts. NAV, however, stayed out of trouble as a child and has no known difficulties with the authorities.']]), ('Pullin’ out fifty racks, walkin’ out of Chase', [['JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A or just Chase Bank is a national bank that’s headquartered in Manhattan, New York. It’s one of the “Big Four” banks in the United States. A “rack” is a thousand dollars so “fifty racks” is $50,000.']]), ('Keep me a razor when I’m in the East
 Open ’em up just like a surgery', [['It’s possible that NAV is talking about how Toronto is located in Eastern Ontario. Rexdale–NAV’s hometown–is a rough neighborhood located in Toronto, full of gang-related crime and thefts.

NAV keeps a knife for protection and compares using it to that of a surgeon, who slices through their patients with a scalpel while performing surgery.']]), ('Cactus Jack me up and down, head to toe', [['Cactus Jack Records is Travis Scott’s record label. In 2019, Cactus Jack collaborated with Michael Jordan to create the Cactus Jack Apparel Collection so Travis could be saying here that he’s dressed in his own Cactus Jack apparel from “head to toe.“



Travis wearing an Air Jordan 1 x Cactus Jack tracksuit']]), ('Fillin’ her nose with some shit I can ski with', [["Cocaine is a stimulant drug that’s snorted through the nose. “Snow“ is common slang for cocaine, as both substances are white and powdery.

This line is reminiscent of NAV’s line on Travis' September 2016 song “beibs in the trap,“ where he rapped:

Got a white bitch snorting up snow"]]), ('(Wheezy outta here)', [['“Wheezy outta here“ is the producer tag for Atlanta producer Wheezy. It’s voiced by Future and was first used on Lil Baby’s and Drake’s May 2018 song, “Yes Indeed.”

Wheezy has produced for all three artists multiple times before—for example, he produced Travis and Gunna’s August 2018 song, “ZOOM“ and NAV’s March 2019 song, “Habits.“']]), ('Hardly get thirsty, got water like a lake', [['“Water“ is slang for pristine and exceptionally clear diamonds. NAV also used the term on his January 2016 hit “Myself“:

Diamonds in my pinky, look like water, make me seasick']])]

genius_description:
A week before the release of the songs “Chun-Li” and “Barbie Tingz”, Nicki Minaj appeared in a Mercedes-Benz commercial, and the hip-hop instrumental used in the commercial was later revealed to be this song according to a tweet by Nicki herself.

https://twitter.com/NICKIMINAJ/status/1025841969434509312

On November 4th, 2018, Nicki performed “Good Form” along with her Little Mix collaboration “Woman Like Me” at the 2018 MTV European Music Awards.

In October of 2018, the viral #GoodFormChallenge was started by Nicki herself to help promote the song. The challenge consisted of people sharing videos of themselves twerking or dancing to the song’s beat, something similar to many other viral-dancing challenges like the #KekeChallenge from “In My Feelings” or the #MannequinChallenge from “Black Beatles”.

https://twitter.com/NICKIMINAJ/status/1055958345692016641

Nicki released the “Good Form (Remix)” featuring Lil Wayne on November 27, 2018.
genius_annotations:
[('Back of the ’Bach, back of the ’Bach
 Back of the ’Bach, back of the ’Bach', [['Back of the Bach refers to the Maybach. In https://genius.com/4257977, where Drake raps when he checked her out. Back of the Bach also refers to https://genius.com/7173773 where she raps about how she thought https://genius.com/artists/Meek-mill caught feelings for her. Nicki owns a Maybach.']]), ('Suck me off', [['For a person to lick/suck the genitals of a person of the opposite sex or even same sex if they are homosexual until that person ejaculates.']]), ('Floss', [['to show off, especially things of high value']]), ('Odyssey', [['A Honda minivan that only over-protective soccer moms want to drive but their teenage kids get stuck with as their first car. Early 2000 models looked like giant hearses.']]), ('Valet', [['One who parks vehicles for those who can afford to pay the high price for such a service.']]), ('I slick, slick drop the top like nip slips', [['“drop the top” refers to when the roof of a convertible car is folded down.
“nip slip” is when a woman’s nipple is accidentally exposed. This can occur when a woman’s top drops or lowers.
Nicki used a simile comparing the way she lowers her converitble roof to a nip slip.']]), ('See, I pull the strings like a tea bag', [['Like a puppetmaster who controls the strings behind the scenes, Nicki Minaj has all these rappers in the industry under her control. The “strings” mentioned are both puppet strings and tea bag strings. “Tea” is a slang word for drama as well.']]), ('I’m the baddest B, I don’t even know how to speak', [['Nicki hereby declares that she’s the baddest bitch while also playing on the word “bee” as in “spelling bee”.

A bee is supposed to be extraordinarily good at spelling whereas Nicki assures us that she’s that bad of a bee that she can’t even speak. In this metaphorical context she also confirms this by using the false superlative form of the word “bad” – “baddest”, instead of “worst”.']]), ('I’m prolly with my jeweler playin’ freeze tag', [['The comparisons between diamond-encrusted jewelry and ice are quite common within the Hip-hop community, and Nicki is certainly no stranger to it. On “Sir,” she raps:

Icy Patek, tell ‘em, “Kiss my ass, sir

Nicki also mentions “Freeze tag,” a game played mostly by children. During the game, when a player tags opponents, they are forced to “freeze” in place as if they are stuck in ice. Nicki’s constantly getting frozen from her jeweler, as buying jewelry is much like a game for her. She often enjoys meeting up with her jeweler so she can try on new pieces.']]), ('So he tryna smash like when the whip flips', [['Nicki describes the power of a man’s desire to have  sex with her (or “smash”) using a simile of a very bad car accident.

Nicki used a similar simile on the song “Handstand”  from her 2009 mixtape Beam Me Up Scotty.

genius_primary_artist: Nio García, Anuel AA & Myke Towers
genius_annotations:
[('Más de 24, en el sexo un bachillerato, yoh
 Si dice que no fuma e’ un teatro
 Se toca y me manda los retrato’', [['En una entrevista hecha por el youtuber argentino Boffe, publicada en julio de 2020, Nio habló sobre estas líneas en las que se refiere a su mujer:

Es que es impecable, es como si lo hubiese estudiado, como si hubiese nacido inteligente. Si dice que no fuma es mentira, es como que me está corriendo de bobo. Son pocas las veces que me manda foto, pero casi siempre las borro rápido, está todo esto de los hackers, y no confío en los celulares. Pero sí, hay veces que llevo dos semanas de viaje y necesito una foto y toda la vaina, no la puedo ver por Instagram na’ má’, por Facetime.

https://youtu.be/Tw1CpNaTFIc?t=540']]), ('Y me compré una’ Air Force, ni Footlocker la’ tiene', [['En una entrevista hecha por el youtuber argentino Boffe, publicada en julio de 2020, Nio explicó esta línea:

Ya cuando hago el remix, todo el mundo sabe que las Air Force Supreme salieron, super difícil de conseguir en ese momento, yo las conseguí, me maté por conseguirlas, soy fanático, las colecciono. Cuando las compré dije “uff”.



Nike Air Force Supreme']]), ('[Verso 2: Nio García]', [['En una entrevista hecha por el youtuber argentino Boffe, publicada en julio de 2020, Nio habló sobre la aparición de un verso suyo en el remix, y explicó por qué en la versión original no había:

No le escribo verso en la original porque no encontré qué escribirle, qué hacer, hace tiempo no tengo tenis nuevas, no tengo nada, no sé qué escribir. El tema se escucha bien así, tengo los dos points, tengo intro y coro, vamos a soltarlo así: se pegó. En el momento de soltarla no tenía de qué hablar, pude haber llamado a cualquier persona que escribiera, pero no, ¿para qué voy a hablar de un intro y coro que tiene mucho que ver conmigo y en el verso no tiene nada que ver conmigo? Hasta que en el remix logré hacer algo que me llamó la atención.

https://youtu.be/Tw1CpNaTFIc?t=404']]), ('Las Air Force son brand new
 Las moña’ verde’ como mi Sea-Doo', [['En una entrevista hecha por el youtuber argentino Boffe, publicada en julio de 2020, Nio García, creador de estas líneas, explicó las mismas:

El que me conoce sabe que mis Air Force siempre son nuevas, me encanta tener las Air Force blanquitas, blanquitas, blanquitas. Las moñas hacen referencia al cannabis, que son verdes como mi jet-ski “Sea-Doo”. Todo lo que hablo en “Jeepeta” es completamente vivido por Nio García.



Sea-Doo color verde

En la canción original, Nio era quién cantaba estas líneas, pero en el remix se las cedió a Anuel.']]), ('Arrebata’o, dando vuelta en la jeepeta (En la jeepeta)
 Al la’o mío tengo una rubia que tiene grande’ las teta’ (Las teta’, eh)
 Quiere que yo se lo meta
 Arrebata’o, dando vuelta en la jeepeta (En la jeepeta)
 Conmigo una rubia, tiene grande’ las teta’ (Grande’ las teta’)
 Quiere que se lo meta
 Arrebata’o, dando vuelta en la jeepeta', [['En una entrevista hecha por el youtuber argentino Boffe, publicada en julio de 2020, Nio García, creador original de la canción, explicó estas líneas:

Todos mis fanáticos saben que medicinalmente fumo cannabis y ese día estaba fumando, y obviamente pongo “arrebatao dando vuelta en la jeepeta”, porque estaba dando vueltas por ahí, porque es que no había luz. “al lao mio tengo a una rubia que tiene grande las teta” estaba hablando de mi mujer. Luego, creo que me dejé llevar un poco por el sentimiento de lo que te conté antes: estábamos en un lugar chichorreando, bebiendo entre parejas, algo muy hot, y no soy fanático de buscar metáforas ni palabras que te digan lo que yo quiero explicarte, es esto y ya. No siento que le estoy faltando el respeto, estoy entrando en un sentimiento erótico, de parejas, obviamente ella quiere que se lo meta, soy su marido. Mucha gente malinterpreta pero a ella le gusta que yo le hable así en esos momentos. En ese momento que estoy en la Jeepeta con mi mujer dando vueltas, quiere que se lo meta, ya, es la que hay.

https://youtu.be/Tw1CpNaTFIc?t=118']]), ('Tú ere’ mía y ya, me va’ a hacer casarme como Nicky Jam', [['El cantante puertorriqueño Nicky Jam se casó por primera vez en febrero de 2017 con la modelo Angélica Cruz, pero se divorciaron después de 18 meses de matrimonio.



 Nicky Jam con su ex-exposa

El 15 de febrero de 2020, Nicky Jam se comprometió con Cydney Moreau, una modelo estadounidense que Nicky conoció durante la grabación del videoclip de su colaboración con Sech, “Atrévete”.



 Nicky Jam con Cydney Moreau en el estreno de Bad Boys For Life']]), ('Yo no soy el más que canta ni el más que entona
 El género no trata de eso (Quiere que yo se lo meta)
 Yo soy el mejor, ¡brr! (Arrebata’o, dando vuelta en la jeepeta)', [['Anuel hace alusión a las pautas utilizadas por Héctor “El Father” en su tema “Sola”, tema que ocupa el track número 4 de su álbum The Bad Boy, estrenado en el año 2006:

Oye, yo no soy el más que canta, ni el más que entona
Yo soy el más que sabe de esto
¿Oíste?

https://youtu.be/mM7UbKQpfmg?t=152']]), ('Baby, Real G foreva, fumando hachí’ (Real G, G)
 Ya estoy tan arrebata’o que veo a Lilo y a Stitch', [['Lilo & Stitch es una película de dibujos animados hecha por la productora Walt Disney Pictures estrenada en el año 2002.

La trama tiene como protagonistas a Lilo, una niña hawaiana de 6 años y a Stitch, un extraterrestre experimental considerado como malvado. Ambos se conocen cuando Lilo adopta a Stitch, confundiéndolo con un perro y desarrollan una fuerte amistad a lo largo de la película.

Como ambos personajes son ficticios, Anuel da a entender que debido todo el hachís que fumó ya no distingue la realidad y se imagina al lado de personajes imaginarios.']]), ('Mami, yo quiero la combi completa (¿Ah?)
 ¿Qué? Chocha, culo, teta (Uah)', [['Anuel hace una interpolación a la canción “En La Cama”, interpretada por los puertorriqueños Nicky Jam y Daddy Yankee, parte del álbum Haciendo Escante de Nicky.

Y es que yo quiero la combi completa
¿Qué? Chocha, culo, teta

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QgZcLdDR7qw']]), ('¿Por qué no hacemo’ una porno como Ozuna? (Uy)', [['Anuel hace referencia al video pornográfico de Ozuna que salió a la luz a principios de 2019. Ozuna, en una entrevista,  confirmó que hizo el video tan comprometedor por una necesidad económica. Se lo extorsionó cuando era menor, y una de las personas que hizo eso fue Kevin Fret, un fallecido rapero puertorriqueño. Al mismo tiempo que salió el video, Kevin Fret fue asesinado en Puerto Rico; no obstante, la policía declaró a Ozuna limpio de alguna relación con su muerte. Después de que el video llegó al público, Ozuna le pidió disculpas a sus fans en Calibash Las Vegas.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BtIP9QflDbY/']])]

genius_description:
Farruko, Anuel AA, J Balvin y Daddy Yankee se juntan a Ozuna en el remix de “Baila Baila Baila” para hablar de una chica que se distanció del amor porque la trataron mal en su antigua relación; sin embargo, quieren que ella olvide sus malas experiencias, haciéndola sentir como nadie nunca lo hizo antes.

“Baila Baila Baila” es el segundo sencillo del tercer álbum de Ozuna, llamado Nibiru.
genius_annotations: [('Solo por un beso como Aventura, mami, hazlo por la cultura', [['Así como lo dice en la canción, Anuel cita el título de una canción de Aventura, “Solo Por Un Beso”, para dejarle dicho a la chica que se está esmerando tanto en hacerla feliz para ganarse al menos un beso de su parte.']])]

genius_description:
Al igual que en la canción original, los intérpretes hablan de una relación amorosa en la que comparan a la pareja de quienes hablan con el dulzor de un caramelo, describiendo su belleza y el agrado que les provoca el estar con ellos.

El remix de “Caramelo” fue dado a conocer por primera vez el 14 de julio de 2020, día en que Ozuna hizo un video en directo agradeciendo por el gran recimiento de la canción original. Al final, mostró un adelanto del remix, diciendo que era una sorpresa.

El 10 de agosto del mismo año, el artista empezó a dar pistas del remix. Primero fue en su Instagram, publicando una foto en la que daba pistas del remix usando emojis: “🍬 R 🔜 🧝🏼‍♀️ 🧔🏾 🧸”. Luego, en Twitter habló específicamente de un remix, para finalmente revelar el supuesto arte oficial el 12 de agosto en Instagram.

https://twitter.com/ozuna/status/1292541021629198336
genius_annotations:
[('Salió de Prada en el jet pa’ Costa Rica (Pa’ Costa Rica)', [['Prada es una marca de alta costura italiana fundada en el año 1913 por Mario Prada. Actualmente la firma ofrece diversos productos para hombres y mujeres, poniendo principal énfasis las carteras y ropa femeninas, razón por la que Ozuna menciona esta marca.

Esta no es la primera vez que el puertorriqueño menciona marcas de lujo en sus canciones. Ya lo había hecho en el año 2018 con “Balenciaga”, interpretada junto a Ele A El Dominio.']]), ('Los panty siempre Fendi', [['Fendi es una marca de lujo fundada en el año 1925 por la diseñadora de moda Adele Casagrande, en Italia. Actualmente la marca confecciona productos para hombres, mujeres y niños, desde poleras a accesorios como bolsos y colgantes

Ozuna habla específicamente que la mujer de la que habla siempre viste pantimedias de esta marca, las que alcanzan un valor de 350 dólares.

Esta no es la primera vez que el puertorriqueño menciona marcas de lujo en sus canciones. Ya lo había hecho en el año 2018 con “Balenciaga”, interpretada junto a Ele A El Dominio.']])]

genius_description:
PARTYNEXTDOOR reunites with his OVO label boss Drake on “Loyal,” an ode to their significant others. They reflect on their respective love lives and the loyalty that their women display.

On November 19, 2019, PND hinted at an upcoming release via an Instagram post, where he used the caption “Friday.” Two days later, he teased Drake’s involvement via his Instagram story hours before its release.

[('One', [['*war

 You’ll see you, you’re my best friend', [['Drake and Party are reflecting on the fact, that despite them being apart from the woman they care about, they will always remain loyally, each other’s best friend.

The line further represents the pair’s loyalty to these women, and despite the even summer’s apart, they will remain faithful to them.']]), ('But I don’t want war with you, or my friends', [['This line represents the tricky dichotomy of a relationship between spending time with your friends or your significant others. Drake and PARTY acknowledge that they want to accommodate both their girls and their friends.']]), ('You, nuh need fi raise war with my friends', [["“Nuh need fi” is Jamaican Patois for “no need for.” PARTYNEXTDOOR—whose mother is also Jamaican—often uses patois in his music. For example, on Calvin Harris' February 2018 song “Nuh Ready Nuh Ready,” he uses patois on the chorus:

Mi and di mandem
We haffi run from half of di gyal dem"]])]

genius_description:
“Hey Look Ma, I Made It” is a tongue-in-cheek celebration of Brendon Urie’s success in the music industry.

As a teenager, Urie’s parents were afraid for his future as a starving artist. Having reached financial stability as a musician, Urie tips his hat to his mother, and reflects on his journey to success, examining the thirst of record labels for new material and the quest to avoid people, who only want to be associated with him due to his fame.
genius_annotations:
[('Hey look ma, I made it
 Hey look ma, I made it', [['These lyrics make up the title of the track. The repeated six words represent Urie saying he has “made it” in the music industry. Often, new artists will be struggling in the industry, and it is quite tough to “make it” and become a successful musician. Brendon’s parents were likely worried that this would happen to him early on, as it does to most who attempt to make a career for themself out of music. However, he ended up becoming famous and successful, which is what most of the song describes. He is finally able to show his parents and the world that he “made it” despite all of the hardships he may have faced.
One could also take these lyrics sarcastically or ironically. Throughout the track, Urie portrays the message of what happens after fame in a tongue-in-cheek manner. The music video shows a puppet taking the place of Brendon as a clear metaphor of others using him as a puppet rather than a human. Many lyrics give sarcastic praise to the effects of fame, which are not in reality valid. He could be saying, “Hey look ma, I made it” as a way of ironically saying that yes, he may have become successful in the industry, but a lot of things are messed up. The cheery sound of the lyrics and tune could lead one to take it all literally, but along with the music video, which shows the puppet version of Brendon progressively getting more messed up, taking drugs, drinking, getting beaten, arrested, and puking. Throughout these visuals, the happy sounding lyrics create a stark contrast, which could also leave the listener to interpret the lyrics sarcastically.']]), ('So I do the deed, get up and leave
 A climber and a sadist, yeah', [['“Doing the deed” is an idiom for sex. These lines continue the analogy of Urie as a hooker working for the record label.']]), ('Ain’t ready for the latest?', [['This speaks about how the fans weren’t ready for the new album. No one knew anything until a few months before the release. Even the record label that he was with said he should just take the year off. Brendon said that he couldn’t just sit still, and worked on songs in-between shows playing Charlie in the Broadway musical Kinky Boots. He would work on his computer during the show, and produced 2 songs.']]), ('I see it, I want it, I take it, take it', [['This line is similar to one in “Emperor’s New Clothes” from Death of a Bachelor.

I see what’s mine and take it

Both lines evoke the idea of Brendon identifying what he wants out of life and doing what’s necessary to gain it.']]), ('And if you lose, boo-hoo', [['Boo-hoo is a phrase meaning “to cry.” In this context, “boo-hoo” carries a sarcastic connotation, as a way to express a lack of sympathy toward someone, who is behaving overly dramatic, and mock them.

Brendon is ready to take on the next chapter of his life. He is prepared to face challenges and rise above them. If other people have a problem with losing, that’s on them.

In “Emperor’s New Clothes”, Brendon expresses a similar idea in the lyrics

Finders keepers, losers weepers']]), ('This world is full of demons stocks
 And bonds and bible traders', [['Stocks and bonds are two ways to make money in the world of investing. Buying a stock in a company now gives the buyer a share in that company while buying a bond entails long-term debt.

Brendon equates the ills of the financial system with those who use religion for self-profit. They are the prominent examples of “demons” in today’s world. This directly links with the main theme of the album’s title to Pray For The Wicked.

“Bible traders” is reminiscent of the short story “Good Country People” by Flannery O'Connor, in which a bible salesman tricks a young amputee into giving him her prosthetic leg and subsequently leaves her on the roof of a barn. Brendon’s use of a bible trader could point to a record label that seems helpful and wholesome but is ultimately indifferent to the artists they represent.

“Bible traders "could also be wordplay also saying Bible Traitors, meaning people who abandoned their religion for a secular lifestyle, or even the notorious traitor, Judas Iscariot.']]), ('‘Cause I’m a hooker sellin’ songs and
 My pimp’s a record label', [["A pimp is most well known as:

a man who controls prostitutes and arranges clients for them, taking part of their earnings in return.

Pimps are also well known for their almost ownership status of their women, often taking advantage of them for personal gain. In this lyric, Brendon is describing his relationship with the recording industry, often taking advantage of artist’s skills for their own benefit.

In an interview with GQ, Urie discusses balancing the personal and business relationship with his label and the “hooker sellin' songs lyric.

That’s just real. I can write these things because I’m good friends with people at my label. We’ve been able to talk and learn from those experiences. Things like that are tongue in cheek, but I’m not totally bullshitting there. I have felt like that in the past until I took control creatively and business-wise. I can make decisions and not just throw myself into the corner. I’m a hooker selling songs: I’m a glorified shirt salesman. I go on the road and hopefully people buy a shirt and see me play."]]), ('In a golden cathedral
 I’ll be praying for the faithless', [['A Cathedral is the principal church of a diocese with which the bishop is officially associated and that contains the Cathedra or  Bishop’s throne.
Cathedrals serve as the central church for members of different dioceses of the same religion.

Urie was raised on a strictly Mormon house even though he grew up to not believe in god.

Here, a golden cathedral would refer to the highest profile a cathedral could get and even there Urie would still hold his stance on religion for himself and others that think the same.

This line was first alluded to during the album promotion. The Panic! team sent out Mystery Potatoes to fans, and some of the potatoes bore the words

Pray!ng for the fa!thless']]), ('In the garden of evil
 I’m gonna be the greatest', [['“The garden of evil” is a play on the Biblical Garden of Eden. The Garden of Eden is a paradise described in the book of Genesis in which Man co-exists with nature and God looks over both. Here, the biblical original sin takes place and Man is thrown out of paradise as
punishment.

Rather than Urie being the greatest in the Garden of Eden, which would suggest his being holy or pure, he reigns over the garden of evil, indicating Urie’s tongue-in-cheek rejection of religion.



The Garden of Eden']]), ('Some are loyal soldiers while
 These other thorns are rosy', [['Is the cup half empty or half full? Some things are a matter of perspective. Do roses have thorns or do thorns have roses? Roses having thorns would say beautiful things may be potentially dangerous while thorns having roses would say any dangerous thing only pretends to be beautiful.

Again, a difference in the sincerity of Brendon’s friends appears in this verse. Some of his friends are truly genuine in their friendship with him. They are the roses with thorns. Others are two-faced in that they only appear to be genuine. Those are thorns that only appear to be rosy.']])]

Heck, it even sounds like a Fall Out Boy line.', 'one of the best songs from the album. props to Brandon', 'I made a piano version (useful as karaoke) with tutorial and sheet music ♡\nhttps://m.youtube.com/watch?v=XCrD9xRUHy8', 'I believe he uses a puppet in the video to show how some music industries control the singers, treating them like puppets. genius_description:
“High Hopes” is about seeking your dreams without hesitancy and seeing those dreams come to fruition beyond your wildest imagination. Having high hopes is a phrase that means to have:

a strong feeling that something good will happen or be true

Throughout Panic! At The Disco’s and Brendon Urie’s career, the band has faced challenges and changes. The beginning of Panic!’s journey was fraught with financial challenges. Brendon Urie, trying to make ends meet, worked in a Smoothie King to support his music career. While creating their iconic “I Write Sins Not Tragedies”, the band could not afford to pay professional string musicians, leaving them to record a middle school band member playing the part one note at a time.

Even with commercial success, the trials of the music industry still plagued the band. From band members leaving and attempting to adapt to a turbulent music scene, Brendon Urie has seen his dream of maintaining success in the music industry fade in and out of view. Despite these difficulties, Urie, now the last remaining member of the band, has continued to strive for his goals and has earned a Grammy nomination, a stint on the Broadway show Kinky Boots, and numerous other accolades.

Upon the song’s release, Brendon revealed his inspiration behind “High Hopes” on Twitter and Instagram, and in the video description on YouTube

I spent too long not setting my expectations high enough, worried about how it felt to fail. I hit a point when I realized I had to aim high and fail, fail, fail in order to keep growing. This one is for all of you who helped me go for it all. I thank you.
- B

The song was released half an hour prior to the due time – 2pm EST – on the official Panic! At The Disco YouTube Channel, racking up just over 1k views, before being officially released via a separate video, and on Spotify.

“High Hopes” is the third single released from Pray For The Wicked. It was preceded by “Say Amen (Saturday Night)” and “(Fuck a) Silver Lining” which were released two months earlier.

“High Hopes” is the highest charting song in Panic! At the Disco history, peaking at number 4 on the Billboard Hot 100, surpassing “I Write Sins Not Tragedies” at number 7 in 2006.
genius_annotations:
[('Stay up on that rise
 Stay up on that rise and never come down, oh
 Stay up on that rise
 Stay up on that rise and never come down', [['Figuratively, staying on a rise means pushing yourself towards success. If you’re always going up, you’ll never have to fall. Ideally, musical artists would like to be at the peak of their careers all the time.

Of course, the lines can also be taken literally. With a literal understanding, one can’t help but to think of the song’s music video.

In the video, Brendon climbs the side of a skyscraper, also known as a “high-rise” building . Once he reaches the roof, Brendon joins the rest of the band to play the rest of the song. Their playing on top of the skyscraper in the music video could be seen as a symbol of Panic! At The Disco’s recent mainstream success. With that interpretation, one could see the onlookers watching Brendon climb from the ground to the roof as the fans of Panic! At The Disco who have stuck with the band since its early days.']]), ('[Chorus]', [['Brendon revealed at the YouTube Live Release Party for Pray for the Wicked that the chorus for “High Hopes” was the first chorus written for the album.

[The chorus] was given to me by a friend [named] Ilsey. She had this whole idea […] and the perfect message. […] It felt just how I wanted to iterate to people about my childhood, making cardboard cutouts of guitars and acting like a rock star.']]), ('So I got one more run and it’s gonna be a sight to see-eh-eh-eh', [['Some people have interpreted this lyric to mean that Pray for the Wicked will be the last Panic! At The Disco album. Brendon Urie addressed this idea in an interview with NME, expressing his desire to continue Panic! for a long time.

[When writing the lyric] I didn’t take it that way, but who knows. I’m so impulsive. I could say that this will never be the last, but I don’t know what’s going to happen tomorrow. […] I don’t have any plans to stop, ever, anytime soon. I want to be like Mick Jagger’s age and still doing it. That’s the dream!']]), ('It’s uphill for oddities
 The stranger crusaders, ain’t ever wannabes
 The weird and the novelties don’t ever change', [['Panic! at the Disco’s introduction into and approach within the music industry has been far from conventional.

As one of the first bands to garner recognition and success through the internet, they were non-conformists in an industry with deep-rooted conventions and expectations, and instead of having little commercial success, they took the world by storm as “stranger crusaders.”

Throughout commercial radio’s musical eras characterized by the dominance of hip hop and pop, Panic! has always opted for “the weird and the novelties” instead. Notably switching from the pop punk and vaudevillian theatrics of their debut, A Fever You Can’t Sweat Out, to the flower crowns and Beatles-inspired psychedelic and baroque pop of their sophomore album, Pretty. Odd., Panic! takes pride in their label as “oddities.”

By following their own interests and disregarding the pressure of their contemporaries, Panic! established a precedent of never giving up in environments that only seem to ostracize them and of never changing themselves at the expense of their quirks and creativity.']]), ('They say it’s all been done but they haven’t seen the best of me-eh-eh-eh', [['Throughout Brendon Urie and Panic! At The Disco’s career, the band has continually changed genre and shifted the status quo. From the 60’s inspired psychedelia of Pretty. Odd. to the electronic, club synths of Too Weird To Live, Too Rare To Die, Panic! has delved into a new sound with each album.

Though some may believe that Panic! has done everything that is possible for a band to do, Brendon Urie believes that only the best is yet to come for Panic!.

The phrase ‘but they haven’t seen the best of me’ is also reminiscent of a lyric in “This is Gospel,” which states ‘but they haven’t seen the best of us yet.’']]), ('Museum victories, every day', [['“Museum victories” refers to paintings of battles that are often housed in art museums. Rulers or military officers would often commission artwork to commemorate their great victories These works of art are typically over the top in their depictions, portraying the victors as shining heroes.

By striving for “museum victories”, Urie continues the theme of seeking out the very best in everything that he does: achieving goals so great that they deserve to have commemorative paintings commissioned in their honor.



John Singleton Copley, The Death of Major Peirson, 1783']]), ('Manifest destiny, back in the days
 We wanted everything, wanted everything', [['The Manifest Destiny was a belief held by 19th-century American settlers that it was their God-given right – or destiny – to settle westward.

‘Manifest destiny’ in the context of “High Hopes” refers to the view that Brendon was destined to be a musician and share his craft with the world.



American Progress, (1872) by John Gast, is an allegorical representation of the modernization of the new west.']]), ('Didn’t have a dime but I always had a vision', [['In the early days of Panic! At The Disco, the band had very little money– only big passions and dreams in music. Their lack of funds can be especially noted in their first album, and most notably in their single “I Write Sins Not Tragedies.”

In an interview on the Zach Sang Show, Brendon shared:

We had ten thousand dollars to do the first album, we had like no money. […] At that point, we couldn’t even get an extra two hundred dollars to pay someone in to come and play trumpet. We had to pay a sixth grader to come in and play trumpet and we recorded each note separately. So if you listen to “I Write Sins Not Tragedies,” first single off first album, we recorded a girl who was, you know, 13, 14 years old, playing cello one note at a time. And we just took them and sampled them basically, played it like an MPC. So we actually did that like, by hand. It was really crazy.

Despite having little money to keep their band and themselves personally afloat, their vision of achieving success was enough to sustain them.

This line also calls back to a similar lyric in “(Fuck A) Silver Lining”:

Was lost in thought but held the vision

This lyric refers to Brendon possibly being overwhelmed or lost, but ultimately remaining set on his goal.']]), ('Burn your biographies
 Rewrite your history,', [['A biography is a work of writing that outlines a person’s experiences and includes intimate details of their life.

The biography mentioned in the lyrics can easily be equated to Panic!’s discography. Throughout Panic!’s career, they have continually ‘burn[ed]’ and ‘rewrit[ten]’ themselves. Each album has been a completely different genre, from the 60’s style of Pretty. Odd. to electronic club beat of Too Weird To Live, Too Rare To Die. This genre fluidity has caused some fans of their music to come and go; however, Panic! has continually abandoned the status quo and created music that has spoken to them.']]), ('Mama said,', [['When describing the sound of the album, Pray For The Wicked, on Instagram Live Brendon hinted that several songs would give a nod to his mother.

Brendon’s mother has inspired him throughout his life, especially concerning music. In a Mother’s Day Instagram post, Brendon elaborates on his admiration for his mother.

I love you, mom. You’re the reason I am who I am today. My nervous energy on stage is from you. Those high notes I sing are from you. My sick dance moves, I got from you. My overly-animated faces I make when someone says they’re taking a picture, yeah I got that from you. Thank you, mom. You are everything. ❤️ #happymothersday

Though a rumor did circulate that his family kicked him out because he decided to pursue Panic!, Brendon has revealed that they were supportive of his choice.

When I told them I wasn’t going to college or on a Mormon mission, that I don’t believe in God and I was pursuing music, they were like, “You’ve gotta move out.” They cooled off, and when we made our first Panic! at the Disco album, I got a care package from my family with this beautiful letter: “No matter what, we will always love you.”



(L,R) Grace Urie (Mother), Boyd Urie (Father), Brendon Urie, Sarah Urie (Wife)']])]

genius_description:
“Into the Unknown” is a cover of the soundtrack’s lead song from the animated Disney musical Frozen II (2019). The song was released by American band Panic! at the Disco as the album’s first single roughly two weeks before the film’s November 22, 2019, release date.

In the movie, the song is originally sung by Idina Menzel, the actress who voices the main character, Elsa, and features Norwegian singer-songwriter AURORA.

According to Billboard, the original song “[gives] voice to a conflicted Elsa as she debates whether to take off on yet another adventure to save the kingdom of Arendelle.”
genius_annotations: [('As I feel your power grow', [['The main, albeit subtle, difference between the lyrics of the P!atD version and original version of Into the Unknown. The original version of this particular line is “as I feel my power grow.” This version that’s shown implies that Jack Sinclair is aiming the line at someone else. Namely, this cover’s version of the voice of Ahtohallan.']])]

genius_description:
El remix de “Calma” es la primera colaboración del puertorriqueño Pedro Capó con su compatriota Farruko. Según él, la canción está inspirada en los días que su madre lo llevaba a la playa cuando era niño. El tema incita al oyente a “cerrar la pantalla” y disfrutar de la playa.

La dupla se llevó a cabo después de que Farru publicó un post en Instagram proponiendo un remix a Capó. Pedro repostea el post ese mismo día, aceptando la propuesta.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BnkaZmgHzdg/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link

El video oficial del remix cuenta con más de mil milliones y medio de reproducciones en YouTube, 470 millones en Spotify y se escaló en la posición número tres en Hot Latin Songs de Billboard. La canción llegó al número uno en 12 países latinoamericanos, así como en Italia, Rumania y Bulgaria.
genius_annotations:
[('Un poco de Bob Marley y unos trago’ ’e sangría
 Pa’ que te sueltes, poco a poquito', [['Bob Marley & The Wailers era un grupo de reggae jamaiquino, que hacía música alrededor de los ‘70s. Junto al reggaetón, el reggae es un género musical que se apega a la temática de playa. La canción y el remix de “Calma” pueden ser clasificadas como reggae.



La sangría es otra bebida alcohólica, hecha a base de vino tinto y jugo de frutas. Es la segunda bebida con alcohol que mencionan en la canción; la primera es la cerveza Medalla.']]), ('Y vámono’ en tropical, por to’a la costa a chinchorrear
 De chinchorro a chinchorro paramo’ a darno’ una Medalla
 Bien fría, pa’ bajar la sequía', [['El término “chinchorro” es típico de las playas puertorriqueñas. Un chinchorro es un local, usualmente ubicado en la playa, en el que venden bebidas alcohólicas. Por lo tanto, el acto de “chinchorrear” significa ir “de chinchorro a chinchorro”.



No es la primera vez que Farruko usa la palabra; en la canción de De La Ghetto “Mirala” con Zion y Farru, él rapea:

Anda con sus amigas, siempre en el jangueo
Se monta en el Polaris, los domingos es chinchorreo']]), ('Y como dice Fonsi, vamo’ a darle despacito (Ya, ya, ya)', [["Farruko alude al tema viral de Luis Fonsi y Daddy Yankee, “Despacito”. Estos dos son puertorriqueños al igual que Capó y Farru, y, al igual que ellos, mencionan su país en la canción:

Despacito
Vamo' a hacerlo en una playa en Puerto Rico"]]), ('Cierra la pantalla, abre la Medalla', [['Medalla Light es una popular marca de cerveza de Puerto Rico; en el video de la canción es posible ver una de ellas.



A algunos esta línea les puede oler a sponsoring, pero Capó explica cómo surgió en realidad:

Fue algo natural, es que Medalla suena a Puerto Rico, a playa. Luego que filmamos el video fue que nos dimos cuenta de que se podría buscar la manera de ir de la mano con la marca, y a ellos les gustó la idea. Pero no, no se trata de un auspicio de la cerveza a mi carrera.']])]
genius_comments: ['This song never gets old for me 😘 😘 😘', 'When Farruko says:“Cierra la pantalla, abre la Medalla”, he is referring to this beer.  The Company named Cervecera de Puerto Rico (formerly known as Cervecería India) is one of two breweries in Puerto Rico. It is located in Mayagüez, Puerto Rico. The company’s main brand is Medalla Light.', 'Farru!!!', 'el cuco']

genius_description:
The Woo’s are a gang alliance of Bloods and Crips in Brooklyn, New York, Pop Smoke’s hometown.

The late rapper popularized the refrain “Woo” and transcended its original meaning to a lifestyle of swagger and luxury. Pop Smoke is typically referred to as the “Woo” and so this braggadocios song is about the women who want to be with him for his lifestyle. Hence his two mixtapes, Meet The Woo and Meet The Woo 2.
genius_annotations:
[('And she only liked the guap, red light these hoes
 Why would I waste my time on a shorty that don’t got me on the front of her mind?', [['Roddy Ricch refers to this girl as a prostitute (red light reference). She only fucks with Roddy because of the wealth and money he has, like a prostitute does, fucking for money. That’s why Roddy doesn’t like wasting his time on girls like this.']]), ('She said, ”Tricks is for kids”, she don’t fall for the tricks', [['50 Cent refers to the iconic sugar-coated cereal Trix and their iconic slogan used in advertisements. It famously includes Tricks, the Trix Rabbit—voiced by Mort Marshall, and later by Russell Horton—an anthropomorphic cartoon rabbit who finds children and wants to trick the children into giving him a bowl of Trix cereal. He bursts with enthusiasm but is discovered every time. The kids always reprimand him with the signature phrase “Silly Rabbit! Trix Are For Kids!”']]), ('[Verse 3: Pop Smoke]', [['Pop’s verse comes from his first verse on his unreleased collaboration with Lil Tjay and producer Drewski “Mary Jane.”

However, Lil Tjay’s adlibs used in the background of “Mary Jane” were cut for the final version of “The Woo.”']]), ('Got that big Birkin bag worth five, six figures', [['This line is a reference to the City Girls’s 2018 track “Act Up” on which JT began her verse by rapping:

Real ass bitch, give a fuck ‘bout a nigga
Big Birkin bag, hold five, six figures

The Hermès Birkin is a purse that many see as a symbol of wealth and elegance. Even on the secondhand market, these bags can cost tens of thousands of dollars. In 2017 a Birkin purse became the most expensive bag ever sold at an auction, costing the winner around $380,000.



A five-figure number is one with five digits, like $50,000. A six-figure number is one with six digits, like $100,000.']]), ('I pull up on her top gone on the Dawn, I’m the don', [["50 compares his girl taking her shirt off to the Rolls Royce Dawn, a 2-door convertible car produced by British automotive manufacturer Rolls Royce.

Despite not actually owning a Dawn, 50 has owned a number of Rolls Royces over the years. Most recently he bought himself a matte orange 2019 Rolls Royce Cullinan for his 44th birthday.

Additionally, 50 is paying further homage to Pop, who has rapped about Rolls Royces numerous times in his music. Pop made a nod to the Rolls Royce Phantom on his fifth track “Gangstas” from Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon where he rapped:

If my opps is chillin' in the foreign (Bah)
Then my niggas shootin' up the Phantom (Bah, bah, bah)

Further, 50 asserts himself as “the don.” Traditionally, “the don” is a term given to the head of a mafia crime family, however, in recent years, the term has colloquially become a term to refer to a man with wealth, power, and respect.

50 has referred to himself as “the don” previously in his music, perhaps most notably on his 2003 hit “Many Men (Wish Death)” where he famously rapped:

I’m like Paulie in Goodfellas, you can call me the Don"]]), ('Hate it or love it (Uh, uh), it’s me and you (Woo)', [["Another reference to a 50 Cent song called ‘Hate it or Love it’

Pop Smoke was a big fan of 50'; Woo often quoted the rapper’s songs, interpolating the entire chorus of ‘Many Man (Wish Death)’ on ‘Got It on Me’

50 Cent also became the executive producer of the Posthumous album by Pop Smoke:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1m1F_lshznk"]]), ('Let me take you to the candy shop (Candy shop)
 Show you all I got (All I got, all I got)', [['Pop Smoke references featured artist 50 Cent’s 2005 hit, “Candy Shop”:

I’ll take you to the candy shop
I’ll let you lick the lollipop
Go ahead, girl, don’t you stop
Keep going ‘til you hit the spot, whoa

50 not only appears on this song, but is also the Executive Producer of Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon.

This is not the only time Pop interpolates 50 on the album as well, as he referenced 50’s May 2003 hit “Many Men (Wish Death)” on “Got It on Me”.']])]

genius_description:
“Mood Swings“ sees Pop Smoke reuniting with Bronx rapper Lil Tjay for a slow-moving track. The two take turns dropping references to their women and expensive items to boast about their lifestyle with fame.

Pop and Tjay made this track the same night they made their October 2019 hit “War,“ a track which was featured on Pop’s 2020 mixtape, Meet The Woo 2.
genius_annotations:
[('Baby, what’s your sign?', [['Tjay is asking her what her zodiac sign is. A lot of people use astrology to determine if they would be the perfect match as a couple.']]), ('I’ll get you everything that you want and that you need from Chanel to Celine', [['Chanel and Celine are both luxury brands. Chanel is a French company producing and creating haute couture, as well as ready-to-wear, accessories, perfumes and various luxury products. The society has originally been created by Coco Chanel in 1910. Celine is also a French women’s ready-to-wear and leather goods company, founded in 1945 by Céline Vipiana, and especially known for its handbags.

Pop already showed his love for the French luxury companies multiple times before, especially with his tube “Dior”, his most popular song. He’s explaining here that he’s ready to pay everything his girlfriend needs and everything she wants, including expensive luxury goods from French companies.']]), ('She a queen, like Nefertiti', [['Nefertiti was one of the most powerful queens in Ancient Egypt from 1353 to 1336 B.C.']]), ('Got up on my Birkin, it’s workin’
 She said she a virgin (It’s hurtin’)
 She my biggest fan, she always lurkin’
 And she know I’m a man, I’ma put that work in
 I know she can’t stand me, I’m fancy
 So I’ma bring her out when I get my Grammy
 Late night sex, she can’t find her panties
 Couldn’t hold it in, now she need a plan B', [['Tjay reiterates lines from the outro of his January 2018 track, “Resume," indicating how this specific girl only plays with his feelings and uses him for his money.

Got up out my Birkin, It’s workin'
She said she a virgin, it’s hurtin'
She my biggest fan, she always lurkin'
And she know I’m a man, I'ma put that work in
And I know she can’t stand me, I’m fancy
So I'ma bring her out when I get my Grammy
Late night sex, she can’t find her panties
I couldn’t hold it in, now she need a Plan B
His bitch need a Plan B
Lil Tjay fancy

Tjay also sang nearly identical lines within his September 2018 hit “Leaked“:

I got up out my Birkin, it’s workin'
She said she a virgin, it’s hurtin'
But she ain’t never show me love when my pockets hurtin'']])]

genius_description:
American artist Post Malone teams up with rising star DaBaby on “Enemies,” an introspective collaboration. Post discusses the way that mainstream fame has impacted his relationships and how he responds to the disloyalty, while DaBaby raps about his newfound success and sends a warning shot to his enemies.

DaBaby teased a portion of his verse and a snippet of the chorus on his Instagram account, an hour before the album’s release.

This track marks the first time that either Post Malone and DaBaby have worked together.
genius_annotations:
[('Laughin’ to the bank like ha, ha, ha', [['Here, Post is talking down on his critics who never thought he could make it as far as he has in the music industry. He is boasting about his wealth, blocking out the criticism as he goes to cash out what would probably be a very hefty check, considering his last LP went platinum.']]), ('When I was shit broke, couldn’t even buy smokes', [['This line is reminiscent of a lyric from Posty’s track “Sugar Wraith” off the 2018 album ​beerbongs & bentleys.

Nicotine fiend, couldn’t even buy a pack, yeah']]), ('[Chorus: Post Malone]', [['The melody of the chorus is reminiscent of Rockwell’s 1984 #2 hit “Somebody’s Watching Me” featuring Michael Jackson. Both songs share a theme of paranoia and distrust. Interestingly, when Post’s Stoney spent its 77th week in the Top 10 of Billboard’s Top R&B/Hip-Hop Album charts, it broke a 34-year record held by Jackson’s landmark album Thriller.']]), ('I just went double platinum with no features
 Just to show a nigga I don’t really need him', [['DaBaby boasts about the success of his featureless March 2019 breakout single, “Suge,” which peaked at #3 on the Hot 100 chart. The single was also certified 2x Platinum by the RIAA on July 16, 2019.

It’s interesting to note that DaBaby’s debut album Baby on Baby included features from four different rappers, such as Offset and Rich The Kid, but his solo songs “Suge” and “Goin Baby” performed better on the charts than those with a guest artist.']]), ('Used to have friends, now I got enemies (Ooh)
 Used to keep ’em close, now they dead to me (Damn)
 Used to have friends, now I got enemies (Ooh)
 Enemies, yeah, it’s so sad', [["In the chorus, Post reflects on how his friends became his enemies when he achieved his newfound celebrity status.

Earlier on 21 Savage’s “all my friends” off the album i am > i was, Post had similar lines:

I lost all my friends countin' bands in the Bentley coupe

It’s common for friends to turn into enemies after a fallout, especially if money is involved. Since Post began his music career and obtained new money, he has since separated himself from those old or untrustworthy friends that were only after his paychecks.

On his song “Paranoid” off his second studio album beerbongs & bentleys he reiterated this:

Even family and friends started switchin'
Ever since I got that check, seen ‘em itchin’
Sometimes feel like I got no friends"]]), ('They’re packin’ the post and I’m home alone', [['Since DaBaby is on a Post Malone song, it makes sense that he would reference him in this line while interpolating the chorus from his breakout 2019 track, “Suge”:

Hah
Pack in the mail, it’s gone (Uh)

Mail stations are commonly referred to as post offices.

DaBaby also references the classic 1990 film Home Alone starring Macaulay Culkin, which IMDB describes as:

An eight-year-old troublemaker must protect his house from a pair of burglars when he is accidentally left home alone by his family during Christmas vacation.



The phrase “Home Alone” is also used as a homophone here. Because DaBaby refers to Posty earlier in the line, “Home Alone” can also sound like “Home Malone,” especially since he pauses in between the two words.']]), ('Friends are like the autumn, every year they leavin’
 And I’ma rake ’em in a pile, throw ’em in a bag
 Tie them bitches up and leave ’em', [["DaBaby is frustrated with the fake friends on his team and suggests that a lot of friendships are merely short term. He compares his friends to the autumn leaves (with the double meaning for leavin' in the first line), which fall off their trees each year in preparation for the winter. Like fake friends, the leaves begin to show their true colors before they fall from the tree, which unveils their deceptive nature. Baby continues the simile by “raking his friends into a pile”, which is the method used to dispose of leaves once they break off their trees."]])]

genius_description: “Die For Me” is a trap-pop banger that features Post and Future lamenting their relationships with untrustworthy women, while Halsey provides a women’s perspective on the bridge. It is Post Malone’s first collaboration with Halsey and his second with Future following the “Congratulations Remix.”
genius_annotations:
[('Remember when you got my ass arrested (Wow)
 At least when I was in jail, I got some rest in (Yeah)', [['Although it’s unclear when or if Post has actually been arrested, he sold a shirt with a mugshot-like photo on his 2018-2019 tour in support of beerbongs and bentleys:']]), ('But that blood in your veins, yeah, I know it’s frozen (It’s so cold)', [['While cold-blooded typically refers to an animal whose body temperature changes to match their environment, it has also grown into slang for someone who’s cruel. Post describes a similar lover on the later Hollywood’s Bleeding track “Take What You Want”:

I feel you crumble in my arms down to your heart of stone
You bled me dry just like the tears you never show']]), ('I heard you comin’ in, I was lyin’ there awake (Awake)
 Didn’t know that it was you, got the gun right out the safe (Damn)', [["Post suffers from paranoia as a result of his success. For instance, according to Forbes, he makes over $500,000 per show during his tours. His house was also broken into after he had moved out of it, back in September 2018.

Post further elaborated on his paranoia on his April 2018 track, “Paranoid”:

Never know when someone comes and tries to take my life
I’ve been sleepin' with the .45 like every night–
–Tell me why I can get no relief (I can’t get no sleep)
Wonderin' when they’ll come for me
A paranoid man makes paranoid plans
I do what I can, but it’s out of my hands
Strugglin' just to find my peace"]]), ('And you don’t have to say I’m crazy
 ’Cause I know nothing’s changed though', [['G-Eazy playfully called Halsey crazy on their November 2017 duet track “Him & I”:

Ever catch me cheating, she would try to cut my (Ha-ha-ha)
Crazy, but I love her, I could never run from her

This “craziness” is often linked to Halsey’s bipolar disorder. In a June 2019 interview for Rolling Stone, Halsey confessed that she was currently in a manic phase, a time where she is more prone to do “crazy shit."']]), ('I sold fifteen million copies of a break-up note', [['As of August 7, 2019, Halsey’s October 2018 single, “Without Me,” is certified 5x Platinum in the US  and has 15 million global adjusted units, according to Capitol Music Group Chairman and CEO Steve Barnett.

On the track, Halsey thows jabs at her ex-boyfriend and rapper, G-Eazy, and calls out his infidelity.']]), ('I came around, I figured out, should follow my gut
 I don’t play anymore, I went through your phone
 And called the girls in your DMs and took all them home', [["Halsey had a similar sentiment on her June 2017 track, “Don’t Play,” where another relationship came to an end:

I’m moving on, I’m getting paid
I’m on my own, I had some space to deal with it
I’m moving on, it’s getting late
Go and grab someone and find a place to deal with it
Yeah, don’t even try
Can’t fuck up my vibe
Double cuppin' in the ride
Motherfucker, don’t play with me

Following her tumultuous on-and-off relationship with G-Eazy, Halsey penned her hit October 2018 single “Without Me.” In a June 2019 Rolling Stone interview she claimed:

he cheated on [me] in front of the entire world, like, a billion times.

According to a June 2018 Daily Star article, during their time together, G-Eazy sent several sexts to an unknown woman in November 2017.

On February 9, 2019, Halsey hosted Saturday Night Live, performing a piano version of “Without Me.” During the performance, the background lit up to reveal walls covered with hand-painted notes, some of which saying:

Ashley I cheated
At home in Los Angeles
In Minneapolis
More places I can’t even remember

In these lines, Halsey alludes to her bisexuality, implying that instead of turning against the other women in the situation, she joined forces to get back at G-Eazy."]])]

genius_description:
On “Take What You Want,” Post Malone enlists the help of fellow rapper Travis Scott and iconic Black Sabbath rocker Ozzy, The Prince of Darkness, Osbourne. The artists take turns discussing a relationship with a girl who broke their hearts. Post’s verse focuses on the emotional baggage of his significant other.

While this marks the first time that either Post Malone or Travis Scott have worked with Ozzy, Post Malone has often expressed his fondness for heavy metal and even used to play in a hardcore band himself.
genius_annotations:
[('And all I ever asked was for the truth (All I ever asked was for)
 You showed your tongue and it was forked in two
 Your venom was lethal, I almost believed you (Almost believed you)
 Yeah, you preyed on my every mistake', [['Telling someone that they have a “forked tongue” is a way of calling them deceptive or manipulative.



Post Malone uses snake imagery to accuse his love interest of misleading behavior.']]), ('I took them stones you threw, made chains for the crew (Ice)', [['To “throw stones” at someone usually means to insult them. The phrase has biblical origins in John 8:7, where Jesus says:

Let him who is without sin cast the first stone.

Stones can also be slang for diamonds, which would be fitted onto chains. Travis uses these metaphorical stones as motivation, pushing his team to be more successful.']])]

genius_description:
“Goodbyes” serves as the second single for Post Malone’s third studio album, Hollywood’s Bleeding. The track also marks his first single of 2019 and the first collaboration between Post and Young Thug. Throughout the song, Post sings about troubles with a girl and expresses his desire to remove her from his life, while Thug’s part seems to suggest that he’s trying to reconnect with a girl, which is in complete contrast to the rest of the song.

The music video for the track features Post being stabbed and killed in the very beginning. Throughout the remainder of the video, a zombified Post emerges from his grave and walks around the Wild West-like town where he comes across Young Thug singing to the same crowd that killed him earlier on. There, he confronts the girl who left him behind originally, which could be a reference to Post’s ex-girlfriend, Ashlen Diaz.

A snippet of the song originally surfaced online on March 12, 2019, and the full song leaked on March 14, 2019. After speculation by various media outlets, Post confirmed the track would be released on July 5, 2019, in a Twitter post.
genius_annotations:
[('Say you needed this heart, then you got it (Got it)
 Turns out that it wasn’t what you wanted (Wanted)
 And we wouldn’t let go and we lost it
 Now I’m a goner', [['These lines may be directed toward Post Malone’s previous girlfriend, Ashlen Diaz. Their relationship appears to have ended as of 2018.



Not much is known about their history as both have kept relatively quiet about it. Post commented on briefly on the situation in a 2016 interview with The Breakfast Club:

It’s been rocky sometimes, but you can imagine that with everything that’s going on […] It’s tough having a balance, between dedicating my life to music and dedicating time for Ashlen.']]), ('[Verse 3: Young Thug]', [['A snippet of “Goodbyes” leaked online on March 12, 2019, with the full track being leaked two days later on March 14. While the leaked version is very similar to the version that was officially released, the leaked version featured a few more bars from Thug:

I just wanna see the side, the one that’s unbothered (Yeah)
And I just wanna hit it one more time, yeah
I don’t wanna damage your love, I ain’t tryna damage your love, woah
And I don’t want ya to never go outside (Outside)

It’s currently unknown why these bars were stripped from the official version.

Thug also confirmed the lyrics to his verse in a post to his Instagram story on July 5, 2019.']]), ('Now I’m drinkin’ again, 80 proof in my veins', [['Proof is a term that goes back to 16th century England to measure the ethanol/alcohol in beverages. They would drop gun powder pellets in booze to see if it would burn or not. The booze was taxed higher based on the pellets burning or not burning.
80 proof is basically 40% alcohol. The use of the measurement ‘proof’ today is mainly historical since we now use alcohol by volume (ABV).']]), ('You’re Barbie life doll, it’s Nicki Minaj', [['“Doll” is used as a term of endearment or as a description of a flawlessly attractive woman. Nicki Minaj has long referred to herself as “Barbie” (a literal doll), dating back to her debut mixtape Playtime is Over, released 12 years before “Goodbyes.” Nicki celebrated its anniversary on her Instagram during the same day.



The two have collaborated frequently in the past. Nicki remixed Young Thug’s “2 Bitches (Danny Glover)” in 2014. The two then collaborated indirectly on “Low” and “Throw Sum Mo” before directly collaborating on “Anybody.”']]), ('Me and Kurt feel the same, too much pleasure is pain', [["Kurt Cobain was an American musician, best known as the lead singer for the rock band Nirvana. On March 3, 1994, the singer was hospitalized after ingesting too much champagne and Rohypnol. Some view this as Cobain’s first suicide attempt, but many did not have this impression when it originally happened. Kurt eventually died by suicide on April 5, 1994.

Post uses this bar as a way to explain that even though popular musicians live exciting lives, there are also serious mental and emotional consequences that come along with it. He expressed similar views on his April 2018 track, “Rich & Sad”:

All this stuntin' couldn’t satisfy my soul (-oul)
Got a hundred big places, but I’m still alone (–one)

Post Malone is a big fan of Nirvana, and specifically Kurt Cobain, whose portrait he has tattooed on his left middle finger—his fingers are reserved for artists who heavily influenced his life. He has covered Nirvana’s classic December 1993 song, “All Apologies,” live during a concert and also has an unreleased song called “Kurt Cobain” with Rich the Kid.



From left to right: Bankroll Fresh, Dimebag Darrell, George Harrison, John Lennon, Stevie Ray Vaughan, Kurt Cobain, and Elvis Presley."]])]

genius_description:
In “High Fashion,” Roddy Ricch uses a smooth, laid-back delivery to list an extensive inventory of luxury status symbols.  Though he insists he “ain’t no player,” he also brags that he has a collection of women, and hopes that displaying his wealth in this way will persuade the object of the song to join it as his “Prada Bae.”

The song is the 11th track on Roddy’s debut album and his second collaboration with Mustard, after his feature on June, 2019’s “Ballin'.”
genius_annotations:
[('High fashion like Goyard', [['Goyard is a French designer brand founded in 1853, originating from Paris. The company specializes in leather goods and products range from one thousand dollars to five thousand dollars plus.

Here, Roddy Ricch compares the high quality of his stylish clothing to that of the items designed by Goyard.']]), ('If I hit it from the back, she gon’ hit the sidewalk', [['Roddy uses a double entendre in this line when speaking about the “sidewalk”.

When he hits her from the back (alluding to the doggy-style sexual position), the impact of the sex will have her stumbling as she walks – walking sideways instead of forwards.

Also, Roddy could also be alluding to how the doggy-style position is usually used for quick-sex which has no passion. To “hit the sidewalk” means to kick somebody out to the streets. She isn’t special, after the sex, he doesn’t want to see her again.']]), ('I put some ice on you ’cause you got a cold heart', [['Ice is an slang term used to describe expensive jewelery with incrusted diamonds.
Roddy may have bought jewelry for his girl.']]), ('I put some ice on you ’cause you got a cold heart (Ooh-ooh)', [['Ice is an slang term used to describe expensive jewelery with incrusted diamonds.
Roddy may have bought jewelry for his girl.

Roddy gives expensive diamond-encrusted jewelry to the women around him. He gifts them jewelry because he knows they don’t care about him and will leave him if he was broke.']]), ('I put some ice on you ’cause you got a cold heart', [['Ice is an slang term used to describe expensive jewelery with incrusted diamonds.
Roddy may have bought jewelry for his girl.']]), ('Mustard on the beat, ho', [['DJ Mustard’s signature tag spoken by YG. It was first used on YG’s song “I’m Good.”

The tag is very recognizable as it has been used on numerous hit songs including Rihanna’s “Needed Me”, Big Sean’s “I Know”, 2 Chainz’s “I’m Different”, Omarion’s “Post To Be”, and Jeremih’s “Don’t Tell Em.”']]), ('She want Chane’-ne’ and Dio’-o’
 I’m only doin’ cash out, I don’t need promo', [['As the song a flex of luxury items that Roddy posses and that his girl wants here he mention the designer brands “Chanel” and “Christian Dior”, which he has previously mentioned in War Baby on the album:

I’m a hood nigga that turned rich so I got Dior’s latest."

Further highlighting the lifestyle he mentions that he pays for everything with cash and doesn’t need promo codes.']]), ('Know you want the shoe with the red at the bottom, bae', [["This line refers to French shoe designer Christian Louboutin, who filed a US trademark infringement claim of red-soled shoes against his former employer Yves Saint Laurent in 2011.

The brand is routinely name-dropped by contemporary rappers, including Roddy himself, who also mentioned it in “Ballin',” his previous collaboration with Mustard."]]), ('And I keep a Patek, too, ’cause I don’t do facades', [["Roddy is not all talk; he makes sure to always flaunt his riches, in this case a Patek Philippe watch. He has previously mentioned his disdain for others manufacturing the façade of wealth on his 2018 hit “Down Below”:

Look at my bank account, I’m runnin' up the digits
I ain’t into all that “Doin'-that-facade” shit"]]), ('And her name ain’t Megan but she a stallion, stallion', [['Roddy references fellow rapper Megan Thee Stallion. Megan has had, just like Roddy Ricch, a very successful 2019 that has found her scoring high charting hits, for example, her summer anthem “Hot Girl Summer.”

The popularity of the Houston female rapper has been heavily associated with the rise of the term “stallion,” which describes an attractive girl.

Plus, in the summer of 2019, both the artists have been included in the prestigious XXL Freshman Class, an event that helped their promising careers develop considerably.']])]
