genius_description:
“The Other Side” is the first single from the Trolls World Tour soundtrack. Justin Timberlake plays main character Branch in the film, and its predecessor—his solo lead single for the first Trolls movie, “Can’t Stop The Feeling” was a global smash.

SZA joins Justin Timberlake here. Given the second film is all about bringing together different genres and collaborators, having more than one artist on the lead single fits.

The song is produced by the Grammy and Oscar Winner Ludwig Göransson and Justin Timberlake himself. It brings back the disco vibe from the 70s.

genius_description:
On “Lost In Japan,” Shawn Mendes demonstrates his commitment to a lover by expressing his desire to visit them on the other side of the world. The song was released a day after the single “In My Blood.”

While “In My Blood” incorporates a rock-arena sound, “Lost In Japan” showcases R&B-heavy beats.

The song’s artwork is an ode to Japan, depicting the country’s national flower, the Cherry blossom.
genius_annotations:
[('I was hoping I could get lost in your paradise', [['This paradise could be Japan, where the lovers are both saying, or it could be Mendes’s love interest’s mind. If the latter is true, Mendes admires this person’s inner and outer beauty and thinks of them as a human paradise.']]), ('Looking through your timeline
 Seeing all the rainbows', [['In a Q&A in Sweden with fans on 15 March 2019, Shawn Mendes explained:

You know why I rewrote that lyrics? It’s because we were in L.A. and there was this massive rainbow and everyone was posting it on their Instagram stories and Twitter and I was like looking through my timeline…and there was like rainbows and stuff.

https://youtu.be/14f41s7F3kc?t=735']]), ('I could feel the tension
 We could cut it with a knife
 I know it’s more than just a friendship
 I can hear you think I’m right, yeah', [['“Cut the tension with a knife” is an idiom that describes a situation so saturated with nervous energy it might as well have a physical presence—just like the tangible presence of this person’s thoughts.

On an interview, he said “I can hear, through her breath that she thinks the same. She doesn’t need to say nothing.”']]), ('All it’d take is one flight
 We’d be in the same time zone', [['On March 18, 2017, Shawn played a show in Manila, Philippines, and the next day he tweeted that he was on his way to Tokyo, Japan:

https://twitter.com/ShawnMendes/status/843358450168020994

Manila is a lot farther than a “couple hundred miles” from Japan (it’s almost 2000 miles away) but it’s the closest location to Japan he’s ever toured, other than Japan itself. Manila’s PHT time zone is only an hour behind Japan’s JST.']])]

genius_description:
“Electricity” is the long awaited collaboration between production duo Silk City (consisting of industry veterans Mark Ronson & Diplo) and Dua Lipa.

The song was first teased when Dua Lipa was seen in the studio with Silk City in January 2018, and confirmed after Silk City dropped their debut single “Only Can Get Better” in May.

Mark Ronson later revealed the title in an interview with The Times magazine, complimenting Dua Lipa’s voice;

She has this deep, soulful voice that harkens back to gospel house.

“Electricity” is expected to be the lead single from their debut EP/album and will be included in Dua Lipa’s debut album repack.

genius_description:
“long story short” is a brisk-paced overview of the public demonizations that Taylor has experienced since her feud with Kanye West in 2016. The drama has taken subject in numerous songs of Taylor’s, appearing all the way back on her sixth studio album, reputation. However, “long story short” offers a confirmation of resolution and peace, with Taylor finally feeling confident that that stage of her life has subsided.

“long story short” is a particular ode to Taylor’s current boyfriend, Joe Alwyn, who she began dating around the time of the drama. Chronicled in a handful of Taylor’s songs, “long story short” further emphasizes that Alwyn has always been her “safe place” throughout turmoil.
genius_annotations:
[('At the golden gates they once held the keys to', [['“They” seems to be the media and public, who contributed to Swift’s loss of control over her image after her spiral in 2016. She referenced this idea on her 2017 hit “Look What You Made Me Do”:

I don’t like your kingdom keys
They once belonged to me

During that line in the “LWYMMD” music video, Swift sat in a golden bird cage:



A still from Taylor Swift’s “Look What You Made Me Do” music video.']]), ('Climbed right back up the cliff
 Long story short, I survived', [['As fans on Twitter noticed, this lyric mirrors one from Swift’s July 2020 track “hoax,” on which she sings:

Stood on the cliffside
Screaming ‘give me a reason’']]), ('Evermore', [['A very obvious ode to the album’s title, evermore.

The previous track, “cowboy like me” includes the lyric:

Forever is the sweetest con

Here, Taylor knowingly ignores the fact that “forever” doesn’t exist, and pledges her eternal love anyway. Combined, these two lyrics contribute to the album’s theme of speculation about the future (as referenced by the title), concluding that the inevitability of what is to come doesn’t matter anyway – that Taylor chooses to believe that her love will last forever, whatever the truth may be.']]), ('And he feels like home', [['The metaphor of her lover as her home– especially in terms of a physical location– is a favorite of Taylor’s. Think of the house as the representation of the relationship in the “Lover” music video, the symbolism of the apartment in “Cornelia Street,” or mourning the end of a relationship with “I’m not your homeland anymore” in “exile” and “I can go anywhere I want, just not home” in “my tears ricochet.” This line is perhaps the simplest iteration of that concept.']]), ('But if someone comes at us, this time, I’m ready', [['In the past, Taylor had talked about how most of her relationships died out after the media got ahold of it and ruined their connection by overexposure and denying them of privacy. In this lyric, Taylor makes a point to emphasise this relationship’s importance to her, learning from her past mistakes and being ready to defend herself this time. Her most known reference to her relationship with media effecting her personal life is in the song “I Know Places” in her 1989 album, the lyric follows as:

“Something happens when everybody finds out
See the vultures circling, dark clouds
Love’s a fragile little flame, it could burn out
It could burn out

‘Cause they got the cages, they got the boxes and guns
They are the hunters, we are the foxes and we run"

Here however unlike I Know Places, she is facing her enemies and hunters.']]), ('I always felt I must look better in the rear view', [['This is the idea of constantly comparing the present to what was. What you had. What you were. That everything was easier because you were a better version of yourself last month, last year, last decade. Which would be difficult for someone like Taylor, who has been in the spotlight since 2006. Someone who has been seen so much musical and personal development in that time.']]), ('And I fell from the pedestal', [['Since this is a song about Taylor’s public demonization during the Reputation era, this line could very well suggest that she fell from the pedestal she was put on in the 1989 era. This could have been a result of the Kanye phone call ‘incident’.']]), ('I tried to pick my battles ’til the battle picked me', [['“Pick your battles” is a common idiom used to encourage a person to not concern themselves with petty conflicts or challenges they might not win. In this line, Taylor takes notice to the fact that, despite her best efforts to avoid drama, such drama always ends up finding and involving her.

This line is also an example of the literary device antimetabole, in which a phrase is repeated with the words reversed, in order to highlight the irony within the inversion.

Taylor similarly sang about her battles picking her in 2017’s “End Game”:

I swear I don’t love the drama, it loves me']]), ('When I dropped my sword
 I threw it in the bushes and knocked on your door', [['These lyrics echo a sentiment from August 2019’s “Daylight,” which describes Swift’s hope for an everlasting relationship after years of heartbreak:

Threw out our cloaks and our daggers
Because it’s morning now
It’s brighter now']]), ('Past me
 I wanna tell you not to get lost in these petty things
 Your nemeses
 Will defeat themselves before you get the chance to swing', [['Swift has experienced several public issues and feuds with other celebrities, most notably rapper Kanye West, fellow popstar Katy Perry, and mogul Scooter Braun.

Though a teenage Swift forgave West for interrupting her speech at the 2009 Video Music Awards and wrote 2010’s “Innocent” as an ode to him, he and this then-wife Kim Kardashian fabricated a story about her approving vulgar lyrics to his 2016 track “Famous”:

I feel like me and Taylor might still have sex
Why? I made that bitch famous (Goddamn)
I made that bitch famous

Kardashian posted illegally-recorded footage claiming that Swift approved the lyrics, but the “evidence” was edited and the full call leaked years later, proving Swift wasn’t aware of the “bitch” line. She wrote songs like 2017’s “This Is Why We Can’t Have Nice Things” about the ordeal.

Swift’s conflict with Katy Perry started around 2013, when Perry allegedly “stole” dancers that Swift was planning on bringing on her Red Tour. Swift reportedly wrote 2014’s “Bad Blood” about the situation, and in 2016, Perry released a perfume called Mad Love that seemingly drew from a key “Bad Blood” lyric:

Baby, now we got bad blood
You know, it used to be mad love

By 2019, the ladies reconnected, and Swift invited Perry to appear in her “You Need to Calm Down” music video. Swift even sent Perry and Orlando Bloom’s daughter a hand-embroidered blanket in September 2020.

Scooter Braun infamously bought the masters for Swift’s first six studio albums in June 2019, when she hadn’t gotten the opportunity to buy them herself. She began rerecording her albums to regain ownership of her work, starting with Fearless (Taylor’s Version) in April 2021.']])]

genius_description:
The titular closing track on the standard edition of evermore is a meditative piano ballad tracking the narrator’s journey from a seemingly unending period of deep depression and hurt to a place of hope.

Like “happiness,” “evermore” deals strongly with themes of mental health, though this track lays out a more linear path towards healing. Fittingly, Swift has publicly discussed her struggles with significant periods of depression in the past.
genius_annotations:
[('And I couldn’t be sure
 I had a feeling so peculiar
 This pain wouldn’t be for
 Evermore', [['This is a callback and reversal of the lines throughout the song. Taylor is recalling a difficult time through most of the song, most likely the summer of 2016, which she called an apocalypse.



She thought that the pain and suffering from that time period would never end. As the song goes on she describes the emotional turmoil she went through, and how one person, likely Joe, was the only one there for her. By the end she has realized that pain would not last forever, and she can finally heal.']]), ('I’m on waves, out being tossed', [['This references back to her earlier statement about being unmoored, but in a more intense and chaotic way that is in keeping with the music during the bridge versus in the earlier verses. The added drama in the metaphor reinforces the intensity of feeling the bridge creates.']]), ('I rewind the tape, but all it does is pause', [['Taylor has lived her life on screen for many years, making it easy for her to watch back public moments and see all the criticism surrounding her every move. In addition to this, she has also filmed a documentary (Miss Americana) which details some of the trials she has been through on her journey. The metaphor is her remembering all the moments in her life that have led to her feeling hopeless, and the fact that she can literally replay videos of her life only adds to the intensity.

I think this line also refers to the idea that sometimes there are moments in life we want to rewind and figure out where we went wrong. “all it does is pause” reminds me of that feeling when you’ve lived through something traumatic (“very moment all was lost”) and you’re so heartbroken your memories become frozen and you can’t access them. Maybe Taylor is trying to understand her past self and feels that there is a barrier there she cant overcome.']]), ('That this pain would be for
 Evermore', [['This line from the chorus is reminiscent of Swift’s “Sweeter Than Fiction,” the lead single off the soundtrack of the 2013 British film One Chance, where she sings:

This pain you thought would last forever and ever

This reference also foreshadows the shift later in the song where the narrator recognizes:

This pain wouldn’t be for evermore

Just as the narrator of “Sweeter Than Fiction” saw her husband overcome the trials and tribulations of his life, so too will the narrator overcome their own troubles.']]), ('Whether weather be the frost
 Or the violence of the dog days', [['“The dog days” is a saying that refers to the hottest, laziest, sweatiest days of summer. Here, Justin Vernon recasts this slow and lethargic time of year as violent. This contrast highlights the kind of emotional turmoil the first half of the song is about.

Taken as a whole, the “dog days” lyric is the opposite side of “whether weather be the frost.” In other words, the weather may change, but the despair he’s singing about doesn’t.']]), ('To be certain, we’ll be tall again', [['Swift described a relationship as “tall” and strong on August 2019’s “Paper Rings”:

Honey, without all the exes, fights, and flaws
We wouldn’t be standing here so tall']]), ('To be double-crossed', [['Like lyrics in the first verse, this could be a cursory reference to Taylor being “betrayed” by the leaking of edited footage in the Kanye West scandal. This incident has been covered in several of her songs, including “This is Why We Can’t Have Nice Things”.']]), ('That this pain would be for
 Evermore
 (Evermore)', [['“For evermore” is a lyric Swift has used before, though in a much more positive light. She first used it on 2014’s “Welcome to New York,” the opener to 1989:

It’s a new soundtrack
I could dance to this beat, beat, for evermore
The lights are so bright
But they never blind me, me

She notably used the phrase on 2017’s “New Years Day,” which is about her relationship with actor Joe Alwyn — Alwyn even co-wrote “evermore.”

There’s glitter on the floor after the party
Girls carrying their shoes down in the lobby
Candle wax and Polaroids on the hardwood floor
You and me for evermore']]), ('Floors of a cabin creaking under my step', [['Here Taylor wraps up the journey she quietly takes us on through this song. In the first chorus she stares out a window and in the second chorus she’s her “barefoot in the wildest winter” presumably outside where she was staring. Both choruses say “catching my death” and feel the pain would be for evermore. Taylor finds herself back in a cabin in the third chorus, finally safe again and feeling her pain won’t be evermore

This lyric also describes the imagery Taylor popularised during the folklore era with the cardigan music video.



This same cabin is also featured at the beginning and end of the music video for “willow,” proving that the cabin imagery has continued into the evermore era.

“Wooden floors” remains a phrase sung quite often by Swift in fellow songs like gold rush

“I see me padding across your wooden floors”

and Cornelia Street:

“Memorise the creaks in the floor”']]), ('[Bridge 2: Taylor Swift & Justin Vernon]', [['The first bridge expands the moment of ultimate dispair the character’s going through.

But the second part of bridge might be the most interesting, as it is the persona debating with theirselves. Taylor’s lines describe the how the persona’s will to get better. While Justin’s stand for that part of our minds that tends to drags us back into our problems.

The bridge is familiar of Swift’s and Justin’s previous collabaration exile. Similarly the vocals sung over another repeating the verses is meant to be a simile of a couple talking about their now-ended relationship and looking back each from their own perspective.

It should be noted that both songs exile and evermore were co-written by Swift’s boyfriend actor and songwriter Joe Alwyn.']])]

genius_description:
“exile” describes two ex-lovers seeing each other following a break-up. Justin Vernon describes feelings of confusion about how quickly a lover moved on, while Swift offers a perspective about repeated warning signs that the relationship was no longer working. It’s also worth noting the contrast between Vernon’s rougher voice and Swift’s smoother one, which mirrors the contrast between their views of the relationship.

The song prompted many comparisons to Swift’s 2012 track “The Last Time,” another song that discusses the downfall of a relationship. Much like “exile,” Swift and featured artist Gary Lightbody’s voices contrast in tone, highlighting their differences.

“exile” is one of many folklore songs to contain a movie motif — other songs to do so include “the 1,” “this is me trying,” and “hoax.” It’s also her first collaboration with Bon Iver, who she called one of her “musical heroes” in an Instagram post announcing folklore.
genius_annotations:
[('Like you’d get your knuckles bloody for me', [['Her ex is staring threateningly at her new partner, but she knows he would never actually fight for her. It’s a play on fighting for her; in this line, she means a physical altercation with her new partner. Whereas throughout the song she reiterates that he never really tried to keep their relationship from falling apart, metaphorically not fighting for her/them.']]), ('[Bridge: Justin Vernon, Taylor Swift & Both]', [['Throughout the verses of “exile,” Vernon and Swift give their own perspectives on why the relationship failed. Within the bridge, their two narratives compete, with their voices layering and interrupting each other. This production choice mirrors the cyclical nature of the couple’s past arguments, in which neither felt heard.

Swift explained in a promotional clip she sent to radio stations:

‘exile’ is a song that was written about miscommunications in relationships, and in the case of this song, I imagined that the miscommunications ended the relationship. […] We imagined the beginning would be his side of the story, the second verse her side of the story, and the end would be the story of them talking over each other and not hearing each other.

Producer Aaron Dessner also shared in folklore: the long pond studio sessions:

When we talked about it, I was like ‘I think he’s gonna be really inspired by this’ and then, when we sent it to him, he was. Then, the process of working on it and what he sent it back, we didn’t ask him to write anything, but he wrote this amazing bridge.']]), ('You never gave a warning sign', [['Interestingly, the song concludes with Justin Vernon getting the last word. Throughout the song, Swift is the one who seems to be more proactive towards the relationship’s end, choosing to leave “out the side door” to prevent more arguments and finding a new lover to move on. She abandons the lyrical argument in the same way she left the relationship.']]), ('I’m not your problem anymore', [['This lyric contrasts a lyric in the previous chorus — Vernon’s character sees Swift’s character as his “homeland” he swore to defend, while she assumes he simply saw her as a “problem” he needed to deal with.

You’re not my homeland anymore

The jealousy Swift describes in her verse suggests that Vernon’s character may still have feelings for her, though she may not realize it. As a result, she doesn’t understand how he could possibly be jealous after his obligation has ended. This is one of the ways in which the theme of miscommunication develops over the course of the song before culminating in the back-and-forth bridge.']]), ('And it took you five whole minutes
 To pack us up and leave me with it
 Holdin’ all this love out here in the hall', [['“Exile” is used as a metaphor for being on the outside of a relationship that once was. The opening verse broadens this metaphor slightly, to encompass the experience of moving out after a breakup. Rather than packing suitcases, he had to pack up his feelings for the other narrator.']]), ('You’re not my homeland anymore
 So what am I defending now?', [['Swift previously described her relationship with Joe Alwyn as “home” on her August 2019 track “It’s Nice to Have a Friend,” and it comes up again on December 2020’s “long story short”:

And he’s passing by
Rare as the glimmer of a comet in the sky
And he feels like home

The notion of defending one’s homeland as a metaphor for fighting for love also ties into the running thread of war and battle imagery on folklore — notable examples include “epiphany” and “peace,” on which she sings:

You know that I’d swing with you for the fences
Sit with you in the trenches']]), ('You were my crown, now I’m in exile, seein’ you out', [['Justin Vernon’s chorus refers to his subject as “my town,” while Swift’s chorus refers to her subject as “my crown.” This represents the patriarchal power dynamic of their relationship that Swift escapes out the side door. A king, for example (e.g. “the crown”), rules over his town. The town is ruled by the crown.

The term “crown” can also be used to talk about a monarchical country, like Britain. In this way, it could actually be a parallel statement to the earlier refrain, “you were my hometown”.

As this line relates back to the song title – exile – it also represents how although Swift may have been the one to leave the relationship, she feels exiled (e.g. punished, barred from one’s home) as much as he does. An exile implies being forced to leave town, often unwillingly and punitively. Even though Swift voluntarily left the relationship, she feels forced out by her partner’s inability to read her signs.']]), ('So who am I offending now?', [['Earlier, Bon Iver sings ‘So what am I defending now?’. This change of lyrics in the chorus conveys the difference between the two personas, as one still feels like they are guarding their past lover whereas the other is portrayed as attacking them.

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: Romantic relationship is usually used as a form to fix someone’s problems in midia. In this line, she’s nodding to past relationships where the partner made her feel guilt about her mistakes, as if they were his responsability.']]), ('Like he’s just your understudy', [['In theatre terminology, an “understudy” is the actor who learns to play the part of another so they can replace the original actor at a moment’s notice if needed.

In this context, Swift’s former lover looks at her current lover as if he’s nothing more than a temporary and subpar replacement for himself. This line deepens the imagery of their love being pre-scripted, with the film having already played out before.']]), ('We always walked a very thin line', [['Swift included a similar description of a relationship’s fragility on October 2010’s “Haunted,” another song that describes desperation and anxiety about a crumbling relationship:

You and I walk a fragile line
I had known it all this time
But I never thought I’d live to see it break']])]

genius_description:
Taylor Swift teaches listeners a lesson about self-love and confidence with “ME!” featuring Panic! at the Disco frontman Brendon Urie. It’s a stark turn from her sixth studio album, reputation, released in 2017, which is known for its dark visuals and mature themes.

After a YouTube credits leak the day before its release, the collaboration was confirmed by Swift herself when she appeared with Robin Roberts on ABC. Before Swift went on air, a Spotify billboard in London, England began to promote the track.

The music video for the song gained 65.2 million views on YouTube in its first 24 hours, making it the biggest 24-hour debut for a female or solo artist on the platform, as well as breaking the record for the biggest 24-hour VEVO debut, which she previously achieved with “Look What You Made Me Do.” It also broke the record for most first-day plays on US pop radio, another record previously held by “LWYMMD.”

Contradicting her own pattern, this is the first cover of one of Taylor’s lead singles to not feature a picture of herself.
genius_annotations:
[('I never wanna see you walk away', [['A key theme of Lover is Swift’s desire for a long-lasting romance — she mentions this longing on the title track, “Paper Rings,” “Cornelia Street,” “London Boy,” “Afterglow,” “It’s Nice to Have a Friend,” and “Daylight.”

Swift also speaks about her insecurities regarding relationships on “The Archer”:

Who could ever leave me, darling?
But who could stay?']]), ('I know I tend to make it about me', [['The idea of being unintentionally self-centered is also mentioned on “Soon You’ll Get Better,” a song about Swift’s mother’s battle with cancer:

And I hate to make this all about me
But who am I supposed to talk to?
What am I supposed to do,
If there’s no you?']]), ('And you’re the kind of guy the ladies want', [['Swift’s worries that Joe Alwyn, her boyfriend as of the album’s release, may leave her for someone else appear multiple times on Lover, including on its title track:

I’m highly suspicious that everyone who sees you wants you

Swift brought this line to life in the “Lover” music video, which sees her getting anxious as her lover speaks to another woman at a party:

https://youtu.be/-BjZmE2gtdo?t=95']]), ('Baby doll, when it comes to a lover', [['Before Swift announced that her seventh studio album would be called Lover, she sent fans on a “scavenger hunt” to look for it in the “ME!” music video. She told The Independent:

I think you see it once, and you hear it twice.

Fans can see the album title on a neon sign in the background of one scene:']]), ('Like a rainbow with all of the colors', [['In March 2019, Taylor hinted the release of this track with an image of herself with a rainbow:



In the music video, Swift and Urie even dance in a vivid rainbow scenery. Each color of a rainbow represents individuality. As Taylor said in an April 2019 interview with Robin Roberts:

ME! is a song about embracing your individuality

It’s worth noting that the rainbow flag is the official symbol for LGBT pride, and the flag as a whole stands for diversity and individuality. In April 2019, just weeks before this song’s release, Swift donated $113,000 to a project that helps combat anti-LGBT laws in Tennessee. She’s advocated for the group before on tracks like October 2014’s “Welcome to New York.” Brendon Urie came out as pansexual in July 2018.']]), ('Girl, there ain’t no I in “team”
 But you know there is a “me”', [['Originally, the Bridge was introduced by Taylor shouting, “Spelling is fun,” but was since removed upon the release of the album due to fans and media outlets calling it immature.

Following the release of the track, Taylor retweeted an image of herself wearing a “Garland Elementary Spelling Bee Champion” t-shirt, although she confirmed she bought it from Urban Outfitters. Additionally, both Taylor and Brendon recognize the inclusion of ‘me’ in ‘awesome’ later in the song.



During an Instagram livestream on the day the song released, Taylor explained her intention for the lyric:

We wanted it to be something playful, we didn’t want it to take itself seriously at all.']]), ('Strike the band up, 1, 2, 3', [['Musicians often count to the number displayed at the top of the time signature; however, Brendon counts to three, when the song is actually in common time, otherwise known as 4/4. The line may also act as a play on baseball, where three strikes result in an out.



Brendon’s band, Panic! at the Disco, also used this phrase on September 2005’s  “I Constantly Thank God for Esteban:”

Strike up the band!
Whoa-oh, the conductor is beckoning']]), ('Livin’ in winter, I am your summer', [['On Swift’s October 2010 track “Back to December,” she uses the seasons as a way to emote how summer brings memories of happiness:

And I think about summer, all the beautiful times
I watched you laughing from the passenger side']]), ('I promise that you’ll never find another like me', [['Swift said the following when she officially announced the single:

‘ME!’ is a song about embracing your individuality and really celebrating it, and owning it. I think that with a pop song, we have the ability to get a melody stuck in people’s heads, and I want it to be one that makes them feel better about themselves.

She also mentioned in a live chat, before the video’s premiere, that the chorus was a pivotal moment for choosing Brendon Urie as her collaborator:



In addition, Taylor stated in an Apple Music special:

I’ve been a fan of his Brendon Urie since the early Panic! at the Disco stuff, and it’s so exciting getting to make a song and a video with someone who is that committed as a performer. It just made it so much more playful and wild and mischievous having someone who’s that excited about making music; it really just lifts everything else up. It’s about not feeling replaceable; I feel like we’re sent so many messages every day that there’s like a better version of us on a social media app, with like better abs in a better vacation spot. But, like, you’re the only one of you.']]), ('And trouble’s gonna follow where I go', [['On her October 2012 hit “I Knew You Were Trouble,” Swift regrets that she didn’t see the warning signs that a relationship was unstable. This suggests that despite finding a long-lasting love with Joe Alwyn, her boyfriend as of the release of “ME!,” she still has insecurities about her romances.

She also voiced her anxiety about her relationship with Alwyn on the chorus of November 2017’s  “Delicate”:

Is it cool that I said all that?
Is it chill that you’re in my head?
‘Cause I know that it’s delicate
Is it cool that I said all that?
Is it too soon to do this yet?

A similar concept appears on November 2017’s “End Game”, featuring Ed Sheeran and Future, on which Swift addresses how public opinion of her has shaped her life:

Reputation precedes me, they told you I’m crazy
I swear I don’t love the drama, it loves me']])]

genius_description:
“coney island” marks Swift’s first collaboration with The National after working heavily with band member Aaron Dessner on both the writing and production of evermore and folklore.

Like much of The National’s extensive catalogue, the track is subdued and melancholic sonically. Through the use of back-and-forth conversational lyrics littered with imagery that is rich with bygone experiences, it evokes a heavy feeling of loss and nostalgia for a past relationship where effort was not equal from both sides.

The lyrics contrast with the title location itself–Coney Island–a neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York that is famous as a tourist destination for its lively carnival park setting. Additionally, the community district is Brooklyn 13, a number that is particularly special to Swift.
genius_annotations:
[('Sorry for not making you my centerfold', [['A centerfold is the page that a magazine most readily and naturally opens up to. It is where the binding is, therefore the magazine naturally splits in half revealing this page. It doesn’t require a crease.

When she apologizes to her past lover by saying that she’s sorry for not making them her centerfold, she is saying that she’s sorry that her lover wasn’t the first person she went to. They weren’t the ‘page’ that she naturally turned to when she faced problems in life. Therefore, they weren’t her first priority.']]), ('[Bridge: Taylor Swift, Matt Berninger, Both]', [['Some people have speculated that, since many lines in the bridge may refer to Taylor’s old relationships, the singer in the bridge may indicate who was at fault for the end of that relationship: when Matt sings, it was the man’s fault, while when Taylor sings, it was hers.']]), ('When you’re too wise to trust me and too old to care?', [['Here Swift reiterates the sentiment of someone being “older and wiser,” which she first mentioned on the earlier evermore song “tolerate it”:

You’re so much older and wiser, and I
I wait by the door like I’m just a kid']]), ('Did I shatter you?', [['The narrator ‘close[d] her fist around’ their relationship, but it was delicate and broke easily, rather than the delicate relationship described in Delicate, about which Taylor describes being very careful. Here, the aggressive idea of the ‘fist’ has ‘shatter[ed]’ the relationship because the right amount of care was not taken with it.']]), ('And if this is the long haul
 How’d we get here so soon?', [['The reference to ‘the long haul’ suggests that they assumed their relationship would be forever, and the narrator seems confused, asking ‘how’d we get here so soon?’ The ‘here’ she refers to could be the here on the verge of their break up, or just the part in their relationship where she feels alone']]), ('Break my soul in two looking for you
 But you’re right here', [['This idea that the narrator must ‘break my soul in two’ in order to find the other suggests that they must become someone different in their search and eventual discovery of the person. Or perhaps they lose something of themselves in the search? And then it’s revealed that even as the narrator searches, they have missed the person who is right with them – is their relationship distant and cold, and therefore they cannot seem to connect despite the fact that the other is right by them?']]), ('Sorry for not winning you an arcade ring', [['Taylor uses a similar metaphor of a less valuable ring in her song Paper Rings:

“I like shiny things but I’d marry you with paper rings, aha that’s right your the one I want”.

In this song, the singer regrets not giving the subject a symbol of their love, no matter how valuable it may be.']]), ('When the sun goes down', [['Taylor used the sun as a metaphor for using the daylight as a symbol for her love and sundown for a symbol of her heartbreak.

In “Daylight”, she sings:
“I’ve been sleeping so long in a 20 year dark night
And now I see daylight”.

In “hoax” she sings:
“My eclipsed sun, this has broken me down”.']]), ('If I can’t relate to you anymore
 Then who am I related to?', [['Taylor explores the phenomenon of being so consumed in a relationship to the point of losing your own identity, and feeling hollow after the relationship ends.

This lyric echoes a similar sentiment in her 2012 song “All Too Well” where she sings:

I’d like to be my old self again
But I’m still trying to find it']]), ('But when I walked up to the podium, I think that I forgot to say your name', [['At the 2016 iHeartRadio Awards, Taylor thanked her then-boyfriend Adam Wiles (AKA DJ Calvin Harris) while accepting an award.
Later that year, Wiles attended the GQ Men of the Year Awards and accepted the Patron Solo Artist of the Year Award. In his speech he said,

I’d like to dedicate this [award] to my manager Mark Gillespie for being a fantastic man. We’ve been through a lot and discovered a lot this year.

The two had just broken up after 15 months of dating, and many Swift fans were upset that he didn’t thank her, seeing “we’ve been through a lot this year” as a jab at Taylor.
Swifties also speculate that “I Forgot That You Existed” was written about Adam, which ties into this.

The core of the song is reflection on a relationship in which the narrator failed to properly prioritize their lover. This is the person whose face they saw in the moment of fear, the person they most wanted when things were rough, but in their moments of joy, pride, recognition, they failed to give that partner any credit or appreciation.']])]

genius_description: Classic 1963 Christmas song by the Beach Boys, from their self titled Christmas album. Even today, this song still receives frequent radio play around Christmas time.
genius_annotations:
[('With a half a dozen deer', [['“Half a dozen” means six.

Santa actually has eight reindeer: Dasher, Dancer, Comet, Cupid, Prancer, Vixen, Donner and Blitzen,']]), ('With Rudy to lead', [['“Rudy” being Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, FYI.']]), ('And when Santa hits the gas, man, just watch her peel', [['This is, of course, assuming that the said “Saint Nick” vehicle is an automobile that doesn’t require 8 or 9 reindeer to pull it.  Maybe it’s actually a Snowcat?

Of course, the conception of Santa Claus and his sleigh can evolve to something more modern, but still in spirit to what the Beach Boys describe, reindeer-driven or not:"]]), ('Every pad', [['Every house.']]), ('Four speed stick', [['A manual transmission']])]

genius_description:
“FRANCHISE,” released amidst Travis Scott’s famed collaboration with McDonald’s, sees the Houston rapper boasting his wealth and lifestyle. Individual locations of chain restaurants, like McDonald’s, are called franchises. Travis reunites with his friend and frequent collaborator, Young Thug; they are joined by British musician, M.I.A.

“FRANCHISE” pays homage to Dem Franchize Boyz and their 2004 single, “White Tee.” Travis Scott and CHASE B first previewed this single as “White Tee” during the tenth episode of .WAV RADIO on July 20, 2020. It was subtly teased again in the commercial for Travis’ McDonald’s meal on September 8, 2020.

The final Travis Scott and McDonald’s merchandise collaboration released on September 16, 2020, and Travis revealed that there was a secret included in it. This secret was the official pre-order for the single’s imminent release. Five days later, on the 21st, Travis officially confirmed the song’s artwork and release date.

The official music video was premiered alongside the single on September 25. Parts of the video were filmed at Michael Jordan’s Illinois mansion. A lyric video and visualizer were also released.
genius_annotations:
[('[Verse 3: M.I.A., Travis Scott & Sheck Wes]', [['M.I.A.’s vocals were taken from her solo demo of the song, which was chopped up & cut down into a verse and an outro.']]), ('Popped ‘em in his hands, he was typin’ (Da, da, da)', [["Reminiscent of A$AP Ferg’s “Plain Jane”

Grandma had the arthritis in her hands, bad!
She was poppin' pills like rappers in society

Thug details someone suffering from Carpel Tunnel Syndrome from repeated typing on a keyboard, needing to take painkillers to ease the symptoms. On the other hand, he could be implying he is “popping,” or shooting the person in the hand. In both cases, he could be referring to someone excessively “talking tough” online.
https://images.app.goo.gl/aZkKx2bkThTPstRY6

Thugger calls these people out on Lil Durk’s “Internet”

You talkin' that shit on the ‘Gram
It’s never same thing that it’s tagged me in yeah
You on Snapchat goin’ crazy
I fuck around, go in and embrace it
Ain’t nobody seein' yo' Facebook"]]), ('I’m higher than the plane, I’m where the Skypes be (Doo, doo, doo, doo, hee)', [['Here, Thug uses “Skypes” to mean “clouds,” since the Skype logo used to be a cloud. He follows this line by ad libbing gun noises in onomatopoeia to the melody of the Skype jingle that plays when one makes a call using the service.']]), ('Incredible, icki-icki, in general', [['Following in this link-up between UK and US music, M.I.A. references “Incredible”, a 1994 song by British jungle producer M-Beat featuring General Levy on vocals.

General Levy’s instantly recognisable vocal style and pace has made the track very well known within the UK, and is perhaps one of the most famous Jungle tracks.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mL2Bgj-za5k&t=156']]), ('Ran up twenty million, told the Devil, “Keep the luck” (Luck)', [['This might be a reference to Lil Durk stating that Young Thug, in the much memed picture above showed him $20 million and it was this that provoked such apparent concentration and wonderment.

There is also potentially a subtle reference here to Pusha T who had not too long before the release of this song told Young Thug in response to an issue with his Pop Smoke verse: ‘Now y’all run along and be gangsters, but u leave the devil alone!’.

The Devil’s Luck implies that someone is so unexplicably lucky that a deed or pact with the devil must have been formed at some point. However Young Thug is so succesful that contrary to what Pusha T said, he did not need to make such deals to make 20 million and thus can metaphorically afford to offer the devil’s luck back at it as a tip as if saying ‘keep the change’.']]), ('London city, left the town (Ah)', [['M.I.A lived much of her early life in Hounslow which whilst part of Greater London is technically a suburban town. Now she lives in a more central part of London that she considers to be more part of the ‘city’.']]), ('Princey in his prime, yee (Doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, hee)
 Yellowbone too feisty, yee (Doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, hee)', [['Yellowbone is a term used to describe light-skinned, mixed race people. It must be noted that used of the term is controversial. It is likely here that the first and second line both refer to the artist Prince who was light-skinned himself.']]), ('Ancient Anunnaki', [['Anunnaki are the highest pantheon of ancient gods from Mesopotamia. They feature amongst them prominent mythological figures such as Marduk. The name is derived from the Sumerian word for An, god of the sky, Anunnaki thus meaning son(s) of the god of the sky. Their first known references within text and sculpture are over 4000 years old (hence the reference to ancient). Their worship spans across a few cultures: Sumerian, Akkadian, Babylonian, Assyrian, Hurrian and Hittite. Within Hittite Mythology it states that they were overthrown by younger gods.

There is a slight chance that this is a very subtle reference to Travis Scott’s ‘Stop Trying To Be God’.']]), ('I just start the label just to sign me (Woo, woo, ooh)', [['Travis launched his record label Cactus Jack Records in March 2017. Travis spoke on the reasoning for the label’s creation in an interview with Numéro:

I’m not doing it to have financial control over my music. I want first and foremost to help other artists, launch new names, to provide opportunities. I want to do for them what happened to me, but better. By better I mean no bullshit. No lying to the artists about album release dates or the budgets of videos and albums.

The label’s acts include Travis himself, Sheck Wes, Don Toliver, Luxury Tax, WondaGurl, and Chase B.



Cactus Jack Records Logo']]), ('You see the crosses over ya (Yeah), that’s how you know it’s us', [['In this line, Travis is referencing his signature Cactus Jack logo pendants, which are formed in the shape of a cross, stating that these signature cross-shaped pendants are how Cactus Jack affiliates can be identified. Initially, Travis commissioned New York-based jeweler Eliantte to make a large version, with smaller versions created thereafter and distributed to the various Cactus Jack signees. Travis and his Cactus Jack record label’s signees, such as Sheck Wes and Don Toliver, have been seen wearing Cactus Jack jewelry pieces regularly.



Travis wearing a cluster of cross-shaped Cactus Jack pendants']])]

genius_description:
On “Suicidal,“ YNW Melly explains the depths of anguish and hatred he feels after a contemptuous breakup with his significant other and compares it to taking drugs, paraphernalia, and ingesting the French cognac Hennessy to forget about their relationship together.

The track is a standout on his recent album Melly vs. Melvin, which was released in November 2019.

A remix of the track featuring late Chicago rapper Juice WRLD was released on March 13, 2020, with Juice WRLD adding his two cents on the breakup and his own struggles with Hennessy.
genius_annotations:
[('And I got too many enemies', [['In these lyrics, YNW Melly could be referring to the altercations with his crew and YoungBoy Never Broke Again and Quando Rondo. This beef could be traced to YNW Melly’s loyalty to King Von, who has been in many altercations with Quando.

Another circumstance could refer to people who drop hateful comments on his social media pages, including those who turned against him after he was charged with double murder in February 2019.

Aside from the previous reasons, the “enemies” could be those in Melly’s head, as it is known that Melly has split personalities and some other mental disorders.']]), ('But you didn’t even put it all on the line
 For me, no, oh, I’m sorry
 This is the end of us
 It’s crazy ’cause my heart is dangerous', [['In this lyric, Melly explains how a past relationship ended due to his ex-partner not putting effort into maintaining the relationship.

Melly also explains how his heart is dangerous and how his ex was playing with it. Melly can be referring to his split personality, Melvin as he is known to be dangerous and aggressive. He speaks more on this topic on “Pieces”, released on July 2, 2021. He describes his heartbreak by saying:

‘Posed to be my peace, instead you broke my heart to pieces
You broke my heart to pieces
You broke my heart to pieces

He also says:

God, send me an angel to heal my heartbreak

In “Far Apart”, released August 13, 2021, Melly describes the feeling of having a broken heart while saying:

Those shattered dreams and broken hearts of lonely distant days']]), ('Suicidal
 Your love is suicidal
 Lately I’ve been feeling suicidal
 Your love is suicidal', [['YNW Melly details his relationship with his partner as “suicidal,” because it was hurting his mental health and self esteem. He was also experiencing depression and suicidal thoughts due to the breakup process.

The mention of “ecstasy” holds different meanings—the joyous emotions which Melly used to feel when he was with his ex and his use of MDMA, the primary ingredient of both ecstasy and molly.

Melly also refers to alcohol use, specifically, the popular cognac Hennessy, to help cope with this emotional trauma. In the music video for “Suicidal”, an animation of Melly’s head even explodes after he grasps a bottle of Hennessy:
https://youtu.be/9OmgXxiKV7A?t=54']])]

genius_description:
“365” is a collaboration between Zedd and Katy Perry. The track was originally confirmed by Zedd  in August 2018 and later registered online in January 2019.

It was rumored that the release date for “365” would be February 7th, 2019, but the song was actually released on February 14th after Katy teased the music video on Instagram with the caption “Valentine’s Day is going to be extra obsessive this year”.
genius_annotations:
[('Got me fantasizing our initials already', [['Katy’s so in love with this someone that she already think about their marriage. This is possibly about her now fiancé Orlando Bloom. Some people choose to change their last names when they get married, hence why she’d be thinking about her initials. Instead of KP, you get KB (Katy Bloom).']]), ('And I know I said go slow, but I can’t hold back no more', [['We can’t control what we’re going to feel about someone or something. Even though sometimes we don’t really want to have feelings with someone else, the heart wants what it wants. Katy knows she said to her love interest to go slow but she couldn’t stop her feelings towards him blossoming real fast.']]), ('I hope you feel the same thing', [['While getting to know somebody, it’s almost natural that one is going to fall in love. Here Katy is in this situation but she doesn’t know if the other person feels the same as her and maybe she’s to affraid to ask him because the answer might be “no”, so all she can do is hope that the feeling is mutual.']]), ('I want you to be the one that’s on my mind
 On my mind, on my mind
 I want you to be there on a Monday night
 Tuesday night, every night
 Are you gonna be the one that’s on my mind?
 3-6-5, all the time
 I want you to be the one to stay
 And give me the night and day', [['Katy is singing about how she wants her love to be the one in her life and nothing else will matter on her time.

Opposing, the music video assimilates this to obsession in relationships that can often be sick and bad for both: Perry is a robot programmed to love your mate, representing the way people idealize love.']]), ('Got a premonition this ain’t gonna be a fling
 You make the weekend feel like a year
 Baby, you got me changing
 24/7, I want you here', [['Katy could be singing to her fiancé, Orlando Bloom. The two were engaged on February 14, 2019—Valentines Day.

https://www.instagram.com/p/Bt5gRBDHNZl/']])]

genius_description:
Producer ​benny blanco teams with Juice WRLD as well as Panic! at the Disco singer Brendon Urie on “Roses,” a highly-emotional ballad of love and loss.

Released on December 5, 2018, “Roses” represents a unique trend of rappers teaming up with alternate rock artists and blurring the boundaries between their genres. Juice WRLD puts his flexibility on full display, able to blend his music perfectly with Urie’s outstanding vocals.
genius_annotations:
[('But I’m ballin’ like a young Maverick', [["Juice compares how well he’s doing in the music industry at the then age of 19 with a double entendre to a young player of the Dalllas Mavericks, who are a basketball franchise apart of the National Basketball Association.



2018/19 players from left to right: Luka Dončić, Harrison Barnes, Dennis Smith Jr., Dirk Nowitzki, and DeAndre Jordan

Juice said similar lines on his Fire In The Booth freestyle, where he raps:

Ballin' like a Maverick"]]), ('Make her pop it like a zit, huh', [['To “pop it” is a coined phrase in hip-hop referring to having sex with a woman—it could also be referring to a woman “popping” her butt out and arching her back, which is also in reference to intercourse.

With this lyric, Juice WRLD likens the phrase with popping zits or pimples. Although it’s not medically advisable, many people will grow exasperated with their pimples and “pop” them, by squeezing and putting pressure on the zit so that it drains the pimple and removes it.']]), ('No father-havin’, I’m a bastard', [['Juice WRLD claims that he is a bastard, someone who was conceived to a non-married couple. This, however, is only half true. Juice WRLD’s mother was in fact eloped to Juice’s father when Juice was conceived.

He may believe (or wish) he is a bastard due to the fact that his father divorced and left his mother to care and look after him and his older brother when he was only three years old. Because of this Juice has expressed his hate towards his father and love towards his mother many times.



At the time of this track, the most recent occurrence of his parental hatred was on his single “Armed & Dangerous”

I called my mom, told her I made it
Yeah, mama, your son too famous (Yeah)']]), ('This heartbreak music is such a passion
 I thought I left it inside the past-tense', [['Juice WRLD’s popularity has blown up seemingly overnight, as many of his followers love his emo-rap themed “heartbreak music,” which has a similar vibe to artists like Kid Cudi or XXXTENTACION.

In this line Juice tells us how passionate he is about his music, especially heartbreak music. This theme was present throughout his entire first album “Goodbye & Good Riddance,” especially with commercial super hits such as “All Girls Are the Same” and “Lucid Dreams.”

He thought he put his heartbreak behind him, but here he is rapping about it again. Not only can making emotional music help him heal and get over his heartbreak, but his fans also love it and it is bringing him success in the music industry, so he continues to make “heartbreak music” bangers.']]), ('You gave me your heart, it was made of plastic', [['This line references a line from Juice WRLD’s previous hit, Lucid Dreams.

You were made outta plastic, fake
I was tangled up in your drastic ways

This line in the context of the song means that his ex, who he is missing, didn’t really care about him and didn’t truly love him.']]), ('Roses are red, violets are blue (Check)
 My heart is dead, I’m such a fool
 Why did I fall for you?
 I gave it all for you
 Roses are red (Check), violets are blue (Check)
 My heart is dead (Check), I’m such a fool (Check)
 Why did I fall for you?
 I gave it all for you', [['The famous nursery rhyme “Roses Are Red” derives earliest from Sir Edmund Spenser’s poem, “The Faerie Queene”:

She bath’d with roses red, and violets blew,
And all the sweetest flowers, that in the forest grew.

The original poem meant to reflect early Elizabethan virtues, such as temperance, chastity, friendship, and courtesy for knights during their travels.

Here, Juice WRLD changes the meaning of the nursery rhyme to question a woman testing his heart too far, abusing his trust in her.']])]

genius_description:
“Eastside” focuses on the relationship of two people who fall in love. It follows them as they go through their relationship and as they reminisce about their memories together.

The song marks the debut of the multi-award winning songwriter, producer and musician Benny Blanco, featuring Khalid and Halsey. Its release was first hinted at by some of his fans on Twitter, just days before its release. Benny Blanco himself then confirmed the song through Twitter on 11 July 2018:
https://twitter.com/ItsBennyBlanco/status/1016748701572714497
genius_annotations:
[('In the city where the sun don’t set', [['Wordplay is used here. The east is where the sun rises from, but you can, of course, see the sunset on the West of the Eastside. It shows the correlation they tried to convey between the East on a map and the Eastside of their city.

Although Khalid was born in Fort Stewart, Georgia he identifies himself as being from El Paso, Texas. This is likely to be a reference to El Paso since the city’s nickname is ‘Sun City’ due to its hot/dry climate and its beautiful sunsets.

An additional meaning is Khalid alluding to New York City, as New York is commonly known as “the city that never sleeps”. In fact, Halsey’s old stomping grounds were New York City, and the East Side is every Manhattan neighborhood bordering the East Rivery. Perhaps the sun doesn’t set due to the skyscrapers surrounding the narrator’s field of view, and the neon lights that light up the city, even at night.

Lastly, in a metaphorical sense, the fact that the “sun doesn’t set” symbolizes the hope and optimism of this happy time in their relationship. The day feels like it will never end, just like happiness of their relationship.']])]
genius_comments:

genius_primary_artist: ‌benny blanco, Tainy, Selena Gomez & J Balvin
genius_description:
“I Can’t Get Enough” is a bilingual electronic song by producers Benny Blanco and Tainy with vocals by American singer Selena Gomez and Colombian rapper J Balvin.

Featuring distorted drums and a melody made out of Gomez’ humming, the song features elements of moombahton, as well as Latin and American pop music. The song was released via Blanco’s own record label, Friends Keep Secrets.
genius_annotations: [('Dice que no le es suficiente (Wuh)\n ’Tá mal de la mente (Yah)', [['Jhay Cortez, who is an amazing artist and songwriter, sat down with me and Balvin to create Balvin’s verse and I really love this verse of his like just the start. He’s saying “She says it’s not enough” and she’s messed up in the head doing everything I can right now over here and she’s like still not enough. So it just feels cool.']])]

genius_description:
“hot girl bummer,” blackbear’s first single since his fifth studio album, ANONYMOUS, was released alongside a low-budget music video directed by Gilbert Trejo, which blackbear and his best friend Cesar Silva creative directed.  This was followed on November 21st, 2019 by a new, higher budget video via Vevo, directed by Adam Powell.

The song is blackbear’s spin on the #hotgirlsummer trend. Megan Thee Stallion fans, who originated the trend, inspiring the song “Hot Girl Summer” reacted negatively to the song, claiming that blackbear appropriated the idea. blackbear, however, claimed the song “has to do [with] the caption trend” and doesn’t parody the song. In fact, he teased the song and title during July 2019, before the release of Megan’s “Hot Girl Summer” on August 9th, 2019.

On the cover art of this playful, energetic track, Maddy Crum, who was previously featured in Aidan Cullen-directed short film, THE ANONYMOUS SAGA, is pictured with a face covered in colorful stickers and a nosebleed. She shared an Instagram story wearing merchandise and another using the official Snapchat filter designed by Harley Wrecks to mimic the cover a few hours before release.



The release date, August 23rd, 2019, marks the one year anniversary of “the 1” and the sixth year anniversary of “N Y L A,” both singles of his.
genius_annotations:
[('They can’t fit me in a Trojan', [['Here the speaker trots out one of the most common excuses for not wearing a condom: the old, self-flattering “it won’t fit me” line.

In fact, a typical condom can hold a gallon of water, and brands like Trojan offer extra large ones for those who still don’t feel like that will accommodate them.']]), ('And you want me to change? Fuck you!', [['I feel like ‘Tim and Eric’s Billion Dollar Movie’ is a very slept on movie. It’s, like, really, really, really funny. And that part is probably my favorite scene from the entire movie, and it’s where Will Forte is playing Allen fucking Bishopman from E-Z Swords. The government pays him to not sell swords, and if he doesn’t sell any swords, he’s even better off. So it’s like a really funny, like, thing, and I just love the, “Fuck you.”']]), ('I’m pullin’ up wit’ a emo chick that’s broken', [['In today’s age, I know a lot of people that think it’s very cool to be depressed, and, like, I kind of do that. You know, on my Twitter, you read it, it’s like, I might’ve been happy that day, but I’m like, “I’ll die waiting for you.” I’m pulling up with that cool, sad girl.  It’s like a vibe now. It’s cool to give off that vibe, like, I’m mysterious, but I’m like suicidal or something.']]), ('Out of pocket, but I’m always in my bag', [['I’m hearing things like, “Out of pocket,” is one. But, “In my bag,” is one too. So, I don’t know if I’m in my pockets or if that’s not right. Should I be in my pockets? Should I be in my bag? I don’t know what to do with my hands. You know what I’m saying? So that’s what that’s about.']]), ('This that drip, it’s more like oceans', [['This that drip is more like oceans. I just hear, like, the drip. People talk about the drip, you know what I mean? The drip is in you. It’s not on you. The drip, you know what I mean? Hearing things like that, left and right.']]), ('They can’t box me in, I’m too left', [['The first verse is kind of from a female’s perspective, talking about the purses and all that. And then the second verse is kind of from the guy’s perspective. So that’s how the song’s set up.
s. It’s things I’m hearing people say all the time, just, like, “I’m too left. You can’t box me in. You can’t fit me in a Trojan.” You know what I mean? Like, this Magnum baby, you know, it’s on site.']]), ('I’m through, I’m through, I’m through
 This that hot girl bummer anthem
 Turn it up and throw a tantrum', [['I wouldn’t even say it’s an anti anything. It’s anti-self. It’s anti-me. It’s anti a part of me that I don’t even like really. It’s my needing and longing to be super cool guy. Yeah. It’s kind of like a fuck you to myself.  Turn it up and throw a tantrum honestly almost feels sarcastic in a way. It’s like here’s this big fuck you, turn it up, brother. But mute that shit.']]), ('Fuck you, and you, and you', [['I’m standing on top of this couch at the club. I’m like, fuck you to everybody. They’re like, I hate you. Whatever. It’s a whole thing. It’s a big fuck you fest, a big dick size judging contest almost. I fall victim to that. Also, it’s almost like when you’re in a relationship and the person is like, “I hate your friends,” it’s okay, I hate them too. It’s almost my relationship with society in a way. Not society even, just culture in a way. Where it’s like I need you, culture. You know what I mean? I need you, but at the same time it’s fuck you.']]), ('One more line, I’m superhuman', [['That’s a double entendre. For this one, I just wanted to for the last line talk about one more line, I’m super human. Obviously, that could be a drug reference, too. It could be a drug reference or it could just mean the last line of the verse.']]), ('This that 10K on the table
 Just so we can be secluded
 And the vodka came diluted', [['I spent 10K on a table. I’ve heard rumors that they dilute the vodka so that they can use half the bottle or whatever it is. I don’t know how they do it. I definitely. When I do go to the club, I have to get my section because I don’t want to go to somebody else’s table and drink they bottles or whatever it is. I actually don’t even drink. Almost three years now I haven’t drank. My last few experiences with the club have been I’m buying all these bottles for other people to have fun and I’m standing up on a couch of whatever, even though you’re not supposed to stand on the couches, but everybody does. You’re just saying fuck you to all these people, but you need them there. Them people, you need them people there to feed your validation, your ego. I don’t know. I’m just kind of poking fun at myself this whole song really. That’s what it’s really about, the whole thing.']])]

 God only knows how it’s killing you', [['This is referencing God’s omniscience as described in the Bible, some of these verses are Psalm 147:5:

Great is our Lord, and mighty in power; His understanding is infinite.

1 John 3:20:

For if our heart condemns us, God is greater than our heart, and knows all things.

And Psalm 44:21:

Would not God search this out?
For He knows the secrets of the heart.

To be omniscience means to be in the state of knowing everything, so God knows exactly what you’ve been through and how it makes you feel.']]), ('But there’s a kind of love that God only knows', [['This love that God only knows is in reference to God’s steadfast and unconditional love for us as described many places in the Bible. Psalm 136:26 states:

Give thanks to the God of heaven, for his steadfast love endures forever."

God loves you more than anyone else could, and only God can love this way.']])]

genius_description:
“Level of Concern” is a “simple but hopeful” song about Tyler’s thoughts concerning the effects the coronavirus made on society and the music industry. In the song, Tyler’s thoughts are presumed to be shared with his wife Jenna as he also asks them for comfort, even if it is a lie.

Inspired to write a song during the pandemic to help the workers in the live music industry, Tyler decided to make his first attempt at writing on an electric guitar. A portion of the single’s proceeds were donated to Crew Nation, an organization that helps individuals who work in the live performance industry who were laid off during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The song’s music video shows Tyler and Josh quarantined in their homes with their families, with Tyler’s then-newborn daughter Rosie appearing in the band’s media for the first time. Tyler and Josh collaborate on the song and video by mailing the USB drive from the single art back and forth to each other.
genius_annotations:
[('Things are starting to get heavy, mm
 I can’t help but think I haven’t felt this way
 Since I asked you to go steady', [['KISS 107.1 Cincinnati tweeted some of the song’s deeper backstory, revealing that much of the song is inspired by Tyler’s relationship with his wife, Jenna, with whom he had just celebrated their five-year wedding anniversary. The radio station shared:

Tyler’s mom inspired him to write a song for their fans in this unprecedented moment in all of our lives. He decided to write about the last time he felt this out of control. This virus has taken such a huge toll on everyone and as a new dad now in lockdown it makes him feel helpless. He chose to turn it into a love song about his wife. He compares this time of little control to that moment when he decided to commit to a life with Jenna & that uneasy feeling of realizing that when you make that kind of a commitment to someone else, you give up a good portion of control. Its no longer all about you, its about us!

Throughout the song, Tyler compares the commitment of a relationship to being in a quarantine together and a “bunker underneath the surface.”']]), ('Panic on the brain, Michael’s gone insane
 Julie starts to make me nervous', [["In an Facebook Live interview with 101WKQX, Tyler shared that he is not calling out a Michael and Julie that he knows, saying:

I guess when I was writing that song I loved the idea of just name dropping two random people because I feel like everyone has a Michael and a Julie in their life that are either thinking they’re experts on what’s going on in the world or experts on your personal relationship. I personally have a friend named Michael but I don’t think I was thinking of him particularly as much as I was just picking two names that I felt applied to what most people would think as annoying people.

The “Michael” Tyler is talking about is the same one fans assumed he was originally calling out. This is Michael Gibson, who was twenty one pilots' tour manager for five years and ended his career with the band in August 2016, just after Blurryface received it 2x multi-platinum certification by the RIAA. Michael made a fake reaction to the supposed namedrop in an IGTV reaction video as well as a an Instagram post calling Tyler insane."]]), ('Need you, tell me
 Need you, tell me', [["Often during times of crises, people lie that things are going to get better when they don’t actually think they will. They just say they will to comfort those around them.

Tyler is presumably asking for comfort from his wife Jenna throughout the song, a theme that was introduced in “Tear in My Heart” and returned in “Smithereens.”

But if I’m feelin'
Someone stepping towards you, can’t describe
Just what I’m feelin'
…
And you know
I got your six…

This shows their working marriage relationship in that they both support and help each other. Jenna often posts about the two of them on Instagram. When their daughter Rosie was born, she wrote to Tyler in a post saying:


tyler,

you’re a thinker, you’re a trooper, you’re a fixer, you’re a looker still at 6am with no sleep. you work so hard. you are the most diligent and supportive person, I’m lucky you’re my person. Rosie and I love you."]]), ('I don’t really care what they would say
 I’m asking you to stay
 In my bunker underneath the surface', [['With the coronavirus came stay-at-home orders from each state to their residents. However, many people objected to this order due to their desire to remain in contact with other people. While this increased their risks for the coronavirus and being arrested, they saw it as a necessary risk in order to spend time with other people.

The bunker Tyler is referring to is most likely his studio space of a basement. It was a dream project of Tyler’s to have his own dedicated space to tinker and write like that, creating a sort of mini-home for him inside his house. The basement was introduced during the leak of “My Blood”. After Warner decided to release the song early due to its virality on YouTube, they allowed Tyler to upload a now-unlisted video with him playing alongside the studio recording in his new space.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BnAJCv7Aibu/

This may also be a reference to the time Tyler asked God to stay and support him in “The Run and Go:”

Don’t wanna give you all my demons
You’ll have to watch me struggle
From several rooms away
But tonight I’ll need you to stay

While still longing for support, Tyler receives it this time from his family in “Level of Concern.”']]), ('’Cause I told you my level of concern
 But you walked by like you never heard', [['Many people grew more concerned about the coronavirus as time went on and it spread. This lead to stay-at-home orders and social distancing guidelines. However, several people ignored these regulations due to their low level of concern both for themselves and those around them.

Initial reports claimed the disease was most intense with infants and elderly people due to the susceptible state of their immune systems. However, that claim has since been denied but still frightens many parents with younger children. The recent birth of his daughter, Rosie Robert Joseph, may have caused Tyler’s level of concern for her well being to rise.

https://www.instagram.com/p/B82Ctp5ArwE/']]), ('Panic on the brain, world has gone insane', [['This song was released during the coronavirus panic so many of the track’s lyrics mirror what was happening in the world at the time. “World has gone insane” likely references the fact that the World Health Organization had recently declared the outbreak of COVID-19 a pandemic. “Panic on the brain” most likely refers to the state of panic that numerous people went to, many of them buying stores out of supplies like toilet paper.

COVID-19, or the coronavirus, is an infectious disease that causes respiratory illness symptoms that are similar to pneumonia. Those suffering from it often experience a cough, fever, or in more serious cases, difficulty breathing. Many citizens all around the world were being encouraged to quarantine themselves in their houses in an attempt to help slow the spread of COVID-19, and with the United States issuing state-wide stay-at-home orders.



The music video for this song shows band members Tyler and Josh quarantined in their houses with their families, pushing the idea that they love spending time with their families despite the social distancing guidelines.

This line could also a pun on the phrase “Would you be my Valentine?”']])]
